IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The limited efficacy of current therapies in metastatic patients argues that we do not fully understand metastasis. The metastatic capacity of prostate cancer (PCa) behaves along a spectrum of disease that contains an oligometastatic state where metastases are limited in number and location. The ROBIN OligoMET Center will test the global hypothesis that consolidative radiation can alter cancer cell state plasticity and host-tumor metabolism that drives metastasis formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our vision is to advance PNA5 as a first-in-class therapy to reduce inflammatory-disease related cognitive impairment in patients at risk for Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) and Vascular Contributions to Cognitive Impairment and Dementia (VCID). With the completion of this project we will obtain the protocols and necessary documentation to amend our IND for our peptide to begin Phase 2 clinical trials to treat cognitive impairment in patients as risk for developing ADRD and VCID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Memory impairment and disruptions in sleep architecture co-occur in various neurological disorders, suggesting that elucidating the mechanisms underlying the entanglement between memory and sleep may offer the opportunity to improve the lives of people suffering from memory disorders as well as promote the significance of healthy sleep habits for the general public. The proposed multidisciplinary project seeks a transformative understanding of memory processes and consolidation during sleep by combining the unique capability of direct recordings from the human brain at multiple levels of resolution—single neurons, localized neuronal assemblies, intracranial local field potentials—in neurosurgical patients monitored with intracranial depth electrodes, and computational power of artificial intelligence. Furthermore, the project will probe causal mechanisms of consolidation by application of auditory and electrical stimulations—with high temporal and spatial precision— using innovative model-driven closed-loop technology, which can help lay the foundation for future therapeutic interventions of memory disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Delaware Center for Neuroscience Research Public Health Relevance Summary The foundation of Phase III proposal is Delaware’s expanding set of human and research resources in neuroscience, which has Delaware neuroscience research competitive on a national level. Our project supports research aimed at determining how thoughts, memories, feelings and actions emerge from dynamic activities in the brain and are changed over time; as well educational programs to develop a workforce that can participate in and benefit from advances in our understanding of brain function. An increased understanding of how the brain and nervous system functions will facilitate treatments for diseases and injuries and provide insights into human behavior, biases, and cognition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Numerous attempts of drug therapy to substantially impact the outcome of patients suffering from glioblastoma have failed over the last 15 years. Indeed, the approval of temozolomide chemotherapy dates back to 2005, and bevacizumab will improve quality of life of some patients, however failed to prolong survival. Reasons for failures are tumor heterogeneity, the exquisitely immunosuppressive microenvironment of glioblastoma, the blood-brain barrier preventing sufficient drug concentrations in the brain, investigations of single agents to an unselected patient population rather than combinatorial approaches and biomarker-based treatments of enriched populations. Our U19 proposal unites renowned translational and clinical investigators from two top and NIH-funded institutions with a strength and dedicated research in brain tumors, evaluating and comparing different approaches of optimized immunotherapy against glioblastoma. We leverage collaboration and pipeline(s) of innovative biotechnology companies who will support our proposal with drugs, devices, but also with access to their expertise and experts, platforms and laboratory investigations, as needed. Thus, this U-19 grant will enable and facilitate a powerful new consortium that will synergize and is able to efficiently translate preclinical findings to meaningful early clinical trials and treatments for patients suffering from glioblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Ceramides are products of fat and protein metabolism that accumulate in individuals with obesity or dyslipidemia and are strongly linked to insulin resistance. Herein we propose to leverage large-scale epidemiologic and clinical cohorts to identify associations of ceramides with colorectal cancer risk, and animal experiments to study the efficacy of new ceramide-lowering interventions. Our study will clarify the key role of ceramides in the metabolic dysregulation underlying colorectal cancer and identify new targets for colorectal cancer prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Delaware Center for Neuroscience Research Public Health Relevance Summary The foundation of Phase III proposal is Delaware’s expanding set of human and research resources in neuroscience, which has Delaware neuroscience research competitive on a national level. Our project supports research aimed at determining how thoughts, memories, feelings and actions emerge from dynamic activities in the brain and are changed over time; as well educational programs to develop a workforce that can participate in and benefit from advances in our understanding of brain function. An increased understanding of how the brain and nervous system functions will facilitate treatments for diseases and injuries and provide insights into human behavior, biases, and cognition.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Public Health Relevance Project Narrative: The goal of this career development award is to transition Dr. Brady Post to independence as a health services researcher with a long-term research agenda focused on how system-level integration of providers affects quality and equity. Rapid and widespread integration between hospitals and cardiologists has unknown consequences for health equity, particularly among rural residents. This grant will apply mixed methods to collect insights from physicians, managers, and patients, providing the evidence needed to develop an effective policy response to the opportunities and dangers presented by widespread hospital-physician integration.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Implications of hospital-physician integration for urban-rural equity in access, care coordination, and outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECTIVE NARRATIVE The heterogeneity of chronic pain conditions, and the complexity and diversity of underlying pathological mechanisms, make it challenging to identify tractable targets with broad implications for therapy. This proposal will identify a convergent signaling protein linking nociceptive activity to the maladaptive synaptic plasticity that underlies the development of chronic pain triggered by different pathological factors. This contribution is significant because it uncovers a conserved mechanism underlying the development of different types of chronic pain and identifies a novel therapeutic target that could be translated into the clinic to treat chronic pain with broad implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The application is aimed to support NCI-funded cancer research projects from investigators at the Wistar Institute Cancer Center, the Fox Chase Cancer Center at Temple University, the Sidney Kimmel Cancer Center at Thomas Jefferson University, and other academic institutions using proteomics and metabolomics technologies offered by the Wistar Proteomics and Metabolomics Shared Resource. Supported research projects are diverse with focus on many different types of cancer, such as prostate, ovarian, and melanoma, and experimental samples include immortalized or primary cells, biological fluids, and tissues. The analytical assays will provide insight into perturbed biological pathways and identify key biomolecules associated with disease states, with the final goal of developing methods for cancer prevention, diagnosis and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lupus is a chronic, multisystem, autoimmune disease with profound associated morbidity and early mortality that disproportionally affects women and certain ethnic populations (e.g., Asian). Lupus has a substantial genetic component, and recent studies on lupus and other autoimmune diseases have linked several single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) with autophagy-related genes, suggesting their role in lupus and general autoimmunity. This project will identify and map the most likely SLE-predisposing variants at six autophagy-related loci discovered in Asian populations, determine their functional roles, and uncover the molecular mechanisms that contribute to SLE pathogenesis across multiple ethnicities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chlamydia trachomatis (CT) infection remains the most prevalent sexually transmitted infection worldwide and causes a significant disease burden, especially reproductive morbidity in women. Understanding T cell-mediated immune responses that help in clearing CT infection will provide important information for CT vaccine design. This study will examine the role of HLA-E mediated CD8 T cell immune responses in clearing CT infection in women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection is a significant public health challenge especially among people who inject drugs (PWID) and people living with HIV (PLWH), populations disproportionately represented within the Department of Corrections. To improve the HCV care continuum, the Louisiana Department of Health launched a comprehensive HCV Elimination Plan that includes an alternative payment strategy to provide access to HCV medications and a peer-support treatment program, Connect for Cure, within correctional facilities. In this project, we will investigate the impact of HCV treatment in HIV/HCV coinfected and HCV monoinfected incarcerated persons on HCV elimination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW MEXICO STATE UNIVERSITY LAS CRUCES
PHR: Project Narrative Human biology depends on complex circuits of communication between our cells and tissues, and when this communication becomes dysregulated disease can occur. Technologies have been developed to “listen in” on the communications between our cells by measuring the cellular release of signaling molecules, but these tools are poorly suited for measuring the release of macro-molecular signaling vehicles called exosomes. Our research program develops new technologies needed to “listen in” on exosome-mediated communications, which will ultimately lead to a better understanding the mechanisms of neurological and metabolic disorders.

PROJECT_TITLE: New technologies for in situ measurement of exosome release from brain slice cultures

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Public health narrative Atherosclerosis of the arteries feeding the brain, even in the absence of artery narrowing, is thought to be responsible for a significant percentage of unexplained strokes. While vessel wall magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of brain arteries can image atherosclerosis, there are no efficient ways to measure them across multiple hospital scanners to understand how to treat such strokes. We will develop an automated analysis software using artificial intelligence-based methods to help clinicians measure the level of atherosclerosis and thereby allow them to use vessel wall MRI in clinical decision making of unexplained strokes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Glioblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumor and one of the deadliest human cancers. We found that calcium channels, known as T-Type calcium channels, are upregulated in glioblastoma and drive malignancy. We propose to study what T-Type calcium channels do in glioblastoma, how they work, how they interact with the surrounding brain, and if we can target them for therapy using a repurposed FDA approved drug and other therapeutic strategies. If successful, these studies will improve our understanding of the molecular mechanisms of glioblastoma and lead to the development of new and more efficient therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it addresses fundamental questions about sleep biology. Despite the importance of sleep for human health, our understanding of how sleep is controlled remains rudimentary. In this proposal, we will use a simple sleep model to investigate the basic mechanisms of sleep regulation at the molecular, cellular, and circuit levels, which will provide new insights into a general principle of sleep regulation.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Many elderly Veterans and those with spinal cord injury rely on a wheelchair seating system, made up of a wheelchair and an effective pressure relief cushion. Used together these provide mobility and sitting stability while decreasing skin breakdown risk and increasing overall sitting tolerance. This project will develop the next-generation low-cost high-performance customizable modular pressure relief cushion. 3D printing will be used to build cushions with SquishINS inserts that combine lightness and variable stiffness. 30 Veterans who are full-time wheelchair users will use personalized modular cushions for two weeks each. Personalized cushions will be created using a cushion fitting process we have already developed and tested. Microenvironmental conditions will be monitored during use. A cost analysis will ensure the customized modular cushion applies value-driven principles. User satisfaction will be measured along with the effects on daily function, skin status and seated tissue health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE In humans, microRNAs bind to target messenger RNAs and prevent their translation into protein, thereby maintaining the integrity of gene expression. To this end, microRNAs need to be loaded into one of four human Argonaute proteins, but how these proteins recognize their specific target RNAs remains unclear. We will solve this question in our proposed experiments so that the outcome will contribute to the development of a cure for microRNA-mediated diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Long-term survivorship is now a real possibility for patients with relapsed/refractory large B-cell lymphoma (LBCL) treated with the chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy. Almost nothing is known about neurocognitive and patient-reported outcomes in patients undergoing this treatment, however. The current study will investigate longitudinal changes in these outcomes in the first year after CAR T-cell therapy compared to individuals without cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE Fetal alcohol syndrome disorder (FASD) is a leading cause of intellectual disability in the United States and is due to maternal alcohol consumption during pregnancy. While the neurodevelopmental disruptions caused by prenatal alcohol exposure are diverse, disrupted axonal and dendritic growth (brain wiring) is a consistent finding. In this proposal we test the novel hypothesis that the wiring defects are caused by dysregulation of a tyrosine kinase called Src making this enzyme a target for neuroprotective strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proper function of neuronal circuits critically depends on the ability of neurons to identify their correct synaptic partners. In this proposal, I identified the extracellular matrix glycoprotein nephronectin (Npnt) as a candidate for mediating synaptic specificity in retinotectal circuits and aim to understand its role in retinal ganglion cell subtype laminar targeting and synaptic choice. By uncovering new molecular cues that direct synaptic specificity within mammalian circuits, my study offers insights to inform therapies to regenerate these circuits in response to ocular and neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) causes long-lasting effects on the brain and body characterized by progressive neurodegeneration and chronic inflammation, respectively. The proposed studies will investigate the bidirectional impact of TBI on bone marrow and aim to reveal how changes in the immune system accelerate aging and brain injury. The determination of hematopoietic stem/progenitor cells and bone marrow-derived leukocytes as causal factors of neurological impairment will dramatically improve our understanding of the neuro-immune axis, provide means for improving diagnostics, and open up new windows of treatment for TBI survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Our goal is to uncover molecular mechanisms underlying myopathic chronic intestinal pseudo-obstruction and megacystis microcolon intestinal hypoperistalsis syndrome, life-threatening forms of visceral myopathy characterized by smooth muscle weakness. Heterozygous missense mutations in gamma smooth muscle actin (ACTG2) are the most common cause of visceral myopathy, but the mechanisms of disease are unknown. Using innovative strategies, including recombinant expression of actin in human cells, advanced quantitative image analysis in human intestinal smooth muscle cells, and visceral smooth muscle- specific differentiation of stem cells, this project investigates mechanisms of ACTG2 mutation-induced visceral myopathy and could lead to new drug screening approaches and novel therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative The risk of Alzheimer’s Disease, a form of dementia estimated to affect over 6.2 million people in the U.S., has been linked to diabetes and other forms of cardiometabolic dysfunction. In this proposal, we hope to expand the understanding of the link between diabetes and Alzheimer’s Disease by examining measures of brain health, including functional connectivity. In a diverse and well-characterized cohort of older adults, we will examine how metabolic impairment and vascular dysfunction affect the functional connectivity phenotype of cognitively healthy and AD individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current study aims to develop an intervention that will address alcohol misuse within Latinx sexual minorities by targeting intersectional forms of discrimination (i.e., racism and heterosexism) as there are no behavioral health interventions that address the unique needs of Latinx sexual minorities within the context of alcohol misuse. The study will adapt a Latinx focused motivational interviewing intervention (Culturally Adapted Motivational Interviewing [CAMI]) using an LGBTQ-affirmative intervention adaptation model to develop a culturally-congruent intervention, with community partnerships, to conduct a pilot randomized controlled trial. Findings will provide initial evidence for a novel intervention to decreases alcohol-related problems and misuse for Latinx sexual minorities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Asthma is a leading cause of children’s hospitalizations, missed school days and caregivers’ missed work days that has a significant impact on low income families. We seek to increase asthma control for children with uncontrolled asthma and health disparities, in order to improve the outcomes of activity, symptoms, and reduce asthma exacerbations. We will evaluate whether two interventions, an evidence-based school asthma program and an assessment of social determinants of health, with the aid of an asthma navigator and school nurse champion can be disseminated and implemented in other school settings to reduce the risk of asthma attacks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of this proposal is to fill a critical gap in the knowledge of the role of beta cell genetics and biomarkers on C-peptide preservation in two longitudinal cohorts of patients with new onset type 1 diabetes or those with chronic pancreatitis who have undergone total pancreatectomy with islet autotransplantation. These studies will utilize large genomic data sets and beta cell biomarkers to elucidate heterogeneity in newly diagnosed patients with type 1 diabetes and a model of patients who have undergone cell therapy treatment. Taken together, these investigations will improve our understanding of factors that influence C-peptide preservation in people with type 1 diabetes and chronic pancreatitis and will support future personalized therapy interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Dry mouth due to radiation therapy is a significant toxicity experienced by many head and neck cancer patients, for which there is no effective treatment or preventative therapy. Building on our experience using mesenchymal stromal cells to treat radiation induced xerostomia, we will plan a clinical trial to test the safety of injecting minor salivary gland derived mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs) into their salivary glands to prevent the development of long-term xerostomia after radiation therapy. It is our long-term objective to develop this innovative approach into a new and effective preventative treatment to improve the lives of our patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to public health because degenerative cervical myelopathy (DCM) is the leading cause of chronic spinal injury. Markers of ongoing injury are lacking. This project is relevant to the NIH’s mission because it will investigate the mechanisms of spinal injury in this disease and develop markers of injury that can be used to enhance surgical decision making and prognostication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Providing care for a family member or friend with Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD, hereafter ‘caregivers’) is a common experience for adults in mid- and later-life and can foster experiences that are beneficial to mental health, including increased purpose and feelings of mastery, but can also lead to poor mental health—anxiety, depression, and suicide ideation. Social disconnection is a common experience among ADRD caregivers and is one of the strongest risk factors for suicide ideation, attempts, and deaths. The objective of this study is to examine three indicators of social disconnection—loneliness, low belonging), and perceived burden on others—as mechanisms that increase suicide risk in ADRD caregivers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death in the US and the origins of CVD begin early in life, however, the mechanisms by which early experiences influence CVD risk are poorly understood. This project examines whether the stress responsive hormone placental corticotrophin-releasing hormone is associated with offspring CVD risk and obesogenic eating behaviors in early childhood. Consistent with NHLBI and American Heart Association goals, these findings could elucidate a potential mechanism by which prenatal factors influence cardiovascular health and provide targets for early childhood prevention of later CVD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH) is a highly prevalent global health issue exhibited by ~50% of men by age 50, and 75% by age 80, which may be associated with bladder outlet obstruction (BOO) and lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS). Standard treatments are often ineffective in preventing disease progression and consequent urinary retention necessitating surgery. We hypothesize that aging disrupts the nitric oxide (NO•)-soluble guanylate cyclase pathway to promote the pathogenesis of BPH/BOO/LUTS, therefore the aims of this proposal are to elucidate this pathway in aged male mice and adult mice with selective CYB5R3 knockout in the prostate or bladder, and the mechanism of action underlying the therapeutic effect of soluble guanylate cyclase activator, cinaciguat.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative USH2A and ADGRV1 mutations are the major cause of Usher syndrome and autosomal recessive retinitis pigmentosa, two incurable retinal degenerative diseases. Our study will identify the defective cellular pathways and involved proteins in Ush2a and Adgrv1 mutant mouse retinas at young ages using both unbiased and targeted approaches. If successful, the findings of our study will provide insight into the disease mechanism underlying USH2- associated retinal degeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Cognition, learning, and memory all rely on precise neurotransmission and plasticity at synapses in the brain. These processes rely on the local abundance of glutamatergic neurotransmitter receptors called AMPA receptors. This project will focus on how AMPA receptors are locally regulated by cell adhesion molecule LRRTM2, both basally and during synaptic plasticity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Accumulating research suggests that barriers to eliminating the persistent racial disparities in cardiovascular disease (CVD) are related to understudied structural inequality, yet this research is largely limited to descriptive associations because high quality cohort data typically lack access to novel structural determinants. This project proposes an innovative solution by leveraging high-quality structural determinants from administrative datasets linked with high-quality prospective cohort data to investigate longitudinal associations between structural determinants and racial disparities across CVD outcomes. Establishing temporality and evaluating mediators in the association between structural determinants and CVD is an important step to establishing causality and identifying modifiable structural risk factors may help design population-level interventions to target specific structural policies and practices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Candida auris, an emerging multi-drug resistant fungal pathogen causes life-threatening infections in humans. This study will define the underlying mechanism(s) by which microbiota regulate the skin colonization of C. auris. Results from this study will expand the knowledge about how microbiota and host factors regulate C. auris, with the long-term goal of developing novel therapeutic strategies to prevent and control invasive C. auris infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: While we have significantly advanced the therapeutic options for breast cancer over the past decades, older women are still often making the difficult decision of withstanding the harsh side effects of chemotherapies and consequent severe reduction in quality of life, or not undergo treatment and have their lifespans cut short. Here, we aim to change this paradigm by defining how breast cancer metastasis interact and adapt to the old host tissue environment. Our overarching goal is to unveil novel therapeutic targets that can be effectively used to treat late-stage metastatic breast cancer in older women and thereby significantly impact their prognosis as well as quality of life.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Asian Americans are the fastest growing major racial or ethnic group in the US. The Asian American Community Cohort-New York will be a state-of-the-art cohort research infrastructure to serve as the platform to collaborate and implement innovative research in Asian Americans, particularly focusing on Korean and Chinese Americans.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Narrative This proposal is to provide short-term, mentored research training to students at the beginning of their veterinary training and inspire them for careers in biomedical and translational research. Veterinarians are uniquely qualified to advance health of humans, animals, and the environment via their in-depth training and knowledge in 1) population systems, food safety, and security, 2) recognition and control of infectious diseases that are transmitted among animals and humans (interspecies), and 3) spontaneous animal models of human diseases. With the additional research training that will be acquired through this program, these future veterinary-scientists will be primed to pursue scientific interrogations to address the gaps in knowledge in the animal-human-ecosystem interface and various public health challenges facing the nation and make significant contributions throughout their careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed embedded pragmatic trial leverages existing data from a newly launched SNAP cross- enrollment outreach and enrollment assistance program among 900,000 Michigan Medicaid beneficiaries. The dual purposes of the study are to (1) estimate the effect of SNAP outreach and enrollment assistance on health, health care utilization and SNAP utilization among low-income adults with disability and (2) characterize the subgroups who may benefit most from the program, based on race/ethnicity, age and chronic conditions. Information from the proposed research is urgently needed to advance health equity and improve food access.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposed US-UK study will include a total of more than 4.75 million children, including more than 458,000 IVF-conceived children born 1991-2018 (346,000 born from fresh embryos and 112,000 born from frozen embryos), 88,000 naturally-conceived siblings, and 4.2 million naturally-conceived control children, with 80.6 million person-years of follow-up, averaging 14.4 years in the US (ranging from birth to age 22) and 18.3 years in the UK (ranging from birth to age 36). Linking IVF treatment data, birth outcomes, and cancer and mortality data for study children and their parents in the US, and additionally childhood morbidity data, and height and weight at ages 4-5 and 10-11 in the UK, this study will provide a comprehensive contemporary picture of child health after conception by in vitro fertilization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The aim of this project is to understand how neuronal populations in the human frontal cortex underpin the cognitive capacity for goal-directed decision-making. To make good decisions, we need to keep track of our goals, so that we can select the actions most appropriate to achieving them. We seek to understand how three key parts of the frontal lobe play a role in the process of selecting and keeping in mind goals as we make decisions and take actions. Understanding how this works is an important step toward knowing how goal- directed decision-making can go wrong in various psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The majority of type 2 diabetes (T2D) cases could be prevented or reversed through successful implementation of diet and lifestyle treatment and prevention strategies, yet diet and lifestyle interventions are difficult to adhere to due to an abundance of calories in the environment, which includes calories from sugar sweetened beverages. This proposal presents a unique sub-study within an ongoing randomized controlled trial and existing population-based cohort studies aiming to explore the underlying mechanisms of how sugar- and artificially sweetened beverage consumption influence T2D risk factors; we aim to identify novel biomarkers of dietary consumption that could lead to an individualized, objective assessment of beverage intake to increase efficacy of dietary interventions for T2D prevention. The unique career development plan provides training in the design and management of RCTs, the implementation of cutting-edge multi-omic statistical analysis techniques, and scientific leadership in T2D prevention that complements the applicants current training in nutritional epidemiology, omics, and biostatistics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The AT(N) framework has been validated to reflect AD pathophysiology, and operationalized postmortem and antemortem, with critical contributions from our group, however, its translation to blood remains challenging. While plasma Aβ42/Aβ40 and p-tau address the A and T aspects of the AT(N) framework in blood, an AD-specific N marker is lacking because neither plasma t-tau nor NfL – the current N markers in blood – predicts AD pathology at autopsy, associates with plaque and tangle pathology, or differentiates AD from non-ADs. The public health significance of the proposed research is that it will improve the specificity and accuracy of blood biomarkers by enabling a complete set of A, T, and N markers that that are specific to AD pathophysiology, and also validated in diverse communities including those most impacted by AD but have received the least resources in AD research and care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Early Onset Parkinson’s disease refers to a sub-group of patients where the disease starts early in life (before the age of 50 years) and has a profound impact on most of patient’s life and on important productive years. A clear understanding of the pathogenic mechanisms of EOPD is lacking, although this is crucial for the successful design of therapeutic strategies and stratifying patients for clinical trials. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it aims to clarify the contribution of recognized important pathogenic mechanisms of Parkinson’s disease (genetics, inflammation, and alpha-synuclein accumulation) in patient with Early Onset Parkinson’s disease to help patients stratification for clinical counseling and clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Cardiovascular disease (CVD) has become a major concern in people living with HIV (PLWH). Findings of this study will advance our understanding of shared etiologies of multiple HIV-associated CVD comorbidities and provide novel insights for prevention and treatment of a range of cardiovascular disorders in PLWH that may apply to other high-risk groups. Because gut microbiota, related host immune activation and metabolic pathways are suitable for direct therapeutic intervention (e.g., prebiotics, probiotics and postbiotics, immune inhibitors), our findings may have important implications for the high public health burden of these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Vertebral compression fracture (VCF) is the most common type of osteoporotic fracture and is associated with increased morbidity and mortality. Only 1/3 of VCFs are symptomatic, and the remaining cases are found incidentally, highlighting the need for more rigorous screening for VCF and also identifying those at risk of VCF. Therefore, we propose to develop a cloud-based platform for automatic, opportunistic screening of CT image studies that will stand by in the central imaging data server of a hospital, investigate each non-investigated spine CT study, and flag the studies of patients that are detected to have osteoporosis or vertebra(e) at risk for fracture.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The central dogma told us that DNA makes RNA makes protein; yet, we have learned that mRNA, now being used for vaccines and other therapeutics, is more than exact copy of the DNA. Chemical changes to the RNA – called RNA processing – diversify the coding potential and stability of RNA, changing the constellation of proteins each cell makes. We aim to understand the mechanisms of RNA processing, which occur during transcription of DNA, by investigating how coupling between transcription and processing regulates gene expression in living cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Learning and executing motor skills is critical for everyday life and involves precisely coordinated and modulated activity of multiple regions in the brain. This proposed study will use a combination of state-of-the- art approaches to identify how motor signals from distinct brain regions can interact and be modulated in the thalamus, a central hub within the brain. Ultimately, this study will provide insights on fundamental brain motor functions that can impact the development of new treatment approaches for motor disorders, such as Parkinson’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed work is to generate and test a VR-based intervention to improve the wellbeing and quality of life of older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI). This project is highly innovative as it is using a VR-based delivery method and harnesses the human capital of older individuals seeking volunteer experiences to engage in meaningful social and cognitive engagement with other older adults with MCI as intervention partners. The intervention development will apply a user-centered iterative design approach to generate and evaluate the Social Engaging Restorative Virtual Environment (SERVE), which will provide older adults with MCI an opportunity for social interaction through a variety of social and cognitively engaging collaborative activities within their own homes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer is primarily a disease of aging and is the most common cause of cancer death in the United States. Lung cancer screening can prevent lung cancer death among adults ages 50-80 with heavy smoking histories, but national guidelines disagree on who is healthy enough to justify the immediate risks of screening. This project will identify who is being screened for lung cancer across three metrics of health and determine who is most/least likely to experience harms from lung cancer screening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative/ Health Relevance Post-menopausal bone loss is an unresolved clinical problem, and a clinical trial for using beta blockers (BBs) to improve bone health has recently been funded entitled, “Beta1-selective blockade for prevention of postmenopausal bone loss: A randomized controlled trial”. We propose to test novel mechanistic hypotheses of BB treatment effect using participant-derived samples from this trial, which will enable future personalized treatment strategies and create opportunities for new drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The impact of prediabetes on the future risk for cognitive dysfunction and Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is of great public health significance considering that a) every 1 in 3 people in the US, including half of all adults aged 60 and older have prediabetes, and b) type 2 diabetes is a strong and consistent risk factor for AD. With the availability of accurate and reliable digital technology to detect individualized glycemic patterns and abnormalities much earlier than conventional glucose metrics, as well as cost-effective, sensitive plasma- based screening tools for early AD risk, we have an unparalleled opportunity to understand how T2DM pathophysiology accelerates cognitive decline and AD risk. The proposed research is relevant to NIA’s mission of accelerating discovery of digital biomarkers for the early detection of Alzheimer’s disease and related cognitive dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Goals can change over time, and it is important to adapt our actions according to our current goals. This proposal will examine changes in behavioral strategy and alterations in neuronal processing that maintain adequate decision-making when the brain areas that normally support decision-making malfunction due to prior voluntary methamphetamine taking or being passively exposed to methamphetamine. Our findings will help to understand how drug abusers may maintain adequate decision-making after drug-induced brain dysfunction, and may identify alternative behavioral strategies that could improve this decision-making after past drug use.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The molecular and cellular effects of physiological stress, specifically gestational stress, on the developing oocyte remain largely unknown. However, the molecular machinery for sensing stress hormones is known to be present in the developing oocyte as it progresses through meiotic prophase 1, a process critical for generating genetic diversity and ensuring correct ploidy. This proposal aims to elucidate the mechanistic consequences of physiological stress on the developing embryonic oocyte and on reproductive fitness which has many broader implications for social determinants of health and their population wide effects across generations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WESTERN MICHIGAN UNIV SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunoglobulin A (IgA) is most abundant immunoglobulin in the mucous of the intestine, preventing invasion of pathogens by coating bacteria, and plays important roles in the homeostasis of intestine and microbiota. Although T cell independent (TI) and T cell dependent (TD) IgA secreting cells are well appreciated, their developmental origin as to whether fetal endothelial-derived or HSC-derived remains unknown. This project aims to elucidate the different roles of IgA secreting cells based on their origins, which open a new paradigm in understanding the mucous immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Public and private research funders have invested heavily in implantable neurotechnologies to improve the management of treatment-resistant conditions and ameliorate or reverse loss of function (e.g., deep brain stimulation (DBS)) systems for recovery after traumatic brain injury (TBI), disorders of consciousness, movement disorders, and psychiatric disorders such as obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) and depression). However, even when some research participants show marked symptom relief or gain of function in implantable neurotechnology trials, there is no way to systematically ensure post-trial access to beneficial non-FDA approved investigational devices. To address this concern, this research seeks to interrogate the post-trial access ecosystem in order to promote participant well-being and advance neuroscience by gaining a deeper understanding of participants and their care partners’ trajectory following DBS trials by conducting in-depth interviews with former participants in experimental DBS trials (e.g., TBI, OCD, depression, and Tourette syndrome (TS)), their care partners, and their local physicians as well as researchers, device manufacturers, insurance providers, and key administrative personnel (i.e., representatives of academic medical centers, FDA, public and private research sponsors) regarding challenges and opportunities for post-trial device access, clinical care, and psychosocial support, as well as the scientific possibilities of extended device access and longitudinal follow up.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative While obesity affects more than a third of American adults, we still do not understand how obesity changes the brain to drive feeding and further weight gain. The research proposed here is relevant to public health because it will study neural circuits that reinforce feeding and reveal how they are strengthened in obesity. This aligns with NIDDK’s mission to support research and research training focused on metabolic diseases including obesity, and will ultimately lead to more targeted therapies to prevent weight gain.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although RNA is found in the ejaculate of many organisms, including humans and important insect vectors of human pathogens, little is known about its potential function. This project investigates the function of proteins derived from male RNA that are translated within the reproductive tract of females. The results of these studies will provide novel insights into the role of ejaculate RNA in mediating reproductive outcomes and may inform the design of novel therapies to treat idiopathic infertility and the design of new strategies for controlling insect vectors of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Klebsiella quasipneumoniae, is a distinct and understudied Klebsiella species associated with human disease including urinary tract infection (UTI), which is among the most common adult bacterial infections affecting more than 150 million people annually. Despite its growing recognition as a serious, often multiple-drug resistant human pathogen, the prevalence of K. quasipneumoniae in human UTI and mechanisms utilized by K. quasipneumoniae to establish infection have not been investigated to date. This proposal aims to fill this critical gap in knowledge by defining the clinical prevalence of K. quasipneumoniae in UTI in women and investigating virulence and colonization mechanisms used by recent clinical isolates of K. quasipneumoniae to establish UTI in a well-established mouse model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Endothelial cell senescence is a hallmark of aging-related cardiovascular disease. Studies in this proposal will explore the novel role of HSPA12B in endothelial cell senescence and define how endothelial cell senescence drives myocardial metabolic reprogramming, hypertrophy, and dysfunction. Proposed studies will advance our understanding of endothelial cell senescence in age related cardiomyopathy and provide new targets and strategies to prevent age related cardiac remodeling and heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Aging women are at an increased risk for cardiovascular disease, which is the number-one cause of death for women in the US; those who experience vasomotor symptoms (hot flushes and night sweats) have a 55% increased risk of cardiovascular disease compared with women who do not experience vasomotor symptoms. The proposed research aims to determine whether autonomic regulation and vascular control are altered in postmenopausal women with vasomotor symptoms and uses a novel and innovative approach to determine how a hot flush influences blood pressure regulation. Findings from this study will break new ground on mechanisms that link vasomotor symptoms to cardiovascular disease in these women and will further inform future research on preventive and treatment strategies to improve cardiovascular health in aging women.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite breastfeeding and maternal anti-retroviral therapy, HIV-exposed uninfected infants have substantially higher risk of growth faltering and morbidity than HIV-unexposed uninfected infants. The proposed project will leverage a unique funded Kenyan birth cohort (NICHD 5R01HD096999) including lactating women living with and without HIV and their infants and expand this cohort to include targeted metabolomics of the maternal plasma and breastmilk to characterize the complex relationship between the mother-breastmilk-infant triad and identify metabolomic profiles associated with the infant gut microbiome and infant growth. Findings from this study will be used to develop targeted metabolomic and microbiome interventions for vulnerable HIV-exposed uninfected infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The mechanisms by which anesthetics induce unconsciousness, amnesia, and immobilization are poorly understood. We aim to characterize the anesthetic effects of a novel intravenous sedative-hypnotic agent, determine how it prevents forebrain mitochondria from generating an adequate mitochondrial membrane potential, and identify a new pharmacologically relevant anesthetic target. Success will provide insight into mechanisms of anesthesia and will permit us to develop the safest and most effective sedative-hypnotics in future work.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is one of the most common inherited cardiovascular diseases and increases risk for major adverse cardiovascular outcomes; however, only 13% of patients are appropriately diagnosed, indicating a significant diagnostic and therapeutic gap. To address this, the proposed research will use machine learning applied to electronic health record data to develop generalizable models to identify patients with undiagnosed hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and clinically relevant predictors of underdiagnosis. This will inform the dissemination and implementation of best practice approaches to accurately diagnose and appropriately treat patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) is a precancerous condition affecting ~3.5 million Americans. Other than active surveillance, there is no treatment to prevent MGUS from progressing into cancers, the vast majority of which are incurable. The proposed CAP-MGUS Center will be one of the few in the nation to facilitate the development of innovative agents against high-value targets in MGUS patients and thereby establish a foundational infrastructure to fast-track precision medicines for cancer prevention and interception.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Three-dimensional RNA structures contribute to the most fundamental cellular activities and represent attractive targets for small molecule drugs, especially for diseases associated with “undruggable” proteins. The traditional methods for structure determination of RNA, X-ray crystallography and NMR spectroscopy, require laborious RNA preparation and structure determination experimentation while more facile single-particle cryo- EM cannot be applied to most RNAs because of their small size. We propose to develop a novel methodology for RNA structure determination that includes a conceptually different biochemical approach for streamlined preparation of RNA samples and circumvents the restrictions of conventional cryo-EM structure determination.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A lack of diversity in the biomedical workforce is recognized to be an enduring problem, even though diversity significantly contributes to the health of our nation through greater research discoveries. This project will investigate whether individualized professional coaching as an intervention increases the success of URG biomedical Ph.D. students, and their transition into sustained, productive careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Aging impairs antiviral T-cell immunity and increases the severity of infectious diseases caused by viral infection. Using a mouse coronavirus infection model, this study will define the molecular mechanisms underlying the age- associated decline in the antiviral T-cell immunity. The results from this study will provide important implications for future development of strategies to improve antiviral T-cell immunity in the elderly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Family members and friends are the core of the uncoordinated system of care that tenuously maintains persons living with dementia in their community settings and delays their placement into more costly settings of institutional care, providing more contributed and out of pocket care support than Medicare and Medicaid combined. The CAN-DO program fills a significant gap in caregiver psychoeducation programing by focusing not principally on day-to-day care management but on the many substantial system navigation tasks that caregivers assume. Supported by preliminary efficacy data, CAN-DO will employ state-of-the art asynchronous interactive learning methods to enhance caregivers’ mastery of skills and confidence to navigate healthcare and other (legal, financial, social service, and family) systems that are crucial to the continued community living of persons affected with dementia illnesses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most common primary brain tumor in adults, is essentially incurable, and is associated with significant morbidity. In this project, we will develop a novel class of targeted cytotoxic therapies using DNA aptamers (single-stranded folded DNA molecules) conjugated to potent cellular toxins. The goals of this project are to identify individual aptamer-drug conjugates for treatment of GBM and to provide a roadmap for how these aptamer-drug conjugates could be easily identified for essentially any cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: OVERALL NARRATIVE: Pathogens continue to emerge, spread from host-to-host, evolve and cause a wide range of diseases that have major impacts on human and animal health. This is a global problem and the mission of the University of Pittsburgh Regional Biocontainment Laboratory is to study these emerging infectious diseases and to accelerate the development of novel interventions and medical countermeasures to prevent them, in a safe and secure environment. Our vision is to be a globally recognized, highly-collaborative, creative and forward-facing team of infection biologists who are poised to respond to emerging biological threats both at the national and international level.

PHR: Project Narrative The overarching mission of the University of Tennessee Health Science Center Regional Biocontainment Laboratory (RBL) is to provide leadership and support in the discovery and development of new drugs, vaccines and diagnostics that would protect the general population from emerging and reemerging infectious diseases and bioterrorism. This proposed application will contribute to this mission by enhancement of resilience of the RBL facilities, BSL-3 practices, and drug discovery capabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lp(a) is a pro-thrombotic risk factor, but it is not known if aspirin modified Lp(a)-mediated risk in the primary prevention setting in individuals without prior cardiovascular disease. This grant will assess whether aspirin reduces the risk of cardiovascular events mediated by elevated levels of Lp(a). Findings from this grant will provide clinicians with information to decide whether to prescribe aspirin in subjects with elevated Lp(a).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Humans and other animals use eye, head, and whole-body movements to command where they are looking and what they are paying attention to, and despite the visual consequences of these movements, perception remains stable. The goal of this proposal is to advance our understanding of the visual and premotor mechanisms which facilitate the continuity of visual perception across saccades. This research has implications for the diagnosis, treatment, and rehabilitation of patients with saccadic eye movement disorders and other human neurological syndromes which disrupt eye movements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project aims to biochemically characterize the role of the ubiquitous mitochondrial protein unfoldase CLPX in erythroid heme synthesis. Completion of this project will fundamentally enhance our understanding of the mechanisms underlying diseases caused by defects in heme synthesis, such as anemias, porphyrias and mitochondriopathies, and how tissue-specific factors regulate and modify ubiquitous metabolic pathways. Because a disproportionate number of anemic patients are women and children, the success of this project will have particular impact on the management of their health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative/ Public Health Relevance Emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases present unique challenges in the research mission of the NIH/NIAID because pathogen evolution cannot be predicted, and development of medical countermeasures that protect public health is reliant upon well characterized animal models that recapitulate the natural human infection. As these studies demand specialized personnel and building infrastructure, the NIH/NIAID Regional Biocontainment Laboratories were constructed to better address these challenges and prepare for unexpected outbreaks by unknown microbial threats. The proposed program will provide safety, security, and operational support to researchers at the University of Missouri Regional Biocontainment Laboratory in order to address priority pathogens and develop new approaches to prevent and treat infections, thereby improving our preparation for responding to an outbreak of emerging infectious disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The BSL3 facilities within the Rocky Mountain Regional Biocontainment Laboratory (RMRBL) at Colorado State University have been responsive to the national RBL mission since 2008, including research and training directed in response to the COVID and MPox pandemics, as well as research and training in other diseases, like Tuberculosis. The RMRBL BSL3 suites are in high demand, and require dedicated management, facilities maintenance, operational support, education and engagement in biosafety and biosecurity practices, and upkeep of relevant scientific technologies to support the studies being performed within this specialized facility. In this application, we address the needs of the RMRBL BSL3 laboratories with 3 Cores to ensure that these facilities are always resourced to face and combat pathogenic pandemic threats; Core 1 is dedicated to improved management, maintenance, and operations, while Core 2 is dedicated to biosafety and biosecurity practices, and finally Core 3 exploits our collective research talents to develop a biocontainment research resource core for pathogen characterization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE (OVERALL): The University of Louisville Regional Biocontainment Laboratory (RBL) is a regional resource that facilitates translational research to develop diagnostics, therapeutics and vaccines to mitigate biodefense and emerging infectious disease threats. We propose to establish three cores that will work in unison to achieve the RBL mission to prepare and respond to public health emergencies like pandemics. The cores will be responsible for facility management and operations; for training laboratory workers in safe BSL-3 work practices; and for operating a full-service research support function for scientists who need to use the RBL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (OVERALL) The goal of the BSL3 management and practice of infectious disease research at HTRL is to provide infrastructures and trained personnel to enable rapid responses and research on Risk Group 3 infectious disease threats, including new and re-emerging agents, Select Agent pathogens, or biological toxins, and to share this knowledge with the scientific community and public in a timely manner. HTRL, Howard Taylor Ricketts Laboratory, is one of twelve NIAID-designated Regional Biocontainment Laboratories (RBL). HTRL will operate within the RBL network with the goals of providing harmonized Standard Operating Protocols for cohesive best practices in BSL3/ABSL3 laboratories across our country.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERALL COMPONENT George Mason University’s Regional Biocontainment Lab serves as a center for scientific collaboration to 1) generate advanced knowledge of pathogen biology and host interaction mechanisms, and 2) evaluate diagnostics, therapeutics and vaccines. This proposal addresses existing gaps and opportunities with solutions to enhance a) safety practices, b) facilities and operations management, and c) research capabilities to more effectively face sudden disease outbreaks and support a more robust pipeline of innovations for response to future pandemics, while continuing to comply with NIAID, CDC, and UDSA/APHIS regulations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative During cardiac ischemia, succinate accumulation and adenine nucleotide depletion result in myocardial damage during reperfusion. Little is known about the mechanisms behind these metabolic changes that play major roles in ischemia-reperfusion injury. The goal of this project is to uncover the primary pathways of succinate accumulation and adenine nucleotide depletion in ischemic myocardium using experimental strategies in conjunction with computational models of myocardial metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health as knee osteoarthritis is a leading cause of chronic pain and disability in older adults, and strategies are needed to reduce pain and improve physical function for individuals with this condition. The proposed research is relevant to the mission of NIA in that it focuses on a common health condition in the aging population and seeks to understand the clinical, behavioral, physiologic, and genetic mechanisms by which non-specific therapeutic effects impact health outcomes in this population. This line of research will improve outcomes in knee OA, and eventually other chronic and painful conditions, by developing and testing strategies to modify clinical care delivery to maximize non-specific effects associated with patient-clinician interactions and enhancing efforts to understand the role of non-specific effects in health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is one of the most prevalent inherited cardiac diseases, with its own unique phenotype and etiology, yet treatments for DCM are largely palliative and derived from other cardiac diseases. Although pharmacologic and mechanical treatments have been able to partially reverse the DCM phenotype, these results are often temporary, and growing evidence suggests that aberrant chromatin and matrix signals persist despite apparent healing from the whole organ level. This proposal aims to better define the time- dependent nature of DCM progression and reversibility by examining permanent epigenetic, structural, and functional changes in the myocardium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with wild-type IDH glioblastoma (GBM) have a median age of onset at 68-70 years of age and represent >70% of all GBM diagnoses. Moreover, advanced age is a strong prognostic factor for predicting worse overall GBM patient survival. However, it's not understood as to why older age groups with GBM have a substantially worse survival outcome as compared to younger adults with GBM. This project aims to mechanistically understand how progressive aging negatively affects the survival outcomes in older adults with GBM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The current proposal outlines a strategic plan to safely and effectively boost research productivity and innovative ground-breaking scientific discoveries in the UAB Southeastern Biocontainment Laboratory (SEBLAB). Upon completion, this project will achieve the following: 1) Support SEBLAB facility operational expenses; 2) Fund the leadership, administrative, and technical staff required to operate this high complexity facility, 3) Replace existing basic scientific equipment, 4) Support high quality BSL-3 biosafety training, 5) Establish integrated research cores within high containment, 6) Optimize and boost SEBLAB scientific research productivity, 7) Foster RBL/NBL network collaboration, and 8) Fund and maintain a highly skilled BSL-3 scientific workforce ready to rapidly respond at the frontline of emerging pandemic threats.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - OVERALL The New England Regional Biosafety Laboratory (NERBL) seeks to develop and maintain RBL containment staffing that is proficient in core competencies to support building, laboratory and vivarium operations, with embedded cross-training to ensure functional redundancies that sustain facility functions. Additionally, we will expand capacities and expertise in key infectious diseases including Mycobacterium tuberculosis and influenza. Achieving these milestones will ensure that the NERBL is sufficiently prepared to respond to pandemic and emerging disease threats as they arise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: The primary objective of the proposed project is to develop a saliva-based biosensor by integrating research advances in sensing elements, machine learning, data analysis, microfluidics and communications for periodontal disease prediction which has high public health relevance. We will establish predictive models for periodontitis based on data from both sensor and patient. The new device will be useful for saliva-based self-monitoring for periodontitis and other oral or systemic diseases to improve the patient's overall health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current therapies for sickle cell disease largely fail to meet patient needs, particularly for the management of acute pain crisis associated with this devastating disease. Healthcare systems are largely ill-equipped for managing patients in the midst of these extremely painful and life-threatening events, leaving patients with medical distrust and no effective treatment option. We are therefore developing IHP-100, a novel P-selectin and complement inhibitor, for at-home self-management of pain crisis, which would represent a major paradigm shift in SCD treatment that empowers patients and provide significant freedom from disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE Acetylcholine is a neurotransmitter that plays critical roles in normal hearing and helps the brain adapt during development, learning and aging and after damage to the nervous system. Understanding these functions is critical for developing approaches to help people with age-related hearing loss, difficulty understanding speech in noisy environments, learning to hear with cochlear implants or coping with hearing dysfunctions in disorders such as autism or schizophrenia. The present proposal will answer critical questions about the circuitry that underlies cholinergic function in the brainstem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative: Peri-implant (PI) diseases, mucositis and peri-implantitis, are triggered by dysbiosis of the oral microbiome, resulting in destructive host inflammatory immune response. Current PI disease treatment protocols are unpredictable and PI disease reoccurs in 42-58% of implants 5 years post treatment. Thus, in this study a multifunctional ionic liquid based dental implant coating technology will be further developed as a clinical treatment modality to target dysbiosis and immune imbalance during the onset of PI diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Age-related hearing loss (ARHL), often called presbycusis, is the most common neurosensory deficit in our aging population, but no FDA-approved drugs or therapeutic armamentarium for sensorineural hearing loss (HL) are available. The overall goals of the Administrative Core are to provide administrative services to all Projects and Cores to ensure programmatic, effective, efficient, and collaborative interactions of the investigative team.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The programmatic research program is proposing innovative mechanistic studies and will take advantage of genetically modified animal models to unravel significant fundamental and translational mechanisms underlying age-related hearing loss (ARHL). The Animal Core (Core B) will provide services for the generation, management, and distribution of aged and gene-targeted mouse models for all three projects, Core C and D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: The purpose of Core C is to support the study of age-related hearing loss (ARHL) through a centralized resource of three-dimensional microscopy. The loss or structural remodeling of specific neurons and their components during aging will be identified in neuronal microcircuits from the inner ear to the brain's auditory centers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Age-related hearing loss (ARHL) is a complex degenerative disease characterized by hearing impairment. The overall goal in this project (P3) is to understand the age-dependent structural and molecular remodeling of central auditory synapses and central nerve axonal fibers, to provide novel insights into how aging influences structural plasticity throughout the auditory system and how connectivity with downstream brain areas are altered in aging.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with cancer and heart failure, which are the leading causes of death in the US, accounting for 40% of deaths annually, experience significant suffering. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Type 1 diabetes (T1D) starts with attack on pancreatic beta cells that produce insulin, but the events that initiate this attack remain unclear. Extracellular vesicles (EVs) play a role to signal between the pancreas and immune system, raising the possibility that they participate in T1D. Here, we will use human tissue to identify EVs from pancreatic beta-cells, their RNA content and how they signal to immune cells, yielding novel insights into the biology of T1D and identifying new blood markers to detect T1D at its earliest stage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE This renewal of R25 AG043365-10 (responsive to PAR-20-317) for NIA’s “Advancing Diversity in Aging Research through Undergraduate Education (ADAR)” program, now re-entitled: “Frontiers in Alzheimer’s and Aging Research EXPERIENCES” (FrA2RE), requests support for five cohorts of ≥12 promising undergraduates annually who “…are eligible…if they are from economically, socially, culturally, or educationally disadvantaged backgrounds’. FrA2RE concentrates on Structured Research Experiences by matching under-represented minority Trainees with Expert Mentors, creating a Dyad investigating Alzheimer’s disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) and Aging along with essential mentoring to launch and sustain careers within NIA’s portfolio, and is well justified since while the ADRD and aging fields continue to grow swiftly, and there are still too few laboratories led by URM scientists and too few new URM trainees. In so doing, FrA2RE innovatively enhances and expands the biomedical research careers of the most promising scientists, while ensuring their investigations comply with NIH’s policy of ‘Inclusion of Women, Minorities, and Individuals Across the Lifespan,’ particularly NIA’s focus on improving the diagnoses, health, and well-being, among the elderly and those suffering from Alzheimer’s Dementia and Related Disorders and their caregivers, and biological, clinical, behavioral, social aspects of aging, as well as helping to rectify inequities and increasing diversity.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This Pathway to Independence award seeks to train the applicant to establish an independent program of research that examines how stress impacts neurocognitive development and how changes in neurocognitive develop may confer risk for later socioemotional and neurocognitive functioning in a multicultural framework. The proposed research investigates how maternal and child stress alters brain activity across infancy and early childhood and how such alterations predict neurocognitive and socioemotional functioning. Elucidating the direct influence of chronic physiological stress on alterations in brain development and the functional significance of such alterations provides important insights for early identification and intervention of future long-term cognitive and socioemotional outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Rehabilitative care can play a major role in preventative care for older adults, targeting the prevention of functional decline and disability. This is known as prehabilitative care and the applicant is one of the few experts in this important area of patient-oriented research. This proposal is renewing support for him to serve as a mentor for trainees from diverse backgrounds wishing to advance their careers through a focus on geriatric rehabilitation research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Belone, Lorenda Project Narrative This study will strengthen dissemination and implementation (D&I) science by testing the implementation of our indigenous focused Family Listening Program (FLP), which is a culturally transformed intervention through the application of a community-based participatory research (CBPR) approach. In this new study we introduce an innovative process called CBPR Culture-Centered System which will be integrated with the Interactive Systems Framework (D&I structures and functions to bridge science & practice) for an examination of the uptake, cultural acceptance, and sustainability of evidence-based strategies moved into practice with three new southwest tribal communities. This grant will continue its long-term CBPR partnership with three southwest tribal partners which will provide a solid foundation for collaborating on the synthesis and translation of the following tools that will facilitate three new southwest tribal partners to adapt their own FLP curriculum and evaluation measures into their own distinct cultural knowledge, histories, values, and practices for implementation: a) Quality Implementation Tool; b) CAB Development Guide; c) Culture- Centered Coaching Guide; d) Digital Story Modules; and e) Culture-Centered FLP Toolkit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative These experiments will provide insight into processes that contribute to cognitive decline with aging and Alzheimer’s disease. I will look at how neurons and their circuits change with age and try to determine which features are harmful and which features are coincidental. These data will help understand what form of the protein tau, a pathological hallmark of Alzheimer’s disease, should be targeted by clinical trials to treat cognitive decline in Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Engineered T cell therapies for cancer have demonstrated remarkable clinical responses in some patients, but many fail to respond due to poor T cell function. Current approaches to enhance T cell function and/or mitigate dysfunction are limited in their effectiveness and durability, and therefore new approaches are needed to help engineered T cells stay in the fight against cancer. This project will develop a novel approach to fundamentally reprogram T cells with enhanced tumor killing function, thereby paving the way for more efficacious cancer therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  While T cells provide powerful protection against viral infections and tumors, many cancers evade immune surveillance, and T cell destruction of self-tissues can lead to severe autoimmune diseases. Methods to control T cell reactivity remain scarce. This project will develop small molecules that fine-tune the recognition of antigens by T cells as a new therapeutic approach for the treatment of cancer and autoimmune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR HIV, VIRAL HEPATITIS, STD AND TB PREVENTION
PHR: Narrative Hispanic/Latino gay, bisexual, and other men who have sex with men (HLMSM) are disproportionately affected by HIV, and medical mistrust is associated with these HIV disparities because mistrust may result in delayed or reduced use of needed HIV prevention and care services. Our community-academic partnership proposes a rigorous mixed-methods, community-based participatory research (CBPR) study to better understand the drivers of medical mistrust among Spanish-speaking, English-speaking, and bilingual HLMSM. We also propose to refine and test a multilevel intervention designed to address medical mistrust and increase the use of needed HIV prevention and care services among diverse HLMSM in Mecklenburg County, NC, one of the jurisdictions prioritized by the Ending the HIV Epidemic in the US initiative.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Exploring and Intervening on Multilevel Factors of Medical Mistrust among Hispanic/Latino Gay, Bisexual and Other Men Who Have Sex with Men (HLMSM) for HIV Prevention in a Priority Jurisdiction

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuroinflammation is a major modifier of disease progression in neurodegenerative disease, yet we lack critical insight into its molecular origins. Recently, we unexpectedly discovered that the pathological proteins found in these conditions mimic the behavior of innate immune signals. Here, we propose to uncover the biophysical and molecular rules that dictate this mimicry to help us better understand the etiology of neuroinflammation in disease and aid us in devising new ways for therapeutic intervention.
