IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Infants represent one of the most vulnerable members of society and considerable resources are devoted to their healthy development, but we know surprisingly little about how their brains process social information from primary caregivers. This project is aimed at understanding the sensory encoding of maternal cues in the infant brain and its contribution to adult social behavior. This is relevant to the mission of the NIH due to its potential to reveal mechanisms underlying sensory neuron dysfunction underlying neurodevelopental disorders and sex biases in their manifestation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: While electrical current is the basis of biological signal transduction and fundamental to all life on this planet, the structural conformation of biological components under electrical stimulus remains elusive. This proposal will establish a novel technique, electrified cryo-EM, that will enable the first nanoscale studies of dynamic neuron activity during an action potential stimulated by an external electrical impulse. Insights from this program will have significant impact on informing next-generation neurostimulation treatments for neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– Whereas scientists can now readily measure the DNA, RNA, and protein content within any biological sample, measuring the small molecules in that same sample has remained more challenging. This project aims to develop a suite of machine-learning tools that will allow us to more comprehensively measure both known and unknown small molecules in any biological sample by analyzing mass spectrometry data. The possibility of identifying unknown small molecules in high-throughput would increase the scope and efficiency of many publicly funded studies and open up new perspectives on the chemical world around us.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Prevention of depressive disorders has become a key priority for the NIMH, but we have no widely available public health strategy to reduce morbidity and mortality. To address this need, we developed and evaluated the primary care based-technology “behavioral vaccine,” Competent Adulthood Transition with Cognitive-Behavioral Humanistic and Interpersonal Therapy (CATCH- IT). We will engage N=4 health systems representative of the United States health care system, and conduct a factorial design study to optimize the intervention in preparation for an implementation study and eventual dissemination.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: As cells differentiate, they activate signaling cascades that are precisely controlled in time to achieve the fully committed phenotype. Our findings will advance our understanding of the human brain and accelerate new therapies for brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Nucleic acids, such as DNA and RNA, exist in cells as highly complex molecular structures subject to numerous modifications and vulnerable to damage, either of which can change their function and impact cellular states; however current sequencing technology can only analyze their base sequence, ignoring much of this information. Here, I present preliminary data and propose a path to expand a technique developed by my lab to directly sequence modified or damaged DNA or RNA, using an innovative approach to modify novel sequencing technology. With these tools, we hope to understand the processes that converge on DNA and RNA, such as chemotherapy in cancer or natural damage that occurs during aging or neurodegeneration, to better learn how cells modify, repair, and interpret their genomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Extracellular vesicles (EVs) are shed into the bloodstream by all cells in the body, providing a unique opportunity to monitor the health impact of environmental exposures through liquid biopsies. Here we propose a technology framework integrating bulk and single EV omics, nanotechnologies, and microtechnologies to extract the blood fingerprints of organ-specific biological responses to life course experiences. The proposed methodologies, technologies, as well as data sets, will be of high value to both basic and translational research communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunotherapies have revolutionized the treatment of cancer, but only a small fraction of patients benefit from these therapies. In my recent work, I pioneered a new class of chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells, peptide- centric (PC)-CARs, paving the way for a clinical trial slated to open in 2024 and offering a roadmap for developing immunotherapies for the lethal cancers that don't benefit from first-generation CAR T cells. Here I introduce a multi-pronged approach to build on these methods, offering innovative new strategies for developing safer and more effective therapeutic strategies that can to lead to new therapies for the most challenging cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE FOR FUNDED GRANT (MOSAIC K99/R00) The androgen receptor is a type I nuclear hormone receptor and master transcription factor responsible for differentiation and development of the male phenotype. Its hyperactivation is associated with multiple diseases, including metastatic prostate cancer, androgenetic alopecia, androgen insensitivity syndrome, and Kennedy’s disease. This proposal seeks to understand the mechanism of androgen receptor regulation and determinants of its aberrant activity using biochemical, structural, and cellular methods, which can facilitate the development of novel androgen receptor inhibitors and lend mechanistic insight towards other related nuclear hormone receptors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Capitalizing on recent technological strides and the amassed big data, we can now envision in silico models of mammalian organogenesis at the embryo level, offering profound predictive insights into human development and relevant diseases. This proposal seeks to pioneer such a venture by constructing the first-ever foundational in silico model of mouse embryogenesis, using Ultima's revolutionary cost-effective “mostly natural sequencing- by-synthesis” chemistry and ultra-high field of view (300, 000 mm2) spatially barcoded wafer disc platform for 3D single-cell spatial multi-omics across E6.5 to E16.5, coupled with cutting-edge machine learning methods like Fourier neural operator learning, graph neural network and the Generative Pre-trained Transformer (as employed in ChatGPT). This proposal will thus set the stage for groundbreaking predictions, including discerning the regulatory mechanisms behind, e.g., the heart's chamber formation and congenital heart disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Developing a CRISPR-free mammalian recombineering system Project Narrative The ability to manipulate large segments of DNA in mammalian cells is essential for research and therapeutics, but we lack genome editing techniques capable of making kilobase-scale DNA changes without cytotoxic double-strand breaks. In this proposal, I describe the development and use of a mammalian recombineering platform, a CRISPR-free genome editing system that enables large DNA insertions, deletions, and substitutions on the human genome without the introduction of double-strand breaks or DNA scars. Our compact recombineering machinery can enable “all-in-one” single-AAV correction of multi-allelic diseases, thus impacting fields from basic research to therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The emergence of artemisinin-resistant Plasmodium falciparum (Pf) parasites imperils global malaria treatment and control. Quiescence plays a central role in artemisinin-resistant parasite survival, as well as in the parasite starvation response, but drivers of entry into and exit from this cellular state remain unknown. The proposed research will employ transcriptomics, mass spectrometry and genetic knockdowns to identify and characterize novel epigenetic mechanisms that regulate drug-resistant parasite entry into and exit from quiescence, thereby fundamentally altering how we understand parasite gene regulation and allowing for the development of novel antimalarials to combat one of the deadliest global diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Parkinson’s disease is a devastating neurodegenerative disorder for which there is currently no cure. Extensive evidence suggests that the disease may originate in the gastrointestinal tract; however, there is an urgent need for animal models that allow for rapid, large-scale testing to uncover novel gut-to-brain mechanisms of disease. In the proposed study, we will generate a suite of new gut-to-brain disease models using the small nematode worm, C. elegans, and with a combination of high-throughput screening and single cell RNA-sequencing analyses, we will provide the most comprehensive investigation to date of the mechanisms underlying neurotoxic disease spread from the gut, with our results bearing significant implications for early therapeutic interventions in Parkinson’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer metastasis accounts for more than 8 million deaths worldwide annually, however, our understanding of the mechanisms underlying metastasis remains incomplete. This proposal aims to develop a comprehensive, spatiotemporally-resolved roadmap of small cell lung cancer metastasis by developing and applying new technologies that integrate single-cell lineage tracing, spatial transcriptomics, and transcriptional recording. A comprehensive understanding of these mechanisms will reveal key molecular changes underlying each step of metastatic progression, and could potentially inform rational therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Mozambique (a country in Africa with the fourth highest HIV prevalence globally) has made good progress in HIV pandemic control, but significant gaps remain. Leveraging proven leadership and expertise as Mozambique’s lead HIV Strategic Information partner and a history of highly successful partnerships between the University of Eduardo Mondlane (UEM) and Vanderbilt University Medical Center (VUMC), the Vanderbilt- Mozambique Biomedical Informatics (VM-BMI) Training and Research program will increase biomedical informatics (BMI) capacity for HIV research at UEM. Over the course of the five-year project, VM-BMI will train 6 UEM faculty fellows, 10 master’s-level UEM students, and 200 Mozambican workshop and bootcamp participants with an eye towards long-term sustainability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project narrative Fluorescence imaging is a crucial tool for monitoring biomolecular processes at high spatial resolutions and in real time but has limited utility for deep tissue imaging because the few available fluorophores in the NIR-II tissue transparency window (1,000 to 1,700 nm) suffer from challenges such as low brightness, large size, and toxicity. This proposed work pioneers a new approach to develop small, bright, tunable, and biocompatible NIR-II emitters for targeted in vivo molecular imaging, by exploiting a new class of NIR-emissive DNA-stabilized silver nanoclusters. We envision that these new NIR-II fluorescent probes will transform the field of deep tissue fluorescence imaging, with applications ranging from cancer research to vascular imaging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging is driven by accumulated damage in cells over time that disrupts normal tissue function. Often, this process is exacerbated by repeated injuries that stimulate proliferation and wound-induced inflammation. This proposal leverages a highly aging-resistant organism that reproduces solely through asexual reproduction and whole-body regeneration to uncover the cellular and molecular basis for whole-organism rejuvenation and anti-aging.

This will provide previously inaccessible insight into the molecular mechanisms of cellular processes in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR IMMUNIZATION AND RESPIRATORY DISEASES
PHR: COMPONENT A – PROJECT NARRATIVE: The planned research is relevant to public health because accurately estimating influenza and COVID-19 vaccine effectiveness (VE) to prevent mild to moderate illness treated in ambulatory settings is a critical component in evaluating the protection provided by nationwide vaccination programs and for the CDC Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) to modify recommendations regarding use of vaccines and antiviral medications as needed. Our Component A project, “Credible Effectiveness Measures of Seasonal Influenza, COVID-19, and Other Respiratory Virus Vaccines against Ambulatory Care for Acute Illness in Texas”, will assess VE against laboratory-confirmed infection with vaccine-preventable respiratory viruses (seasonal/pandemic influenza, COVID-19, and other respiratory viruses such as Respiratory Syncytial Virus for which vaccines may become available) among children and adults needing ambulatory care for acute illness, monitor ongoing viral evolution of influenza and SARS-CoV-2 viruses through genomic sequencing, and conduct potentially year-round surveillance of COVID-19 for respective VE and incidence estimation. This research will generate new knowledge towards the long-term goal of advancing understanding of the epidemiology of viral respiratory infections while measuring the public health impact of immunization of children and adults on reducing the overall burden of illness and improving the health of the population.

PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-IP-22-004, Component A _ Credible Effectiveness Measures of Seasonal Influenza, COVID-19 and Other Respiratory Virus Vaccines against Ambulatory Care for Acute Illness in Texas (and Component D).

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite being a large segment of the population, rural, minority, and underserved children are traditionally underrepresented in clinical trials, often due to decreased access. Failure to represent these children in pediatric studies overlooks the needs of an important segment of the population, limits the scientific evidence base, and leads to unequal distribution of the opportunity to benefit from medicine and research. Our program, IMproving Pediatric Access to Clinical Trials in Vermont (IMPACT VT) will continue to collaborate as an ECHO IDeA States Pediatric Clinical Trials Network Site to improve clinical trials access, develop and implement clinical trials pertinent to our populations, train a pipeline of pediatric investigators committed to clinical trials research for rural and underserved children, and in the long-term decrease disparities with the goal of improving health for all children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE OVERALL Recovery from viral pneumonia is a clinically important yet understudied process. Despite advances in supportive care and treatment with anti-viral medications, viral pneumonia-induced ARDS carries a mortality rate approaching 40%. By linking causal mechanistic studies in cell and murine models with bronchoalveolar samples from patients with severe viral pneumonia, this PPG seeks to identify mechanisms that promote the successful transition from the initial deleterious phases of acute lung injury to the later phases of resolution and lung repair in the virus-injured lung.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The studies proposed in this application will examine the role of myosteatosis as a determinant of cardiometabolic syndrome (CMS) in obesity. Using a mouse model of obesity individually crossed with models of Galectin 3 (GAL3), NADPH Oxidase 1 (NOX1), and stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1) deletion, we will test the hypothesis that obesity-driven ectopic fat accumulation in SKM drives vascular dysfunction and impaired angiogenesis in a GAL-3 and NOX1 dependent manner and is the underlying cause of CMS, which is ameliorated by the reversal of myosteatosis, improving cardiovascular health by restoring insulin sensitivity. This proposal seeks to explore a novel and poorly understood risk factor in metabolic syndrome and will, through the targeting of the GAL3, NOX1, and SCD1 genes, shed new insight into the mechanisms by which skeletal muscle is protective of vascular health, as well as provide potential therapeutic targets for the treatment of cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PAR-19-363, Integration of Imaging and Fluid-Based Tumor Monitoring in Cancer Therapy (R01 Clinical Trial Optional) Project Narrative: Assessing response to therapy in patients with bone-only (BO) or bone- dominant (BD) metastatic breast cancer (MBC) is hampered by absence of easily measurable disease by standard imaging criteria and by lack of effective blood biomarkers (i.e., tumor markers). This proposal will integrate fluid-based tumor monitoring (by serial collection of circulating tumor DNA, ctDNA) and FDG-PET/CT imaging to determine if these biomarkers, separately or combined, can predict a response to therapy for in patients with BO or BD MBC in the context of a multi-center, prospective clinical trial, EA1183 (FEATURE).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inhibitory control is an essential brain function that is disrupted in people with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Despite significant progress in illuminating mechanisms and key neural substrates underlying inhibitory control, physiological distinctions between processes related to termination of movement and the cognitive control processes that initiate inhibition are still unclear. This project will address this gap in knowledge by disentangling cortical signatures of the cognitive and motoric aspects of inhibitory control, which will ultimately pave the way for objective diagnostic tools and targeted treatments for ADHD.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The ability to develop a high resolution non-invasive prenatal screen (hrNIPS) that comprehensively surveys all coding variation for pathogenic variants would decrease morbidity associated with invasive testing and has the potential to transform maternal fetal medicine. The optimization and implementation of methods to call the spectrum of variation (SNV, indel, CNV) with hrNIPS and integration of systematic phenotyping will bring this approach closer to clinical use, contribute to the repertoire of variation associated with anomalies in pregnancy, and develop an infrastructure that can be applied to other projects.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The VA’s Maintaining Internal Systems and Strengthening Integrated Outside Networks (MISSION) Act of 2018 greatly expanded opportunities for Veterans to be referred outside of the VA for complex cardiac procedures. However the VA is a national leader in quality of care for advanced cardiac procedures, thus increased referrals outside of the VA may lower the quality of cardiac care, worsen clinical outcomes, and increase VA’s costs for Veterans receiving cardiac procedures. Our multi-disciplinary research team will use VA’s extensive national data resources on cardiovascular procedural care to examine the MISSION Act’s effect on health care access, quality, outcomes, and costs among Veterans receiving major cardiac procedures. The project’s overarching goals are to inform Veterans’ decisions regarding where they receive advanced cardiac care, improve care coordination, optimize clinical outcomes, and reduce costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Centrosome aberrations disrupt mitosis and lead to genome instability: a hallmark of cancer. This study aims to understand how Orb2, a conserved RNA-binding protein implicated in RNA localization and translational regulation, regulates neural stem cell centrosome dynamics and mitotic spindle organization required for mitotic fidelity. Successful completion of this study will illuminate drivers of disease progression and liabilities opportune for intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Tendon hierarchical structure dictates its ability to effectively transmit loads from muscle to bone and formation of tendon during tendon development and healing is reliant on coordination of multiscale regulatory governing processes such as formation of fibrils from collagen molecules, assembly of fibril bundles to form fibers, and recruitment of fibers to form fascicles. The objective of this proposal is to establish the mechanisms involving collagen XII regulation of tendon hierarchical structure, mechanical function and composition throughout postnatal development and healing. Utilizing our innovative mouse models, we will define tendon-specific regulatory mechanisms involving collagen XII to provide a fundamental understanding of the acquisition of tendon structure and function and its re-establishment during healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Racial discrimination has been identified as the primary social stressor for Black youth1 where 90% of Black youth (age 8-16) reportedly experienced at least one racial discriminatory encounter.2 The proposed study will utilize physiological data to assess the physical effects of in-the-moment racial coping paired with self-report of racial coping and mental health outcomes among Black adolescents. The proposed research will 1) provide a person-centered approach to understanding racial coping and its effects on depression, stress, and anxiety, as well as the moderating effects of cultural familial processes on racial coping, and 2) inform theory and efforts to promote positive youth development in the face of racial discrimination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Missense mutations directly cause or exacerbate human diseases by introducing changes to the amino acid sequence of a protein that disrupt its native biophysical properties. Attempts to predict these functional effects from sequence variation have leveraged recent advancements in sequence-based machine learning, but have suffered from a lack of large, biochemical datasets connecting sequence variance to descriptive measurements of in vitro effects. Here, I will develop a cutting-edge experimental strategy to make quantitative biophysical measurements for thousands of mutations in a major class of human proteins and establish a framework for leveraging this data to enhance sequence-based predictive models for variant effects prediction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative A protein traffic control system that regulates left-right patterning and heart development The development of the heart and its correct connection to major blood vessels depends on complex and poorly understood systems that control left-right asymmetry of our internal organs. By advancing the understanding of cell-cell communication mechanisms that establish the identity of the left and right sides of the heart, we hope to build the foundation for new diagnostic, preventative and therapeutic strategies for the ~7000 babies born in the United States each year with severe congenital heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sodium sensing in the brain is critical in mediating neurohormonal responses to acute hypernatremia. The goal of this proposal is to use BOLD fMRI to determine whether there are sex differences in central neural activation of sodium sensing brain regions and brain regions involved in regulating sympathetic outflow during acute hypernatremia elicited via hypertonic saline infusion. Identification of sex differences in brain activation could have important implications for understanding sex differences in fluid balance and blood pressure responses to sodium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Folate-mediated one-carbon metabolism regulates biological processes critical to hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) establishment and function, however how folate supplementation affects the developing hematopoietic system is unknown. We hypothesize that varying prenatal folate status will affects alter HSC function across adulthood by perturbing HSC metabolism during development. The objective of this grant is to identify the effect of varying prenatal folate status on HSC function and development across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The genetic architecture of X chromosome and X-chromosome inactivation (XCI) escape and their links to sex- biased phenotypes remains poorly understood, presumably due to unique analytic challenges. In this research we propose two methods that accurately model the unique biology of X chromosome to genetically identify relevant tissue/cell types and X-linked genes in which aberrant regulation of XCI plays a significant role in the etiology of complex diseases and traits. We will apply our methods to some of the largest datasets across various tissue/cell types and a variety of complex traits including lupus, diabetes, and addiction to not only improve functional genomics and disease association analysis of the X chromosome but also highlight the unappreciated role escape from XCI plays in shaping human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will harness innovative genomics approaches to identify causal gene variants and regulatory pathways involved in response to poly- and perfluoroalkyl substance (PFAS) exposure to reveal specific structure-activity signatures of toxicity. This knowledge will potentially advance risk assessment for the thousands of PFAS pollutants of unknown toxicity. The proposed research is relevant to the parts of the mission of National Institutes of Environmental Health Sciences to identify variation in sensitivity and response to exposures, advance predictive toxicology, and ultimately contribute to the reduction of negative health outcomes associated with environmental pollution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abnormalities in right ventricle (RV) development are associated with congenital heart disease (CHD), however lack of appropriate animal models has hindered studies of the molecular basis of RV development following chamber formation. Our analysis of mice with cardiomyocyte (CM)-specific knockout (cKO) of NEDD4 (Neural precursor cell expressed developmentally downregulated protein 4), a HECT E3 ubiquitin ligase, revealed a unique RV-specific phenotype. Proposed studies are aimed to elucidate the role of NEDD4 in RV development, as well as the impact of congenital RV defects on cardiac performance, by histological, physiological, biochemical, and molecular analyses of constitutive Nedd4 cKO mice, and to determine the critical window during which NEDD4 is required for RV development by analysis of tamoxifen-inducible Nedd4 knockout mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Advances in precision oncology have led to extended survival for patients with metastatic oncogene-driven non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), yet metastatic NSCLC remains incurable and patients live with uncertainty regarding their prognosis that leads to distress. This clinical research and career development proposal will support an early stage investigator to refine and pilot test a palliative care intervention that integrates elements of survivorship care for patients with metastatic oncogene-driven NSCLC. The intervention aims to decrease distress related to uncertainty, increase self-efficacy for management of chronic disease, improve prognostic understanding and increase communication about goals and values to inform future decision making among this novel population of cancer survivors living with incurable cancer.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE In stark contrast to the reduction in injury deaths among industrial nations, low and middle-income countries have experienced growing rates of injury, especially in sub-Saharan Africa. This proposal builds upon long- standing collaborations developed among the Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology (KNUST), other Ghanaian institutions involved with injury control, and the University of Washington, in order to (i) develop a cadre of trained injury research leaders, and (ii) engage junior researchers in innovative, mentored injury related health research to reduce the burden of injury and strengthen the practice of injury control; and (iii) build capacity for injury control in Ghanaian and other West African institutions. We will develop, expand and consolidate existing collaborative research and training networks by integrating researchers from Ghana, other West African nations, the UW and other institutions with a shared commitment to preventing and treating injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Natural products from bacteria, fungi, and plants have long been a rich source of therapeutically relevant molecules, but the relationship between natural product structure and activity is not fully understood, hindering our ability to further optimize natural products for therapeutic use. Machine learning can be used to develop models that explain trends in data and make predictions for new data points. In this work we will apply machine learning to understand structure-activity relationships in natural products, design biosynthetic gene clusters to improve our ability to biosynthesize natural product analogs, and repurpose natural products as protein- protein interaction inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to study the microfluidics devices that can exploit the biophysical responses of cells to ultrafast compressions. We aim to create new technologies for the delivery of large transgenes and probes to many cell types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Because Latino children are disproportionately affected by short sleep duration, poorly timed sleep, and obesity by the age of 3 years, it is critical to understand factors that may contribute to both sleep and obesity in this population. This study will advance our understanding of how environmental (e.g., household, neighborhood, societal), sociocultural (e.g., acculturation, beliefs), and parental (e.g., sleep-related parenting practices) factors contribute to toddler sleep and toddler weight status over a 2-year period in Mexican American families, one of the largest growing ethnic minority populations in the U.S. By identifying contextual factors and modifiable behaviors that must be considered for intervention design, this study will contribute to the development of family-focused, culturally-tailored, and contextually-informed early prevention programs focused on sleep and weight status in this underserved population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Systemic sclerosis-associated interstitial lung disease (SSc-ILD) is the leading cause of death in patients with systemic sclerosis, and a disease for which no therapies conclusively alter mortality or target the central pathogenic cells. The differentiation of resident pulmonary fibroblasts to aberrant myofibroblasts is a key process in the pathogenesis of SSc-ILD. This work will define the gene regulatory programs fundamental to SSc-ILD myofibroblast differentiation and the pathogenic myofibroblast phenotype and determine the mechanisms by which RUNX2/3 regulate critical myofibroblast effector functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The development of lung inflammation and fibrosis is a significant complication that limits the effectiveness of stem cell transplantation as a cure for cancer or autoimmune disease. This proposal seeks to understand how the process of stem cell transplant alters the natural bacterial communities in the lung, and how those altered microbial communities influence the development of immune responses that lead to inflammation and fibrosis. Successful completion of the work should identify bacterial-based therapeutic options to improve outcomes for patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune checkpoint inhibitors are drugs that have revolutionized the treatment of lung and bladder cancer as well as other cancer types. The goal of this project is to identify biomarkers that predict immune checkpoint inhibitor efficacy and/or side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current proposal seeks to uncover the population genetic determinants of dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), the leading global cause of heart transplantation. With growing availability of genetic data, an improved understanding of DCM genetics may permit genomic risk prognostication as part of routine clinical practice, enabling early identification and management of patients at risk for DCM, and thereby mitigating risk – and the potential need for heart transplantation – before the onset of disease. Furthermore, identification of putative drug targets through genetic discovery may motivate the development of novel therapeutics capable of altering the poor prognosis that is currently associated with DCM.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Veterans who access health care from multiple systems are at risk of experiencing fragmented care. Fragmented care can lead to feelings of mistrust, abandonment, and isolation. Fragmentation created by dual use of VA and non-VA services creates inefficiency, unnecessary care, and worse outcomes. The 2018 MISSION Act and Medicaid expansion under the ACA result in more health care options for Veterans, but also increased risk of fragmented care. We will assess choices Veterans made about their care after Medicaid expansion. We will focus on a group particularly vulnerable to fragmented care–patients with complex health care needs from advanced chronic kidney disease. As VA incorporates more non-VA sources of care under the MISSION Act, understanding trade-offs between increasing access and ensuring high quality, coordinated care will become a central question for VA. Understanding how Veterans choose to access care when given multiple options is key to making health system improvements in resource deployment and care coordination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Shigella species are a major global cause of morbidity and mortality, estimated to be responsible for 269 million cases and 212,000 deaths annually. There is no approved vaccine and only a poor understanding of natural or vaccine-elicited immunity, in large part because of the lack of a physiological mouse model of infection. In this application, we propose to take advantage of our development of a new oral infection mouse model of shigellosis to answer fundamental questions about Shigella pathogenesis and immune responses to this important global pathogen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This training grant application focused on lung biology and pathobiology requests continuing support for 7 predoctoral and 6 postdoctoral trainees. The Training Program is grounded in 5 inter-related thematic areas of research training: (1) Biology and Pathobiology of Lung Vasculature, (2) Regenerative Mechanisms in Lung and Vascular Biology, (3) Cellular and Humoral Bases of Lung Inflammation and Injury, (4) Cell Signaling Mechanisms in Lung Injury, and (5) Lung and Vascular Genomics. We are well positioned to continue to train a highly-qualitied group of young scientists, providing a range of skills needed in a rapidly-evolving and increasingly competitive scientific environment that can be applied in careers in both academic research and alternative pathways.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will leverage the Asian Bipolar Genetics Network (A-BIG-NET), an international collaboration of investigators from the U.S., Taiwan, South Korea, Singapore, India and Pakistan, to carry out a molecular genetics study of bipolar disorder in East and South Asia. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Since 2011, the Amazon has experienced the largest percent increase in malaria cases in the world, with the highest increase in burden occurring in Venezuela, Peru, Brazil, Colombia and Ecuador. Through support from NASA, our team developed a Malaria Early Warning System (MEWS) for Peru that accurately predicts malaria cases 8-12 weeks in advance using sophisticated statistical models and environmental drivers of malaria transmission (i.e., climate, land cover, hydrology). The objective of this proposal is to geographically expand our MEWS to all Amazonian regions and obtain additional data to improve downscaling and forecasting by mapping community networks and potential migration routes related to malaria transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This innovative new proposal is designed to supplement the education of postdoctoral trainees with MD, PhD, or equivalent degrees in the areas of pulmonary, allergy, or critical care medicine by supporting research in heart, lung, blood, and sleep related disorders. We built a research training curriculum to meet the special needs of these trainees and expose them to high standards of multidisciplinary medical research. Once they complete our highly adaptive program, trainees will have the knowledge and skills to pursue outstanding cutting-edge independent research careers that will give them the ability to rapidly translate scientific discoveries into better ways to diagnose and treat disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Organs-on-Chips are becoming an ever more popular tool to tackle the downsides of static cell cultures and animal models; while the standard models can demonstrate basic biological phenomenon, these models are inefficient for modeling disease and studying therapeutics in-vitro. While Organs-on-Chips are a better model, there is still a need to address their reliability and use in large scale studies. Here we propose improvements and experiments for a novel, organ-on-chip platform to recapitulate normal glomerular filtration, as well as glomerular hyperfiltration due to changes in hydrostatic pressure, osmotic pressure, and membrane stiffness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions):  Tick-borne Disease (TbD) in the US has tripled due to both vector range expansions and emergence of  novel tick-transmitted pathogens, leading to increased morbidity and mortality. A major limitation of the  current detection techniques is the extreme bias towards detecting single pathogens and lack of  consideration of coinfections. Our MEDICO platform will diagnose babesiosis, anaplasmosis, and acute,  early-stage Lyme disease that share the same tick vector, I. scapularis, and often coexist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is a leading cause of death and disease among Black American women and is associated with pregnancy complications and experiences of early and chronic stress. We will measure health and behavioral indicators of CVD risk in a sample of Black women who have participated in a 20-year longitudinal study to examine the effects of lifetime stress exposure and stress reactivity on profiles of CVD risk across the first two years postpartum. New data from this study will improve understanding of CVD risk specific to Black women, and will inform the targets and timing of interventions to reduce persistent racial disparities in maternal health.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE Disorders of the respiratory tract continue to be a major cause of morbidity and mortality, affecting tens of millions of people. This grant will prepare MD and PhD scientists with superior training in areas relevant to lung biology and lung disease and equip them to be leaders in their selected field of research.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Clinical trials provide the highest quality research evidence for the effectiveness of medical treatments, but most pediatric clinical trials fail to achieve enrollment and retention goals. The Nebraska Pediatric Clinical Trials Unit (NPCTU) addresses this gap in improving child health outcomes by extending research infrastructure and clinical trials participation opportunities to children, families, and health care providers in rural and underserved communities across Nebraska and neighboring IDeA states. The NPCTU will build upon its initial successes in enrolling children into clinical trials conducted in the IDeA States Pediatric Clinical Trials Network by expanding rural outreach, research infrastructure, and professional development programs through collaborations with multiple institutional partners across Nebraska and other IDeA states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biological processes are regulated through intricate signaling events that vary in time and 3D space (i.e., 4D). This project pioneers generalizable efforts to mimic, exploit, and quantify biology’s 4D complexity, paving the way to new therapeutic targets and treatments of disease through a fundamentally transformed knowledge of basic cell physiology. Critically, the methods being developed and implemented are cell-, tissue-, and disease- agnostic, enabling enhanced understanding of a wide variety of biological processes while laying the foundation for advances in disease diagnosis, treatment, and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will leverage the Asian Bipolar Genetics Network (A-BIG-NET), an international collaboration of investigators from the U.S., Taiwan, South Korea, Singapore, India and Pakistan, to carry out a molecular genetics study of bipolar disorder in East and South Asia. It will establish a valuable genetics resource with 4x low-pass whole genome sequence and rich phenotype data that will dramatically increase the worldwide diversity of genetics data on bipolar disorder, an important step to accelerate gene discovery in this disorder and advance global mental health equity.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project will first develop a novel smartphone application (app) providing cognitive based therapy via the Mothers and Babies Program (MB) curriculum and then assess the feasibility and acceptability of utilizing the app as a study intervention in a randomized feasibility trial. The study app will contain on-demand education on postpartum health, breastfeeding; and infant milestones as well as interactive MB-based modules; those randomized to the control group will not access any MB content. Data obtained in the proposed trial will be critical for the design of a subsequent R01-supported randomized controlled trial, which will be fully powered to determine the effect of app-based MB on rates of postpartum depression among low-income, racially and ethnically diverse women at high risk for developing these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic kidney disease (CKD), which affects 37 million Americans, progresses with the loss of important proteins such as Klotho, leading to severe endocrine disease, as well as increased renal oxidative stress that further damages the kidneys. In this career development proposal, I will enhance my computational skills to identify how the interactions of Klotho and its ligand fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23) protect against oxidative stress at the molecular level. These studies will provide the backdrop for key career development as well as help to identify new pathways regulated by Klotho and FGF23 that may slow CKD progression, and potentially uncover novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed program, “Research Training on HIV Prevention and Treatment in Children and Adolescents,” will build research capacity in Kenya for emerging health professionals with clinical backgrounds who wish to continue in clinical practice as well as build a research career in academic settings. The University of Nairobi (UoN) will collaborate with the University of Washington (UW), providing training to improve capacity in epidemiology and biostatistics, towards a goal of strengthening evidence-based approaches to prevent and treat pediatric and adolescent HIV and conduct locally relevant research in Kenya.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The VA Health Care System has done a magnificent, under-appreciated job in the COVID-19 pandemic. The US Veterans served by the health care system are enriched for older men with co-morbid conditions who are especially vulnerable for serious morbidity and mortality from COVID-19 infection. The problems with serious lung injury in SARS infections are mediated by specific antibodies, which are enabling a destructive inflammatory response that makes normal breathing impossible and brings death by suffocation. Antibodies are proteins that our body makes to defend us against infectious organisms. In this situation some of the antibodies appear to have the potential to make the infection more deadly instead of defending the infected Veteran. We propose to identify these specific and dangerous antibodies and then work to understand their structural characteristics and behavior of these so that we can change the clinical outcome for our many Veterans at risk of contracting this deadly infection.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) is major burden to global health systems and responsible for a disproportionate amount of patient morbidity, mortality, and strain within the Veterans Health Administration. Increasing knowledge of the basic biology of CKD holds the promise to unlock new therapies to halt or reverse kidney fibrosis, a pathologic finding that is responsible for CKD progression in humans. Our proposal seeks to better define the role of eicosanoids, which are potent inflammatory molecules that appear to play a major role in driving chronic inflammation that is directly linked to kidney fibrosis and CKD progression. We plan to use animal models of CKD, genetically altered mice, drug therapies, advanced imaging technology, and other highly sophisticated tools in order to determine how we can exploit certain eicosanoid targets for future drug therapy development in humans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: HARRY S. TRUMAN MEMORIAL VA HOSPITAL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The prevalence of type 2 diabetes (T2D) continues to increase in the US, with 26.8 million adults carrying a diagnosis. Importantly, T2D is widespread in the Veteran population, and the VA administration spends $1.5 billion annually in diabetes care. This epidemic of T2D also contributes to the staggering rates of cardiovascular disease and cardiovascular mortality. Lifestyle modifications, including increased physical activity, are recommended as first-line therapy for the management of T2D. Unfortunately, patients with T2D exhibit diminished vascular adaptations to exercise. The proposed project will test the overall hypothesis that degradation of the endothelial glycocalyx, a characteristic feature of T2D, precludes shear stress mechanotransduction and consequent exercise-induced vascular adaptations. As such, we pose that restoration of the endothelial glycocalyx via dietary supplementation of glycocalyx precursors will potentiate vascular adaptations to exercise in Veterans with T2D.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cesarean delivery, the most common major surgical procedure in the US, is the strongest risk factor for maternal infection (a top 3 cause of death during childbirth). Adjunctive azithromycin compared to standard antibiotic prophylaxis alone is proven (through our large C/SOAP trial and other studies) to be highly effective in preventing infection after cesarean - with authorities now recommending consideration of its use while calling for more information on long-term health outcomes after exposure at birth. We propose a US multi-center long-term follow- up study of children from the parent C/SOAP trial at age 6-8 years to evaluate childhood respiratory and gastrointestinal health effects after perinatal exposure to adjunctive azithromycin; findings from this study will be used to inform and strengthen national and global health care policy regarding the use of adjunctive azithromycin to reduce maternal infection after cesarean delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: The Programming Long-lasting Immunity to Coronaviruses (PLUTO) program project will identify B cell responses and immune histories that lead to long-lasting antibody responses to coronaviruses to inform the design of vaccines that protect from SARS-CoV-2 variants, as well as pandemic, zoonotic and seasonal coronaviruses. The efficacy of interventions will be demonstrated in pre-immune preclinical models. The assembled multi-disciplinary team of investigators has extensive expertise in virology, immunology, pathogenesis, universal vaccine development and structural biology as well as a well-established track record of successful collaborations.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The opioid epidemic is a serious public health crisis, with an alarming increase in the rates of opioid use disorder (OUD) and overdose in both the Veteran and general population in the United States over the past two decades. The COVID-19 pandemic is likely to have a short- and long-term impact on the opioid epidemic. It is important to be able to reliably predict which individuals might be more susceptible to developing an OUD or overdose to improve intervention and treatment of high-risk individuals. Post-9/11 Veterans, who were deployed to Iraq, Afghanistan, and other regions in this era of conflicts, have unique risk factors that may predispose them to OUD and overdose related to their history of repeated deployments and deployment- related trauma, including posttraumatic stress disorder, traumatic brain injury and depression. This study will use VA electronic medical record data to build Veteran-specific risk models to understand how the combination of these conditions along with other known and novel risk factors can increase the risk of OUD and overdose.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) are a proven drug target, yet resistance to β-lactam antibiotics, such as carbapenems and cephalosporins, has resulted in a global health problem. We aim to overcome the resistance mechanisms often associated with β-lactam antibiotics, such as β-lactamases, by developing non-β-lactam pyrazolidinone PBP inhibitors to develop novel antibiotics against four ESKAPE pathogens, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Acinetobacter baumannii.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Women are a growing share of the VA population, especially among younger veterans. While there have been some limited evaluations of maternal health/pregnancy care and outcomes among women veterans, to date there hasn’t been a comprehensive assessment of this care. The VA provision of this care is complicated by the fact that VA purchases virtually all pregnancy-related care, which effects the coordination of care in both directions (VA sending information to obstetrics providers and receiving back information about the pregnancy). VA has made significant efforts to address care coordination for pregnant veterans. A comprehensive assessment is needed to inform VA of possible gaps and guide continued improvement of this care, especially around factors that veterans are at elevated risk for, such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The study team is closely linked with Women’s Health Services (WHS) and will feed results to WHS to allow rapid diffusion of policy relevant findings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypomorphic mutant BRCA1 proteins support DNA repair and limit the efficacy of PARP inhibitors in a subset of BRCA1 mutant cancer patients. RNF168 is a major driver of BRCA1 localization for the repair of DNA damage, however its role in BRCA1 mutant cancers is not clear. In this proposal, we explore the BRCA1 mutation-specific roles of RNF168 in cancer cell survival, DNA repair, and PARP inhibitor response while also laying the groundwork for future development of RNF168-targeted therapeutics.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic disabling inflammatory autoimmune disease which affects nearly 1% of Veterans and increases all-cause mortality more than two-fold. Early and aggressive treatment of RA improves likelihood of remission and reduces disability. Biomarkers identifying patients with high likelihood of developing disease could identify those who would benefit from early interventions aimed at preventing disease and reducing disability. Small RNAs (sRNAs) are novel markers and mediators of disease that have potential for elucidating mechanisms and providing accurate diagnosis and new therapies; thus, this proposal focuses on the role of both human and microbial small RNAs in the development of RA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are 25-32 million perceptual errors in radiological case studies worldwide each year, contributing to med-ical error, the third most common cause of death in the US. We seek to reduce detection errors in radiology with four innovations: (1) we will empirically and objectively determine the visual textures used by expert radiologists to identify abnormalities within medical images; (2) we will determine the ways in which expert radiologists use their eyes, and especially their peripheral vision, to scan images and target informative regions; (3) we will de-velop a perceptual learning paradigm to optimally train residents in both texture perception and oculomotor per-formance domains; and (4) we will construct a deep learning model bestowed with simulated human visual and oculomotor capabilities, to create a normative model of human radiological expertise. The combined results from these studies will quantify peak expert performance and be employed to track and enhance individual expertise acquisition during radiology training; thus, the proposed research will help reduce medical error and moreover provide objective fitness-for-duty measurement tools—based on quantified biomarkers—to evaluate and ame-liorate the effects of fatigue on radiologic performance.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: Poorly coordinated healthcare increases patient and provider dissatisfaction, health risks, and resource waste. Coordination of specialty care is a particular challenge which is growing as Veterans receive more care from outside VA under the MISSION Act. To optimize specialty care coordination, we must account for the perspectives of Veteran patients. We will use surveys to compare VA primary care patients' experience of coordination for VA specialty care vs. community-based specialty care (CC); examine how clinicians' experience of coordination relates to that of their patients; and examine how patients' experience of coordination in VA and CC relates to test duplication, medication problems, A1C control (in diabetes), self- efficacy, and patient satisfaction. Results will be actionable by VA management, contribute to new scientific knowledge, and form the foundation of future work to better understand and coordinate specialty care, and ultimately improve satisfaction, health, and costs.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES A. HALEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: The VA system has approved 800,000 disability claims from Veterans which include chronic outcomes of wounds such as increased risk of infections, scars, limited mobility, strained joints and a growing evidence of psychological impact. COVID19 and infection at surgical site, as well as aging, diabetes are significant contributors of slow and delayed wound healing affecting the Veterans’ quality of life. Hence, there is a dire need to develop agents that significantly promote wound closure and support positive long- term outcomes following injury which restore quality of life of US Veterans. Timely treatment also reduces the economic burden. The data shows tremendous potential of hASCexo mediating tissue repair and regeneration for recalcitrant dermal wound related sequelae. Treatment of wounds with hASCexo is an undeniable positive advancement of wound treatment in Veterans. Enhanced treatment of wounds is consistent with the priorities outlined by Department of Veterans Affairs (2018-2024 Strategic plan).

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Narrative There is strong sexual dimorphism in the prevalence, symptom presentation and in response to antidepressant treatment in major depressive disorder (MDD). The proposed study will use a recently established female social defeat mouse model to investigate the role of CCL5 and CCR5 in the pathogenesis of depression and to repurpose maraviroc as a novel therapeutic for treating depression. A successful outcome of the application will fill the gap of knowledge in female social stress and provide experimental evidence and supporting data for targeting CCL5/CCR5 axis as novel antidepressant therapy.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Tobacco use disorder (TUD) remains the leading cause of preventable death in the world. The majority of adult cigarette smokers want to quit and more than half make an attempt but fewer than 1 in 10 smokers successfully quit at the end of 1 year. Rates of cigarette smoking are higher and cessation rates are lower in the veteran population in the United States compared to the nonveteran population. Using noninvasive techniques to change the function of brain areas that are involved in TUD is one approach to developing treatments for TUD. A small area of the brain called the insula is involved in the urge to smoke. This study tests a new noninvasive technique called low intensity focused ultrasound (LIFU) as a way to inhibit the insula and determine whether this causes smokers to have less of an urge to smoke when they see cues that remind them of smoking and whether activity in the insula is decreased after LIFU. Results from this study could provide important information on how the brain becomes addicted to smoking.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Roughly half of all treatment seeking Veterans with PTSD have problems with alcohol, however, the impact of excessive alcohol use on fear extinction and contextual fear processing—processes central to trauma recovery— is unknown. A clear understanding of how ongoing, problematic alcohol use interferes with the mechanisms of fear extinction and contextual fear processing could provide new targets for treatment development and help clinicians and Veterans alike understand how continued problematic drinking may impact exposure-based treatment gains. We propose to use gold-standard and innovative physiological and functional neuroimaging measures to determine the impact of current, heavy alcohol use versus abstinence on the mechanisms of fear extinction and contextual fear processing in Veterans with PTSD and alcoholism. The proposed study will identify critical alcohol-specific mechanisms of impairment to provide a roadmap for the development of targeted interventions to increase efficacy of PAUD treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal, we will study the role of self stress-peptides in mobilizing an antigen specific CD8 regulatory T cell subtype, restricted to HLA-E, and controlling allo-immunity. We will study in particular, the synthetic FL9 peptides and their role in suppressing T follicular helper cells and donor specific antibody generation. These findings open the possibility of HLA-E-targeted vaccine strategies that exploit the limited polymorphism of this MHC class Ib gene and avoid problems of class Ia MHC diversity.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Antimicrobial use is one of the strongest risk factors for the emergence of antimicrobial resistance. Antimicrobial stewardship programs (ASPs) can minimize unnecessary antimicrobial use and are thus an essential tool for addressing the crisis of antimicrobial resistance. The VHA has mandated that every VHA hospital have an ASP, but ASPs tend to focus on antimicrobial use administered to patients while hospitalized without addressing antimicrobial use in the 20% of patients who are discharged on an antimicrobial. This proposal will identify hospitals that are having good clinical outcomes while prescribing less antimicrobials to patients both while they are hospitalized and at the time of discharge. The project team will study the processes these high-performing hospitals are using to improve antimicrobial use at discharge. Across all VHA sites, the team will evaluate whether a specific stewardship process at discharge is beneficial.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Apnea, the transient cessation of respiration, is one of the most common sleep disorders among U.S. military Veterans. Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is characterized by recurrent episodes of partial and complete airway obstruction during sleep with resulting apneas and hypopneas (shallow breathing). The objective of this proposal is to conduct a pragmatic, prospective, observational study that compares a health care delivery model, Direct Referral for Apnea Monitoring (DREAM), with initial in-person (IP) clinic encounters for Veterans at risk for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). The central hypothesis of the proposed research is that the DREAM clinical pathway can improve Veterans’ access to sleep services by reducing wait times for home sleep apnea testing (HSAT) and OSA treatment while maintaining prognostic accuracy that is comparable to IP assessments. If DREAM demonstrates efficacy in the proposed study, it will facilitate significant improvements in the delivery of VA sleep care services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: MicroRNAs are small RNAs that control the formation and loss of bone. For the present application we have conducted experiments showing that microRNAs from the miR 27~23~24 microRNA cluster have great promise as a treatment agent against bone loss. Using this microRNA as an active ingredient in new tissue engineering strategies will help to repair bone and form additional and new bone. We hope that our studies will benefit the health of Americans suffering from bone loss, and result in advanced methodologies for bone regeneration.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) is a devastating systemic disease, which without intensive medical attention and often very expensive therapeutics, often results in joint destruction and virtually complete physical incapacity. We have developed new results that suggest Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) may be a possible cause of RA and have shown that this virus can infect cells from the joints and alter the expression of RA genes. We identified a protein from the virus that potentially alters gene expression in ways that encourage the development of RA and propose to explore its actions in cells, which if our suspicions are established, will provide the basis to change how RA is diagnosed, treated, and, perhaps, even prevented.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Technology holds the potential to aid in understanding the real-world phenomenology of risk for suicide, including identifying potential targets for early intervention. This project will employ smartphone-delivered tests of specific cognitive variables and examine real-time relationships between cognitive dysfunction, negative emotions and social contexts, and suicide risk in Veterans. This pilot project implements mobile health tools for understanding the cognitive mechanisms underlying suicidal ideation outside of the laboratory, setting the stage for future mechanistic and intervention research.

PHR: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) affects 200,000 in the US annually with 40% mortality and no known cure. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We are in the midst of a rapidly moving and dynamic era of biomedical research, where the gap between basic biology and medical practice is growing. The quickening pace of scientific discovery demands a new generation of scientists who are able to understand the languages spoken both in the research setting and in the clinic at the bedside, and communicate effectively with each. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: More than 300,000 Veterans have been exposed to blast or concussive injury, a number that grows larger every year. Veterans experience multiple mild traumatic brain injuries (mTBI) through military-related activities, contact sports participation (including American football, hockey, or boxing) and other recreational activities. Veterans exposed to concussive or blast mTBI are at risk for developing the progressive neurodegenerative disease, chronic traumatic encephalopathy or CTE. CTE cannot yet be diagnosed during life and there are no treatments. Very little is known about how CTE is triggered in the brain and how it progresses, although our previous studies suggest that neuroinflammation and neurodegenerative cells play a pivotal role. We propose to comprehensively identify the inflammatory proteins and cell types involved in the onset of CTE. The results generated by this study will lead to new ways to identify CTE in living Veterans, and to develop effective therapies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a serious public health problem with approximately 69 million individuals estimated to sustain a TBI each year. TBI is a regarded as a signature wound for many Veterans, with the rate of TBI among troops reported to be as high as 33%. Furthermore, the propensity for head injuries sustained in combat has placed our Veterans at even greater risk for developing neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer’s disease (AD), highlighting the urgency to understand the causal factors that can be targeted to prevent or treat affected Veterans. At the moment, there are no effective disease-modifying therapies available for TBI or AD, and there is a clear, unmet need for novel strategies to treat these disorders. The current proposal will investigate a critical biological mechanism that contributes to disease progression following TBI, with the purpose of identifying new treatment strategies for this disorder, which will improve the welfare of our Veteran population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Overall, our proposal is conceptually novel in that it seeks to implicate a membrane transporter in essential pathophysiological functions that are not directly dependent on its transport activities. In addition, the proposed research will also facilitate the development of therapeutic strategies targeting intestinal inflammatory conditions, including colitis and may prevent colitis associated cancer. Impact on Veterans Health care: Over one million adults in the US, including members of the VA population, suffer from IBD, and about 50,000 new cases are diagnosed each year (according to the Crohn’s and Colitis Foundation of America. The VA IBD patients have a much higher rate of colorectal cancer compared to the general population (2.9% vs. 0.1%; from National Center for Health Statistics data). Thus, attaining an understanding of the etiology of IBD and the relevant pathological mechanisms are major aims of research seeking to develop effective future treatments will directly benefit the veteran population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute lung injury (ALI) is a frequent and often lethal secondary organ complication of acute kidney injury (AKI) that has no therapies. The combination of AKI with ALI carries a 60-80% mortality risk with no specific therapies. The proposed research is relevant to the mission of the VA as it may lead to the development of novel therapeutic options for secondary organ complications of AKI, in particular ALI. The expected outcomes of our studies are thus relevant to the mission of the VA to reduce morbidity and mortality in kidney patients and could significantly impact suffering and health care expenditure.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To date, there is no proven effective cure for alcoholic liver disease. The work proposed in this application will dissect the pathogenic role of a protein complex of liver origin as a central upstream regulator of a proinflammatory program that besides being detrimental to the liver, drives intestinal injury; hence, creating an amplifying feedback loop in alcoholic liver disease. The results from this project will benefit the design of new therapies for preventing or treating this devastating disease that affects many US Veterans and is currently on the rise.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The outcomes of septic patients in the VA are known to vary depending on facility and region of treatment. Typically, the care of septic patients at high risk of death is provided in the ICU. While there are known treatment modalities that improve the outcomes of sepsis patients, it is unclear what these modalities are and if these modalities are used in the VA consistently. This proposal will use advanced datasets, previously not available, and qualitative measures to examine the care delivered in septic patients in the VA. In this proposal, we describe using data from the TeleICU and other VA sources to develop a better understanding of the care delivered in VA ICUs to look for variation in practice and modalities that are associated with improved outcomes in sepsis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Vitamin B1 is indispensable for normal human health due to the essential roles it plays in oxidative energy metabolism, ATP generation, reduction of oxidative stress, and mitochondrial function. Humans cannot synthesize vitamin B1, and thus, must obtain it from exogenous sources ( i. e, diet and the gut microbiota) via absorption along the intestinal tract. Deficiency of vitamin B1 occurs in conditions like inflammatory bowel diseases, sepsis and chronic alcoholism, which affect significant number of our Veterans and the general population. It is therefore of physiological, nutritional and pathophysiological importance to understand how the different forms of vitamin B1 are absorbed in the gut and how conditions/factors that the intestine is exposed to under certain disease states affect these absorptive processes. This is our objective in this proposal. Results should provide novel information regarding vitamin B1 absorption in health and disease, which should assist in the designing of effective strategies to optimize its homeostasis/nutrition, and thus, improve human health.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Obesity and its associated comorbidities reduces healthspan and quality of life, including that of Veterans. Easy access to obesogenic diets drives weight gain, metabolic disorders and sleep disturbances. Orexin is a brain compound that increases calorie burning while stabilizing sleep/wake states, and it prevents weight gain during overfeeding in rodents. We would like to develop orexin-based anti-obesity therapies for humans, but orexin itself does not cross the blood-brain barrier, which is needed to achieve the anti-obesity affects. To this end, we have developed two novel compounds (orexin agonists) that mimic the effects of orexin, but which can cross the blood-brain barrier, making them promising candidates for use in human obesity. In this application we will test these two novel small molecular weight orexin agonists in mice, to determine their effectiveness as anti-obesity agents and in improving sleep/wake patterns. The overall goal is to provide preclinical data on these agents for use in future studies, to help address obesity in the Veteran population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs

PHR: Plasmodium vivax (Pv) malaria is the most widespread malaria infection, with an estimated 2.85 billion at risk and >10 million clinical cases annually. Of the approximately 170,000 active duty soldiers deployed overseas today, at least 10% are in countries endemic for Pv, and malaria is the second most common chronic infectious disease of active personnel. Pv is a concern for veterans because following initial exposure and illness, the parasite develops latent stages in the liver, and relapse can occur up to 5 years after leaving endemic areas. The Military Infectious Disease Research Program has prioritized the development of a Pv vaccine. Results of this research will enable progress toward a multi-component vaccine and novel therapeutics against Pv, thus aiding attempts at elimination, and will also advance the potential of antibody therapies for severely ill individuals and those in need of sustained prophylaxis during seasonal transmission and tours of duty.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Diabetes (DM) complications are the major cause of DM morbidity, mortality, and costs. As current care does not take advantage of progress in genetics, we will incorporate genetics. Since Veterans thought to have type 2 DM may also have genes for type 1 DM, we will assess the contributions of these genetic loads to the patterns of disease. To account for a wide range of risk, we will assess the combined contributions of genetic and nongenetic risk factors to the DM complications of eye and kidney disease, hypoglycemia, and heart failure, including development and testing of predictive models. Since changes to our DNA can alter what our genes do, we will identify “epigenomic” markers and molecular systems underlying DM complications. Our study of the genetics of diagnosis, gene-environment interactions, epigenomics, and predictive models should both aid translation – to identify risk in individuals, and help personalize treatment to reduce DM complications and hypoglycemia – and support discovery of new therapies to mitigate the underlying processes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sudden cardiac arrest is highly prevalent in the United States, affecting over 380,000 Americans every year and occurring in 4 out of every 1000 Veterans Administration hospitalizations. The mortality for sudden cardiac arrest exceeds 70%. Despite the high prevalence and mortality, there are no pharmacologic therapies that have been shown to improve survival outcomes in these patients. This project aims to better understand the molecular mechanisms of sudden cardiac arrest by evaluating mitochondrial DNA changes and related cardiac inflammation in mouse and cellular models, which may lead to novel targets to improve outcomes following sudden cardiac arrest.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Excess steroid hormone production from the adrenal cortex increases with age and contributes to hypertension, heart failure, obesity, glucose intolerance, and low bone mass. Veterans are vulnerable to these diseases and the associated morbidity due to their prior exposures and complex medical histories. Surgery is the preferred treatment, but many Veterans are not surgical candidates, and current medical treatments are limited to receptor antagonists that all have narrow therapeutic indices and significant side effects. The two different enzymes that catalyze the last steps of cortisol and aldosterone synthesis are ideal drug targets, but these enzymes are very similar. Drugs that inhibit specific steps in aldosterone and cortisol synthesis would be better treatments, but we do not know enough about the differences of these highly related enzymes to rationally design drugs to block only one of these reactions. To pave the way for better treatments of aldosterone and cortisol excess, we propose to systematically dissect the biochemistry of these two enzymes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal and incurable neurological disease characterized by progressive paralysis due to motor neuron (MN) degeneration. We propose a multicenter, translational study using both post- mortem tissue from ALS patients and transgenic ALS mice to test the hypothesis that in ALS, an altered sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P) system drives the proinflammatory activation of astrocytes and microglia and that treatment with S1P modulators will interfere with the proinflammatory process to slow down (or recover) the degeneration of MN. To evaluate pathology, we will use a combination of biochemical, immunohistochemical, spectroscopy, and imaging techniques. The study will provide valuable data towards understanding the pathological process of ALS and finding new therapeutic approaches to prevent, slow, or cure the disease.
