IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Post-traumatic stress disorder is a major problem for the VA. According to the VA, 14% of individuals that served in OIF or OEF develop PTSD, a rate that is substantially higher than the general population (7-8%). Women veterans appear to be more a risk for PTSD than men. Frontline treatment options (e.g., SSRIs) can improve symptoms but do not currently offer a cure. To develop further strategies to this end, it is critical to understand the foundations of the disease process as it develops. This proposal examines the role prefrontal cortex stress hormone (glucocorticoid) receptors in driving development of PTSD behavioral pathologies, ranging from anxiety symptoms, exaggerated fear responses and cognitive dysfunction. These studies employ pharmacological, genetic and cell physiological approaches to test the role of abnormal glucocorticoid signaling in generation of behavioral disturbances in rodent models. Our results will inform future strategies to target abnormal stress hormone signals in behavioral pathologies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) results in cellular structural damage followed by widespread dysfunctions including maladaptive dysregulation of injury-response mechanisms and ultimately neurological. We aim to characterize the molecular mechanisms that modulate progressive brain neurodegeneration and associated neurological impairments after TBI. Veterans are a distinct group of brain trauma patients because military TBI features specific conditions, before and after trauma that impact the developing neuropathology. Recent studies have shown that stress results in significant and wide-ranging negative effects on the brain that may be mediated by pro-inflammatory systemic and central (brain) mechanisms. These processes that may underpin the development of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) become even more significant in association with TBI. We hypothesize that exposure to pre- and/or post-TBI stress changes the trajectory of neuroinflammation and neurodegeneration progression in TBI, accelerating and extending the neuropathological processes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The kidney provides fluid balance and toxin removal essential to human health. The filtering units (glomeruli) and the permeable drains (tubules) that carry and remove fluid from the body can be easily damaged, and such damage (called 'acute kidney injury', or AKI) often leads to prolonged hospitalization and permanent kidney damage among Veterans. However, physicians are currently only able to measure the function of the glomeruli. I plan to study measures of tubular function in the kidney. My goal is to provide an understanding of how AKI happens and to develop clinical tests that can predict risk of AKI. Based on the data generated from the CDA2 award, I intend to apply for an independent research grant from the VA. I envision testing the markers in a variety of clinical settings, for instance, in cancer patients exposed to life-saving but potentially kidney-damaging medications.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Alcohol use disorders is highly co-morbid with depression and chronic pain, and especially high in veterans, but there is limited research on the impact of these co-morbidities on brain neurobiology. The goal of the proposed training and research is to delineate the overlapping and co-occurring patterns from neuroimaging and clinical symptomologies that form a brain signature of depression and chronic pain within the alcohol use disorder brain signature through the use of advanced computational modeling algorithms to better inform individualized precision medicine treatment approaches for veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Liver damage leads to scaring of the liver in a pathologic process known as cirrhosis. This leads to many different complications that lead to a poor quality of life, including severe intestinal bleeding, fluid buildup in the abdomen, and others. This proposal aims to understand the cause of this scarring in the liver, and ultimately to provide insights that lead to new therapies to treat this problem.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Narrative The commensal gut microbiota is a robust modulator of innate immune signaling and skeletal growth and maturation, but there is a limited understanding of commensal gut microbiota actions impacting skeletal maturation and deterioration. While innate immune complement signaling has been shown to regulate pathogenic microbes and promote osteoblast-osteoclast differentiation and signaling, the role of complement in the maturing and aging skeleton in health and disease remains to be elucidated. Mechanisms underlying how the commensal gut microbiota regulates the skeleton across the lifespan are unclear, thus lies a critical need to advance our understanding of commensal gut microbiota mechanisms impacting bone mass accrual in our young service members and Nation’s Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Tinnitus and hearing loss have been the #1 and #2 disabilities at the VA for more than a decade. These auditory disorders are associated with depression, isolation, anxiety disorders, PTSD, sleep deprivation, cognition, loss of employability, and increased industrial and motor vehicle accidents. Yet there is no effective treatment for either disorder and genetic distinction between the two disorders is as yet uncharacterized.  Our plan is to use the rich data in the Million Veteran Program to perform and analyze genome-wide association studies in order to identify relevant genes. In our current work, we have established a pipeline and for the first time, identified genetic variants associated with tinnitus. We will computationally separate and examine the genetic architecture of these two auditory disorders using military- and Veteran-relevant etiologies, i.e., age-related, chronic noise secondary to military exposures, blast, and traumatic brain injury. Identifying genes and their relevant pathways will direct pharmaceutical approaches towards treatment and ultimate cure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The current “one-size-fits-all” strategy for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) early detection using abdominal ultrasound +/- a serum biomarker, alpha fetoprotein (AFP), in all patients with cirrhosis ignores the heterogeneity in HCC risk among patients with cirrhosis and the suboptimal accuracy of current screening tests, highlighting a need for risk stratification and early detection biomarkers. Our Clinical Validation Center for HCC (CVC-HCC) will leverage existing infrastructure across five health systems to create two novel resources not offered by the current sample sets including (1) a biorepository with both blood and imaging data from patients, with and without HCC, representing contemporary etiologies of liver disease for Phase I-II biomarker studies and (2) a prospective cohort of patients with indeterminate liver nodules to evaluate HCC risk stratification and early detection biomarkers to conduct Phase III biomarker studies using a prospective- specimen-collection, retrospective-blinded-evaluation (PRoBE) design. Overall, our CVC-HCC will lead to significant advances in phase I-III validation of novel biomarkers for HCC risk stratification and early detection, areas of need that will facilitate development of well-designed phase IV clinical utility trials.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Lung cancer represents a considerable disease burden within the Veteran population. It is diagnosed at a rate of 18.8%, second only to prostate cancer in highest incidence. However, even after definitive treatment, lung cancer patients remain at risk for recurrent disease and developing second primary lung cancers for which imaging surveillance guidelines exist. By examining the patterns of care, guideline concordance, and clinical outcomes associated with post-treatment surveillance following definitive treatment for lung cancer, the VA may better define the elements of quality care for lung cancer patients and enhance the ability of the healthcare system to respond to the anticipated increased imaging demands associated with the adoption of CT screening within the VA population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application seeks funding to continue a training program in developmental therapeutics focused on cancer drugs at the Moores Cancer Center at the University of California, San Diego. Our vision is that cancer can be controlled with novel drug, immunologic and viral therapeutics directed at molecular targets that allow individualization of treatment. The mission of the program is to provide training to postdoctoral PhD and MD- physician-scientists in each of the major steps in the development of novel cancer therapeutics so as to position these individuals to play leading roles in translating laboratory-based discoveries into safe and effective therapeutic agents.

PHR: NARRATIVE Mutations in KCNMA1 BK potassium channels produce a wide range of neurological disorders which include epilepsy and autism. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malignant melanoma is the most dangerous skin cancer, with a very poor survival rate once metastasis has occurred. Current treatments target the primary tumor and not the process of metastasis, and once the cancer has disseminated, chemotherapy has limited value. This project aims to integrate novel tissue engineered tumor mimics with patient derived tumor xenografts to explore progression towards patient-specific models for therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: PALO ALTO VETERANS INSTIT FOR RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to identify intrinsic differences in immune phenotype and function, irrespective of the degree of immunosuppression, between liver and kidney transplant recipients who did or did not respond to SARS-CoV- 2 vaccination. The studies will employ state-of-the-art technologies to decipher phenotypic, transcriptional, and epigenetic features of responders versus non-responders at the single cell level. The proposed high-risk mechanistic experiments on ex vivo human cells, have the potential to deepen our understanding of the immune responses against SARS-CoV2 vaccine in organ transplant recipients (high reward) and will provide the basis for larger studies to test the generated hypotheses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Fear of recurrence or cancer coming back is an important issue for the estimated 17 million cancer survivors who are alive in the US today, but cancer recurrence information is currently not available for research in the national cancer registry data due to difficulties in capturing this information. At the Utah Cancer Registry, we have multiple statewide linkages to health records data that other registries do not have, that could facilitate obtaining cancer recurrence data. We propose to develop methods to identify recurrence and validate the methods with the Cancer Registry in Seattle-Puget Sound, so that other researchers can apply the methods to data in the cancer registries and with additional data linkages that are rapidly increasing across cancer registries in various states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because obesity rates are steadily increasing and there are significant health and financial costs associated with this increase. Understanding the neural mechanisms that underlie feeding, and specifically those underlying non-homeostatic feeding and responses to food-associated cues, which can drive feeding the absence of homeostatic need, is necessary to identify new targets and approaches to treat obesity and other eating disorders. Thus, this proposal is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to fostering fundamental basic science discoveries, using innovative approaches, with the goal of ultimately improving health.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative  Acute kidney injury (AKI) is a common and serious complication in hospitalized Veterans. Patients with AKI are at significant risk for the subsequent development of chronic kidney disease (CKD). This proposal will focus on the lymphatic system, which is crucial for maintaining fluid balance, transporting lipids, and aiding in immune function, within the kidney particularly during AKI and the AKI to CKD transition. Successful completion of the aims of this project will help better understand the pathogenesis of AKI during both injury and repair and could provide new avenues targeting the lymphatic system for therapeutic interventions in AKI.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Bacterial pneumonia and influenza are a leading cause of death worldwide. Our veteran patient populations are at particular risk for these infections due to advanced age, chronic medical conditions, and other factors. Neutrophils are a type of white blood cell that is critically important to fighting bacterial and other infections. Unfortunately, how to properly regulate neutrophil functions is not well understood, because up until relatively recently, the field of immunology has not appreciated the considerable diversity of neutrophil subtypes that can develop during infections. Our research will investigate whether neutrophils that develop during flu infections possess different characteristics and functional capabilities than neutrophils generated to fight bacterial infections. A new powerful technology called mass cytometry will be used to detect over 30 markers on individual neutrophils, to identify neutrophil subsets. Ultimately, these results be used to create new treatments to regulate neutrophil functions more appropriately.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Veterans who get much of their healthcare in the VA system are often hospitalized or seen emergently at non- VA community hospitals or clinics. While this is often necessary and wanted, some research says that getting care at multiple places can result in problems like higher risk for getting re-admitted to the hospital or having medical complications. In order to make cross-system healthcare safer, the VA Office of Community Care is designing programs to coordinate Veterans’ medical care during and after visits in community hospitals. Our research team plans to study these new programs when VA facilities across the country start using them in 2018. We plan to measure whether or not Veterans are more likely to get readmitted to the hospital or seen in emergency departments once the programs start, and we’ll ask Veterans, doctors, and nurses what they think about the programs. Our goal is to figure out if the programs are helpful and successful, and to improve them for the future.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: HARRY S. TRUMAN MEMORIAL VA HOSPITAL
PHR: The mechanisms of heart failure are complex, and include hemodynamic overload and local and systemic neurohormonal changes. Although pharmacologic treatment of heart failure has made significant advances, the associated mortality and morbidity remains high with significant cost to the Veterans Healthcare System. RECK (Reversion Inducing Cysteine Rich Protein with Kazal Motifs) expression is significantly reduced in human heart failure. Since RECK targets multiple mediators known to contribute to adverse cardiac remodeling and heart failure development, we believe that strategies that induce RECK expression in the heart will ameliorate the structural and compositional changes within the heart, and vastly improve outcomes for cardiac patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Diarrhea is one of the most common causes of disability of U.S. Veterans while they serve overseas. The most common chronic diarrheal disease in this country and in Veterans is inflammatory bowel disease (IBD; e.g. Crohn’s disease). Diarrhea is the most common and disabling morbidity of IBD. The prevalence of IBD has increased 2 to 3-fold among VA users and its prevalence is also known to increase with each decade of life in Veterans. Malabsorption of electrolytes and fluid by intestinal epithelial cells is a critical determinant of diarrhea in IBD, in which immune inflammatory mediators are known to play pivotal role. Thus, the overall goal of this project is to understand how NaCl absorption is regulated in the IBD intestine so that this novel information may form the foundation for designing new, superior, and specific immune-based therapies for diarrhea in IBD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Deterioration of kidney function, or acute kidney failure is an important contributing factor to the morbidity and mortality of hospitalized veterans. Unfortunately, there is no established treatment to date for this disease except supportive care with dialysis. Our proposed research will study the role of a protein, Tamm-Horsfall Protein (THP), that may protect the kidneys in the setting of injury. Therefore, this project has improtant direct relevance to veterans health. A better understanding of the role of THP holds promise for future therapeutic stategies that improve outcomes of kidney failure by enhancing the protective role of this protein.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The U.S. Veterans are under risk to develop lethal blood cancers due to exposure to carcinogens, such as agent orange, during their active military service. Many of these cancers are treated with hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) or bone marrow transplantation (BMT), where the successful outcome of transplant procedure is curtailed by the devastating and lethal graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). The US Veterans are likewise under risk to develop end-stage organ failure (such as kidney failure), where successful treatment with organ transplantation is curtailed by rejection. GVHD or rejection of a solid organ can be prevented without the use of toxic immune suppressive medications by inducing a condition called mixed chimerism, which is characterized by the presence of recipient and donor blood cells after transplantation. Our studies are expected to lead to the identification of novel, safe and potent therapeutic approaches to treat Veterans against GVHD or organ rejection by stimulating mixed chimerism, while preventing the relapse of the cancer.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: SOUTH TEXAS VETERANS HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Parkinson’s disease (PD) is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in the Veteran population, comprising an increasingly prevalent neurodegenerative disease with profound motor, cognitive, and behavioral dysfunction. More than a million Americans suffer from PD, of whom more than 80,000 are Veterans, and about 50,000 new cases are diagnosed annually. The burden of PD is especially heavy in the Veteran population, due in part to the aging demographic – age is the best documented risk factor – as well as the risks of traumatic brain injury and exposure to environmental neurotoxins in military settings. The total US economic burden of PD – currently $52B annually – is expected to skyrocket as almost eight million baby boomers, including many Vietnam era Veterans, have recently turned 60, the age at which PD prevalence begins to increase sharply. Identification of early diagnostic biomarkers, as we propose to do in this application, will provide the best opportunity for effective early intervention to treat the disease before disabling symptoms appear.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will determine the importance of different mechanisms that allow HIV persistence in gastrointestinal, genitourinary, and adipose tissues. Duplication of HIV DNA by cell division, transmission of HIV RNA between cells within tissues, and trafficking of virus between these tissues may all contribute to HIV persistence. This study will analyze and compare these processes, so that HIV cure research can focus on the critical obstacles to eradication of the virus from these under-studied organ systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Pulmonary hypertension (PH), despite new therapeutic advances, continues to be associated with significant morbidity and mortality. It is increasingly clear that inflammation plays a critical role in the disease, yet at present, there are no therapies that effectively ameliorate this component of the disease process. This proposal seeks to uncover novel pathogenic processes linking pulmonary vascular inflammation and vascular remodeling. In this proposal we test the hypothesis that early and persistent pulmonary vascular specific activation of complement leads to persistent inflammation and vascular remodeling. We propose to uncover new biomarkers and new targets for intervention in this devasting disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative for the Overall Component The mission of the UT Southwestern Wellstone Muscular Dystrophy Specialized Research Center is to promote collaborative basic science, translational, and clinical research for the advancement of promising CRISPR/Cas9- mediated genomic editing technologies to permanently restore dystrophin expression and improve the lives of Duchenne muscular dystrophy patients. Our Center provides excellent training for the next generation of researchers and outstanding resources for the muscular dystrophy communities. Our community outreach efforts increase patient and caregiver awareness of our research progress and opportunities to participate in clinical research studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Persistent perivascular inflammation is observed in many forms of pulmonary hypertension and is now thought to contribute significantly to both the overall vascular remodeling and high pulmonary artery pressures that characterize this lethal disease process. We show that early activation of complement occurs in PH and that this activation is critical in the early recruitment and persistence of inflammatory cells. The purpose of our project is to determine the mechanisms contributing to early and persistent complement activation and to determine if complement activation, in the vessel wall, can ultimately be targeted to ameliorate the disease process.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative for the Administrative Core The proposed NIH P50 Grant Application has significant relevance to the public health of our nation. The overall study is both significant and innovative because it proposes that genome editing can permanently restore dystrophin expression within the skeletal muscle of patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy. The Administrative Core will be charged with the mission of providing effective leadership and management of the UT Southwestern Muscular Dystrophy Specialized Research Center in order to enhance the Center’s opportunity to successfully and significantly contribute to the field of muscular dystrophy research and patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The immune system likely contributes to the development of pulmonary hypertension by excessive inflammation, which causes disease in the lung blood vessels. Our research investigates how different parts of the immune system, including complement proteins, CD4 T cells, monocytes and macrophages can together cause pulmonary hypertension. Our main approach is by studying mice exposed to schistosomiasis: this is a parasite released by freshwater snails in tropical countries, affecting over 200 million people worldwide, and is a major cause of pulmonary hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project 3 in this PPG seeks to provide the translational significance to Projects 1,2 and 4, by investigating the proteome (proteins) and transcriptome (mRNA) of lungs of individuals with severe pulmonary hypertension due to idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension (IPAH) as compared to normal lungs. We also seek to investigate the presence of markers of complement activation in the serum of a large cohort of well-characterized patients with IPAH and in tissue sections of IPAH patients correlating these data with inflammatory parameters. We apply the same methods to 2 models that most closely approximate the human condition to test if they can better provide preclinical data regarding targeting complement. Finally, we test whether blockade of complement can reduce the PH inflammatory environment and normalize the PH vascular proteome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The chromatin-based DNA damage response (DDR) pathway is an intricate network composed of multiple protein complexes. Dysregulation of the DDR pathway leads to genome instability, developmental defects, cancer predisposition, and premature aging. The goals of our research are to characterize the DDR network, decipher the DNA damage-induced epigenetic codes, and understand the functions of the DNA repair proteins to build a foundation for therapeutic strategy development in the DNA damage-related disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The Myoediting Core is designed and managed as a shared Scientific Research Resource Core to support the research of the Muscular Dystrophy Specialized Research Center (MDSRC) at UT Southwestern, other Wellstone MDSRCs, as well as serving as a resource for the national and international muscular dystrophy research community. This proposal offers a novel strategy for treating Duchenne muscular dystrophy, called “Myoediting” which involves molecularly modifying the genome of muscle cells affected by this disease, correcting the mutation in a manner that causes permanent skipping of the mutant exons within the dystrophin gene transcript. The Myoediting Core is developing state-of- the-art myoediting tools, technologies and reagents to improve efficacy of current gene repair strategies and to facilitate new strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is a progressive and often fatal disease driven by inflammatory mediated vascular remodeling. This project examines the mechanisms by which complement activated platelets drive endothelial activation and monocyte/macrophage proinflammatory differentiation and recruitment, promoting vascular remodeling in pulmonary hypertension. These results will set the stage for future studies targeting the platelet immune response in patients with pulmonary hypertension with novel currently available therapies.

PHR: Project Narrative There is no cure available for Duchenne muscular dystrophy. We are using CRISPR/Cas9-mediated genomic editing (we call “Myoediting) to correct the mutation causing Duchenne muscular dystrophy in human cells and animal models. This project represents a close collaboration between clinicians and basic scientists sharing the common goal of advancing Myoediting, an new therapeutic strategy to permanently cure Duchenne muscular dystrophy in humans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans as a group, are at high risk of severe disease from SARS CoV-2 (CoV-2) during the COVID-19 pandemic and both breakthrough and reinfection are increasingly documented. Critical questions regarding host immune responses during and following infection remain unanswered. We found that CoV-2 particles and the structural spike protein (S) directly interact with human immune cells, altering normal T cell functions and differentiation, and we hypothesize that CoV2 interference with T cell signaling contributes to the establishment of infection, immune evasion, and reduces effector and memory T cell responses. These findings will facilitate new approaches to therapy and potentially lead to more effective vaccines.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Despite decades of work, the mechanisms that cause high blood pressure (hypertension), a major health concern for veterans, continue to be elucidated. Immune system activation has been linked to the development of hypertension, and is also directly linked to rheumatic diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) that predominantly affect women. Rheumatic disease and are a major health concern for the military, and women represent an increasing demographic among veterans. This proposal will explore how immune system activation during SLE impacts kidney function and leads to hypertension with a focus on understanding a specific immune cell type (neutrophils) and the powerhouse of cells (mitochondria). Examining how the immune system impacts blood pressure during this disease will not only provide new insights for women with SLE, but also will add to the overall understanding of hypertension.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Osteoarthritis (OA) is a common form of arthritis, affecting 50+ million adults in the US and for which there is no effective treatment. Post-traumatic OA (PTOA) is a form of OA that develops after a joint injury. It accounts for 12% of all OA and 20% of all joint replacements. Additionally, among combat veterans from ongoing US military operations the frequency of arthritis is estimated at 11.8%. We propose to develop nanotherapeutic approaches that can be delivered into the injured joint to prevent or halt the progression of PTOA. We believe that any intervention that decreases the risk and rate of PTOA reduces the overall burden of OA.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Bone injuries are a major health problem. There are 7.9 million bone fractures sustained annually in the U.S. alone. Bone healing is impaired in 10% of fractures with seriously delayed union or nonunion, causing morbidity for patients and enormous healthcare costs. Thus, there is a compelling need to find novel effective therapies that promote fracture healing. In this project, we will use 3D printed fibrin gel/β-tricalcium phosphate (βTCP) scaffolds to test the therapeutic effects of the smoothened agonist, SAG21k, to activate hedgehog signaling in a burst manner and a prolyl hydroxylase domain (PHD)2 protein inhibitor, IOX2, to activate hypoxia signaling in a sustained manner in a clinically relevant femoral segment defect model for nonunions. Our successful completion of the proposed work could lead to the development of novel SAG21k-IOX2-based therapeutics which accelerate bony bridging and, thereby, minimize the chance of developing a nonunion fracture. Our proposed work on the elucidation of the role of chondrocyte-to-osteoblast conversion for SAG21k and IOX2 effects at the fracture site could also identify new therapeutic drug targets for bone healing.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heterotopic ossification (HO) is the formation of ectopic bone in extra-skeletal tissues due to aberrant soft tissue healing following musculoskeletal damage. Musculoskeletal injuries range widely, from trauma incurred during combat operations to controlled tissue damage during orthopaedic surgeries. Complications from HO include chronic pain, chronic infection, and impaired wound healing, leading to loss of mobility and inhibiting prosthetics use, thus impeding Veteran independence and return to normalcy. These difficulties can lead to comorbidities like opioid addiction and depression that can lead to overdose or suicide, which are all major issues in overall Veteran health. Current treatment options for HO are limited due to the lack of understanding of the molecular mechanisms that drive ectopic bone formation. In this proposal, we will elucidate the links between abnormal extracellular matrix deposition, aberrant osteogenic signaling, and ectopic bone formation in order to identify new treatment strategies to prevent HO formation in our Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) accounts for 80% of adult acute leukemia and has a five-year survival rate of only 25%. It is more common in men and incidence increases with age. AML is associated with military service in specific groups of Veterans. It also develops following treatment for other cancers, including those common in Veterans. This merit award proposal explores approaches to improving treatment for AML with fms-like tyrosine kinase 3 internal tandem duplication (FLT3-ITD), a molecular abnormality present in AML cells in 30% of patients and associated with poor treatment outcomes. The work has the potential to improve outcomes in Veterans who develop this common and unfavorable AML subtype, including following military and medical exposures. The long-term goal is to develop clinical trials of multi-targeting approaches to improving outcomes of patients with AML with FLT3-ITD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative  Anxiety disorders are common and often disabling. They also frequently present with other psychiatric disorders such as major depressive disorder (MDD) and post- traumatic stress disorder; these disorders may share commonalities in their underlying genetic architecture. These commonalities might be informative in the treatment of veterans suffering from PTSD. Additionally, anxiety disorders have known overlapping risk for cardiovascular disease and lung cancer. Anxiety disorders are not only common, but they have broad and understudied health implications for veterans. We propose to perform the largest genetic study of anxiety ever conducted. We will use this information to investigate overlapping genetics between psychiatric disorders and known health risks such as cardiovascular disease and lung cancer.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Reduction of myocardial conduction velocity (MCV) in the heart is a primary cause of ventricular tachycardia and sudden cardiac death. There are no treatments for cardiac arrhythmias that improve MCV; however, we have recently described carbon nanotube fibers (CNTf) as a strong, flexible, electrically conductive suture material that is capable of electrically bridging scar tissue in the heart. The goal of this research proposal is to examine the mechanisms whereby CNTf serve as a conduit to restore electrical conduction within the heart.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Approximately 200,000 veterans receive cancer care in VHA facilities. About 30% of them undergo radiation therapy as part of their treatment. With increasing cancer survival rates, the long-term adverse side effects of cancer therapies, including radiation therapy have becoming widely apparent. Damage to endothelial cells, in particular in microvessels is believed to drive many long-term health problems after radiation therapy, including heart failure and lung fibrosis after radiation therapy to the chest and cognitive decline after radiation therapy to the brain. The proposed research aims at understanding how mitochondria in endothelial cells mediate the radiation-induced microvascular damage and provide proof of concept for developing new mechanism-based treatments. The proposed research is directly relevant to VA healthcare because of the high disease burden of cancer with its increasingly recognized implications for vascular disease and the enormous health care cost it causes in veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is a highly prevalent and chronic psychiatric disorder in Veterans and the broader US population. It is a terrible disorder, associated with significant stigma, diminished psychosocial functioning, poor physical health, and lessened quality of life. The disorder is complex and multifaceted; diagnosis is often difficult, and the mechanism of the illness is not fully understood. We proposed a novel approach in this CDA-2 application to generate novel biological markers of PTSD symptomatology and to link each of the PTSD symptom domains with a deficit in specific brain networks. To understand this complex and heterogeneous illness, we will employ modern analytical tools and machine learning algorithms. Doing so would represent the innovative first step towards characterizing heterogeneity in this disorder, and, if successful, could lead to objective markers of circuit dysfunction that can be targeted by specific interventions.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Lower airway dysbiosis characterized by the enrichment of the lungs with oral commensals is a poorly understood phenomenon, but a common event that increases in the diseased lung. Veterans with lung dysbiosis may be at-risk for increased pathogen susceptibility and infection. Chronic dysbiosis is associated with increased lung PD1+ T cells and Tregs which may mediate the poor immune response to respiratory pathogens, something that I will study using a pre-clinical murine model in this project. I will use next-generation sequencing with multi- omic bioinformatics and measurement of microbial metabolites to identify functional host-microbiota signatures in chronic dysbiosis associated with increased pathogen susceptibility. I will evaluate the mechanisms involved in determining the altered lower airway immunity against respiratory pathogens induced by chronic dysbiosis. My proposal is relevant for the veteran population as pneumonia is one of the main causes for VA hospital admission, thus identification of modifiable targets is a priority.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Schizophrenia is a leading cause of disability for Veterans, but remains poorly treated. A primary focus of Dr. Tregellas’ research is developing a better understanding of the neurobiology underlying schizophrenia and developing new, more effective treatments for the illness. Much of this work is aimed at reducing activity of the hippocampus, which is now considered a core feature of schizophrenia. Dr. Tregellas’ current study is determining if low-dose levetiracetam , typically used at higher doses to treat seizures, can reduce hippocampal activity and improve schizophrenia symptoms. He also is interested in how antipsychotic medications used to treat schizophrenia symptoms cause weight gain and metabolic problems in patients, and how exercise might alter these effects. Related to this, Dr. Tregellas is interested in understanding the neurobiology of obesity not only in schizophrenia, but also in non-mentally ill Veterans, who have obesity rates substantially higher than in the general population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS) and Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) are closely related blood malignancies that are most prevalent in aging populations. Occurring typically after the age of 60, these malignancies are usually fatal. As the proportion of Veterans reaching old age is increasing, understanding the molecular mechanisms underpinning the role of aging in these diseases is critical for effective treatment. Furthermore, environmental exposure to various toxic chemicals has been linked to higher incidence of both MDS and AML, likely putting Veterans at an increased risk for both diseases. Unfortunately, treatments for MDS and AML are largely ineffective, as evidenced by a 5-year survival rate of less than 25% for AML patients. The proposed studies aim to increase the efficacy of existing treatments for myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML) by identifying and characterizing RNA processing phenotypes that predict age-related disease progression and drug resistance.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: The VA provides health care to more than 250,000 Veterans with psychotic-spectrum disorders, including schizophrenia, a chronic illness associated with significant disability and high health care costs. The symptom of avolition, a deficit in initiating and sustaining goal-oriented behavior, is a strong predictor of poor outcomes in patients with schizophrenia and is resistant to currently available treatments. An improved understanding of the neurobiology of avolition, and validated neurobiological models that translate across species, can lead to more effective interventions. This project seeks to uncover the underlying mechanisms of avolition using a powerful combination of neuroscientific tools and a translational paradigm that taps parallel mechanisms across humans and rodents. Successful completion of this project will yield a broadened knowledge of the neurobiology of avolition. Further, evidence garnered from this study can help advance the development of novel neuroscience-informed interventions to improve the lives of Veterans with schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: SOUTHERN ARIZONA VA HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Spinal cord injury (SCI) is a debilitating condition without meaningful treatment. The Department of Veterans Affairs provides care and disability compensation for over 42,000 veterans suffering from SCI, with the annual healthcare cost for SCI victims being 6.5 times greater than that of the average veteran. Treatment of SCI involves intensive care immediately following injury, as well as rehabilitation and treatment for any resulting complications. Unfortunately, recovery post-SCI often plateaus after about 12 months. The reason behind the development of this plateau phase is not fully understood. If the plateau phase could be prevented or reversed, perhaps continual recovery following injury could be possible. The proposed studies will attempt to address this gap in knowledge, which could prove beneficial for not only the patients themselves, but also for the healthcare system in general.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Heart failure is the number reason for admission among patients in the Veteran (VA) health system without cure, consuming a significant portion of VA medical resources. This proposal is to test a hypothesis that targeting UCH-L1, a deubiquitinating enzyme, is a novel approach for the treatment of heart failure and circulating UCH-L1 serves as novel biomarker of heart failure. The outcome will pave the way for translational studies of targeting UCH-L1 to treat and manage cardiac disease and heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Overall - Interaction of external inputs with internal dynamics:  influence of brain states on neural computation and behavior  Project Narrative Neural activity in the brain is thought to give rise to the entirety of our mental lives, including sensation, perception, cognition, deliberation and action. The proposed research seeks to establish a fundamental understanding of how the activity of populations of neurons reflect these processes, on a moment by moment basis and with quantitative rigor, to help establish a principled theory of the relation between internal neural states and our mental lives. Thus this research will lead to a deeper understanding of the function and dysfunction of the central nervous system, and ultimately contribute to the ability to diagnose and treat neuropsychiatric disease and injury. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE  The human lung is widely innervated, and yet how signals from the lung impact the nervous system and how signals from the nervous system impact lung function is poorly understood. In this study, we will test the property and function of a newly uncovered neural circuit that senses aerosol signals such as allergen in lung, transmits it to the brain, and then back to the lung to control airway constriction. Given that increased airway constriction is a key feature of asthma exacerbation, our findings will provide insights into the use of neural modulation as a novel therapeutic option for treating airway diseases such as asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human milk oligosaccharides assist in promoting the healthy development of the brain, gut, and immune system of infants and are produced in an infant-specific manner where biological responses drive their structures. Unfortunately, existing analytical methodologies remain limited in fully separating all their isomeric permutations, thus precluding their accurate structural characterization. To address these challenges, we will develop a bioanalytical workflow consisting of a new multidimensional separations platform to be used in conjunction with the development of chemical probes and gas-phase sequencing strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Military spouses report higher levels of alcohol misuse and mental disorders than their civilian counterparts and these rates are higher when they are in a relationship with a service member with alcohol misuse. Partners Connect intervenes with the concerned partner (CP) to support them in effectively communicating with their service member to encourage service member help seeking behaviors for alcohol abuse disorders. A two- stage SMART trial will reveal how to address the wide range of symptoms CPs present with by evaluating what additional intervention helps increase service member help-seeking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Genomic organization in the 3-dimensional nuclear space emerges as a new epigenetic regulator of transcriptional specificity that affects various developmental processes. The olfactory system provides an ideal system for deciphering, in vivo, the developmental intermediates of genomic compartmentalization and for obtaining structural insight into compartments with critical roles in neuronal gene regulation. Importantly, by revealing that genomic compartments dissipate in a humanized model of Alzheimer’s disease, not only do we explain the long-standing puzzle of olfactory deficits as a prodromal symptom of neurodegeneration, but we also open new routes for prognoses and pharmaceutical screens based on nuclear architecture perturbations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: 8. Project narrative The assembly of tissues and organs during embryonic development and their subsequent maintenance for decades are remarkable processes, requiring cells to choose appropriate cell fates via cell-cell communication, stably adhere to one another, yet also be able to change shape and move. Defects in cell communication or cell adhesion underlie certain birth defects, while inappropriate activation of cell signaling, as occurs after mutation of the tumor suppressor APC, drives colon and other cancers, and altered adhesion and motility underlie cancer metastasis. We have developed model systems using both the fruit fly Drosophila and in cultured mammalian cells to define the molecular basis of these remarkable properties during normal development and how they go wrong in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), which causes a severe lung disease named COVID-19, has spread out of control worldwide and is causing severe illness and death partly due to its relatively high transmission rates and infectivity. Highly effective vaccines have been developed in record time; however, new SARS-CoV-2 variants have appeared recently with mutations that correlate with higher infection rates and the ability to escape specific immunity, causing major concerns. The goal of this proposal is to understand the mechanisms that mediate SARS-CoV-2 virus entry and immune escape leading to high infectivity and pathogenesis, by manipulating the host ubiquitin system, and identify host factors that can be targeted for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Advances in lightsheet technology have spurred important discoveries in biology, both in health and disease. However, current methods have limitations in acquisition speed, spatial resolution, and the number of possible labels that can be imaged which restrict the types of biological questions that can be addressed. Through this proposal we will develop new user-friendly imaging modalities that will not only improve the spatiotemporal resolution of the current state-of-the-art but will also enable classification of 12+ different cell types in tissue that is cleared for large millimeter sized volumes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Studies show large disparities in alcohol-involved sexual assault in bisexual women (BW) compared to heterosexual women. Research into the underlying factors that can explain these inequalities constitutes a critical area for public health. The proposed research will use multiple methods and datasets to identify modifiable determinants of alcohol-involved sexual assault within BW across the lifespan that can be used to inform public health interventions that reduce alcohol-involved sexual assaults in this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: SOUTH TEXAS VETERANS HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Parkinson’s disease (PD) is a common disorder among the elderly. PD is progressive and therefore with time increases costs of healthcare and financial and emotional burden to the caretakers. As the world's population ages, PD is a growing concern. Current therapies alleviate the symptoms, but do not stop the progress of the disease. Our macrophage-mediated GDNF delivery may realize the neuroprotective and neurorestorative effects of this molecule, leading to a long-sought treatment for PD patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Depression is the leading cause of disability worldwide and prevalent in veterans, and current treatments rely on an inefficient trial and error approach for prescribing treatment that is not based on objective biological tests. Better understanding of how changes in the brain are related to symptoms of depression is necessary to develop more targeted treatments. The role of the corticostriatal circuit in approach and avoidance behavior is well characterized in human and animal models, and implicated in symptoms of depression. This proposal tests whether a marker of approach behavior, value-based attentional capture, is a sensitive readout of corticostriatal dysfunction in depression. Brain imaging, brain stimulation, and computational modeling will be used to characterize neurobiobehavioral substrates of depression, with the long term goal of furthering development of novel brain stimulation interventions targeting specific brain circuitry and depressive symptoms.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Sepsis strikes 750,000 Americans every year; most of these patients will survive the acute stage of sepsis only to end up back in the ICU, weeks later, with hospital-acquired infections. The objective of this competitive renewal is to study how changing the “starting point” of the immune system (i.e., mature, adult-like immune system of ‘dirty’ mice that have experienced physiological microbial exposure vs. naïve, neonate-like immune system of SPF mice) influences the magnitude of the acute innate immune response to a septic event. We will also be using a human microbiota-associated mouse model that allows transfer of human microbiota to a fully developed mouse to investigate how intestinal microbiota dysfunction during sepsis affects the magnitude of the innate immune response and promotes increased incidence of late-onset mortality.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Missed diagnosis of child abuse, in which abusive injury goes unrecognized or is misattributed to accidental trauma, is among the gravest examples of pediatric diagnostic error. At the same time, there are striking disparities in child abuse evaluation. To lay the groundwork for improved accuracy and equity of abuse diagnosis in pediatric primary care, the objectives of this proposal are to 1) identify markers of abuse in primary care EHR data, 2) characterize clinician diagnostic-process failure modes using EHR-based simulation, and 3) develop and prioritize strategies for improving primary care diagnosis of abuse.

PROJECT_TITLE: Averting Diagnostic Error Through Improved Recognition of Child Abuse

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a cause of significant morbidity amongst veterans. Experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) is a well-established mouse model for MS. In prior studies, we have found a novel immune suppressive role for central nervous system myelin antigen-targeted CD8+ immune T cells (CNS- CD8), which can protect against EAE, halt EAE progression, and reverse ongoing EAE. In the proposed studies, we will dissect the mechanisms of such CNS-CD8-mediated disease suppression and investigate novel approaches for activating and enhancing this population with the goal of developing innovative treatment strategies for this disease and providing important insights into an overlooked area of MS immunology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT RELEVANCE: We propose to optimize and validate an AI-enabled Digital Pathology Platform (ADAPT) for multi-cancer diagnosis, prognosis and prediction of therapeutic benefit. By integrating the AI- pathomic tools within PathPresenter, a widely used digital pathology image analysis platform, ADAPT will have a global footprint for the prognostic and predictive tools. ADAPT will be validated in the context of estrogen receptor positive (ER+) and triple negative (TN) breast cancer, oral cavity squamous cell carcinoma (OC-SCC), and prostate cancer for (1) prognosticating recurrence, (2) predicting pathologic complete response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy, (3) predicting benefit of adjuvant chemotherapy and radiotherapy as well as for (4) identifying individuals in whom radiation therapy can be de-intensified, respectively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Progressive resistance exercise has been shown as an effective therapy for many neurological disorders but has never been studied in patients with dystonia. The current study will employ functional MRI and TMS techniques to understand whether there are significant brain adaptation effects specific to dystonia pathophysiology in response to progressive resistance exercise in dystonia. The outcome of these studies will advance our understanding of pathophysiological underpinnings, which is critical for the initiation of a large scale clinical trial in patients with dystonia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The T35 Northwestern Summer Research Program for Medical Students provides an academically rich and fertile environment at the Feinberg School of Medicine, Northwestern University (NU), for 8 academically promising students interested in basic, translational and outcomes research in the NIDDK areas of interest from five participating medical schools in the Chicago metropolitan area (NU, Loyola, University of Chicago, University of Illinois, Rosalind Franklin). It provides a highly didactic 8-weeks of hands-on experience in the lab with mentorship from predominantly NIDDK-funded researchers that includes daily T35 Lunch Lectures, weekly T35 Trainee Meetings with the PD, a T35 Retreat with a NIDDK funded Visiting Professor and a Poster Session at the end of the summer. The program emphasizes the recruitment of students from underrepresented minorities and women, encourages the continuation of research after the T35 summer and will mentor students in a structured format until graduation and beyond, paving a path for medical students, especially URM and women, to become the next generation of clinician-scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed project targets reduction in mortality and morbidity from skin cancer via advancement of improved informatics tools to improve artificial intelligence development and clinical education for skin detection. Multi-modal International Skin Imaging Collaboration (M-ISIC) archive will advance machine learning and computer vision informatics tools to support large-scale multimodal ingestion, organization, registration, and curation of skin images and metadata datasets to improve skin cancer detection. With its open-source tools for automatic data quality control, ingestion, organization and curation, the M-ISIC archive will support the education of medical professionals and the development and clinical testing of automated diagnostic systems and eventually supporting flexible clinical translation of AI algorithms.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic rhinosinusitis is a disease of the sinonasal airways that causes significant morbidity and economic burden but for which the etiology is unknown. In this proposal, I seek to define causative mechanisms for this disease through defining alterations in the structure and function of the nasal submucosal glands, as well as key regulators of glandular development and remodeling in both mice and humans. Outcomes from this study will enable the design of therapeutics for the treatment and cure of this chronic and debilitating disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Dynamic changes in the 3D epigenomic landscape during corticogenesis remain mostly unexplored. We aim to identify the differences in 3D regulatory chromatin loops in six cell types from the prefrontal cortex across three critical developmental stages: third trimester, neonatal/infancy, and adolescence ages and interrogate the relationship between neuropsychiatric diseases associated variants and their target genes via chromatin loops. Our plan will generate a precious resource and reveal new insight into 3D chromatin architecture in human brain development and diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative According to a recent UNAIDS report, alcohol use is an overlooked factor in the HIV epidemic that requires greater attention. My proposed research will estimate the long-term, population impact of harmful alcohol use on HIV transmission and mortality, and will assess the value for money of investing in alcohol use interventions to reduce HIV transmission in the UTT era in Uganda. As countries in Sub-Saharan Africa seek to end the HIV epidemic, my research could provide impactful information for policymakers on integrating alcohol and HIV strategies and resource allocation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While there has been a significant increase in the uptake of antiretroviral therapy among women living with HIV (WLHIV) in many low- and-middle income countries (LMICs), the coverage of cervical cancer screening and, treatment among WLHIV remains low. In this study, we aim to leverage the available infrastructure for HIV care and treatment programs in Nigeria to integrate cervical cancer screening and treatment and conduct a cluster randomized, hybrid type III trial design to assess the comparative effectiveness of a Core set of implementation strategies versus a Core+ (enhanced) set of implementation strategies to implement cervical cancer screening, onsite treatment, referral and referral completion, treatment, and retention in care among WLHIV. The overarching goal is to improve the health and life expectancy of WLHIV with co-occurring cervical cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plasmids are engineered pieces of DNA that are used for biological research and for manufacturing biologic drugs and therapeutics. Despite the central importance of plasmids to biomedical research and development, the scientific community does not have a standardized, validated and secure infrastructure for associating the physical DNA molecules with the electronic records that describe them. We are proposing to develop a new digital certificate technology that will permanently label the DNA molecules themselves with an identifier that will connect them to standardized electronic documents describing their sequence, function, history, and other essential information allowing scientists to use them in a reproducible, safe, and secure manner.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Infection with H. pylori affects almost 4.4 billion people world-wide. According to the World Health Organization, National Cancer Institute, and epidemiological data, individuals with chronic H. pylori infection carry a 6-fold higher risk of developing gastric cancer. Recent studies of U.S soldiers deployed to the Middle East and Far East have shown that the incidence of H. pylori infection was 7.3 percent per year compared to 2.5 percent of U.S. military recruits living at home, which represents a major increase in risk. We will investigate molecular factors that promote H. pylori-induced inflammation and oncogenic signaling, leading to the development of gastric cancer. Our results will have a strong impact on understanding the biology and could have a potential role in the preventive, early diagnosis, and possibly therapeutic interventions in gastric cancer.

PHR: OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recognizing that one of the greatest areas of need for pancreatic cancer patients is the rapid translation of therapies to the clinic, our Tissue Procurement, Pathology, and Genomics Core and Integrative Quantitative Sciences Core work seamlessly with the projects to process and analyze data from each of the projects and for the Selective Targeting of Pancreatic (SToP) Cancer SPORE as a whole. Thus the foremost goal of our SToP Cancer SPORE is to establish a new paradigm for clinical trial design based on cutting edge research that is not isolated to a single therapy or biomarker.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Public Health Relevance  Our immediate goal is to develop a tool for quantitative, high-speed endoscopy via anatomic optical coherence tomography (aOCT) that eliminates radiation exposure for evaluation of infants and children with subglottic stenosis, a life-threatening upper airway disorder. The tool will be developed as part of an individualized pipeline to model each subject’s airway, simulate surgery, and predict surgical outcomes to better inform surgical decision-making. Our long-term goals are to validate this approach clinically at multiple institutions, to evaluate the ability of these methods to improve outcomes, and to extend our methods to study other common airway diseases in children and adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT 1: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is characterized by KRAS-dependent tumorigenic growth. We recently determined that the treatment of PDAC with inhibitors of the key KRAS effector pathway, the RAF-MEK- ERK mitogenic activated protein kinase cascade, unexpectedly caused further elevation of the metabolic process autophagy, rendering PDAC acutely dependent on autophagy, and hypersensitive to autophagy inhibition. We propose studies to facilitate further clinical advancement of novel combination anti-autophagy strategies with the goal of identifying effective treatments for PDAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it seeks to establish the efficacy of an innovative and scalable intervention to addresses two prevalent and debilitating conditions, falls and urinary incontinence, which together affect 1 in 2 older adult women. Successful completion of this project has the potential to significantly decrease the substantial morbidity that results from these two conditions in community-dwelling women and thus is relevant to the NIH’s mission to enhance health and reduce disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: In this grant we will structurally characterize HIV-1 glycan shield targeting Fab-dimerized glycan reactive (FDG) antibodies. The overall goals of this study are to define atomic level structures of novel FDG antibodies in complex with their HIV-1 Env epitopes, to elucidate the structural determinants of FDG antibody evolution, and to determine the structural basis for FDG antibody recognition of diverse Coronavirus (CoV) spikes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT 2: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have had success in treating patients with hematological malignancies by using their own immune cells modified with a chimeric molecule that eliminates tumor cells but spare part of the immune B-lymphocytes. We are now extending this approach to solid tumors such as pancreatic cancer that remains a tumor with poor prognosis. In this project we intend test in a Phase I clinical trial the safety, persistence and in vivo functionality of these cells that have been modified to persist target an antigen expressed by pancreatic cancer cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spina bifida (SB) is the most common cause of lifelong childhood paralysis, which results from the incomplete closure of the neural tube and overlying spine during fetal development. Patients require life-long treatment as they navigate lifelong paralysis, cognitive disabilities, musculoskeletal deformities, and bowel and bladder dysfunction. We aim to develop a novel engineered hydrogel system for local and sustained neuroprotection to be used in conjunction with a bone scaffold, thus resulting in an optimal combination scaffold as a long-term therapy for the in utero treatment of SB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Three redundant proteins, the YTHDF proteins, share the unique function to degrade mRNAs marked with a specific chemical modification called m6A. However, it’s been challenging understanding how this process is regulated. Using innovative technologies, I propose to study how these YTHDF proteins are dynamically regulated to control the degradation of m6A-marked mRNAs and the impact of this mechanism in hematopoietic stem cells differentiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE MDM2 and its numerous isoforms are key regulators of the expression and function of the p53 gene, a critical tumor suppressor that prevents inappropriate cell growth and proliferation. The proposed research will study the molecular connection between DNA damage, MDM2 isoform switching, p53, and cancer. Unraveling this pathway could lead to the discovery of novel therapeutic intervention points and thus be a crucial stepping-stone for cancer drug discovery.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE AIDS is one of the largest pandemics in history that remarkably, in the 40 years since its first description, the etiologic agent was identified, accurate tests to detect its presence were created, and over 30 novel drugs developed. This has turned a universally fatal disease into a chronic, manageable condition. Owing to the rapid emergence of both the disease and its treatment, many unanswered questions regarding the long-term outcomes of patients remain proving that ongoing research is needed to help answer these questions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: CORE C: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Integrated Quantitative Sciences Core participates in the design of all clinical trials, animal studies, and translational research proposed in the SPORE to ensure that all relevant studies are well powered, utilize appropriate statistical methods, and are properly designed to address relevant hypotheses of study aims. In this manner the Core supports the rigor and reproducibility of all results that are generated by the SPORE, which in turn has significant impacts in the fields of public health and medicine. Expert analysis of project data and clear reporting of scientific results are of similar importance for addressing scientific hypotheses and similarly have strong implications in public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Transfusion of Prematures (TOP) Trial randomized 1,824 preterm infants to liberal or restrictive red blood cell transfusions in order to determine which practice might be best for neurodevelopmental outcomes at 2 years. The current “TOP 5 Study” will assess functional neurodevelopmental outcomes of TOP subjects at 5 years of age, an age which will permit detailed assessment of cognitive skills, motor coordination, emotional/behavioral development, and academic readiness. Evaluating which approach to transfusion minimizes damage to vulnerable neuronal circuits is expected to have a significant impact on the clinical management of preterm infants and, in turn, improve both short and long-term outcomes for premature infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This study will demonstrate the efficacy of a perturbation training intervention to reduce postoperative falls after total knee arthroplasty. Osteoarthritis is a risk factor for preoperative and postoperative falls and people with endstage osteoarthritis undergoing joint replacement are at particular risk for injurious falls. The proposed research is relevant to public health because falls are a major public health issue for older adults, including the over 750,000 who receive total knee arthroplasty each year.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diacetyl is a highly toxic chemical found in many foods and drinks. This proposal will critically examine the role of airway stem cells in diacetyl-induced lung disease in order to identify new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The human immune system has evolved in response to selective pressures exerted by a range of viral pathogens. This project aims to determine the role of herpes simplex viruses in influencing and adapting to evolutionary changes in the host cell antiviral protein MxB. More generally, the results of these experiments will contribute to our understanding of the risks and barriers to cross species viral transmission events.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: It is estimated that 1 in 4 current Veterans Affairs medical system users suffers from cardiovascular disease (CVD). The most common form of CVD is atherosclerosis, or hardening of the arteries. Despite advances in treatment, deaths due to CVD equal approximately 1 million Americans annually, making it the leading cause of mortality in both the Veteran and general population. Understanding the mechanisms of CVD so that new, more efficient therapies can be identified is imperative. This proposal seeks to understand how the immune response to oxidized lipoproteins, that form during atherosclerosis, affects disease progression. We also ask the important question of whether sex is a determining factor for these immune responses. With the increase in female Veterans (approximately 9% of total Veteran population), it is necessary to understand the role that sex plays in atherosclerosis. It is the ultimate goal of this research to define immune-mediated mechanisms of CVD so that new therapeutic targets can be identified.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Clinical evidence coupled with experience in contemporary military arenas clearly indicates that traumatic brain injury (TBI) is becoming a signature injury of war which makes our troops a high-risk population. In fact 6.7% of OEF/OIF veterans in 2009 were diagnosed with TBI and 73% of those were diagnosed with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). At present there is no approved treatment for TBI due to an incomplete understanding of the underlying pathobiology. This proposal examines the potential of targeting mitochondrial biogenesis and push forward the repurposing of the FDA approved drugs formoterol and lasmiditan to limit the brain damage and dysfunction resulting from TBI.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hospitalized children suffer harm from medical errors at a rate three times that of adults and depend on clinicians to partner with their families to improve patient safety. Sharing doctors’ notes, which detail their diagnoses, treatment and contingency plans, has prompted adult outpatients to identify safety concerns, over half of which resulted in changes of care. Extending this work to hospitals, the objective of this proposed research is to design an intervention, BedsideNotes, to share doctors’ inpatient notes with families at the bedside to engage them in the care of their hospitalized child and partner with them to prevent harm.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: BedsideNotes: Engaging families to improve pediatric safety

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: SOUTH TEXAS VETERANS HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Exposure to risk factors such as stress or inflammation has been shown to be an important predisposing factor to psychiatric disorders and suicide. However, many individuals exposed to adversity maintain normal psychological functioning, and the factors underlying resistance to the deleterious effects of stress remain unknown. We propose that BDNF functions as a modulator non-neuronal cells responsible for neuroinflammation and kynurenine metabolism in brain, and that it is through this mechanism that BDNF confers resilience to stress.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertension and cardiovascular disease are conditions that are devastating and for which there are no curative therapies. Hypertension is the most common risk factor for the development of cardiovascular disease, which is the leading cause of death for United States Veterans. This project seeks to understand how inflammation causes blood vessel and kidney damage in hypertension. The discoveries form this study will lead to new therapeutic targets to combat this escalating health epidemic in the United States Veteran population.

PHR: Speech perception, how one hears speech sound sequences and associated stress patterns, is specific for native speakers of a language. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: To ensure the relevance and high quality of NIGMS research, it is essential that senior scientists are satisfied with, and thriving in, their careers and their future, and are an adequate representation of our society according to gender, race/ethnicity, economic, and cultural background. If our leaders and role models are diverse, we stand to benefit from enrichment of the pool of future investigators, broader perspective in research agenda prioritization, greater success in recruiting diverse research participants, and ultimately enhanced ability to reduce health disparities. By providing intensive training to overcome the final transition barrier to attaining science leadership, we will support the goal of NIGMS and of NIH to achieve sustainable transformation in scientific workforce diversity at all levels, including the most senior one.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioma has been associated with a number of infections. We will examine antigen reactivity to all infections previously linked with glioma to assess the risk and survival associated with each of these infections and groups of co-infections. We will then sequence an area of the genome that controls immune response to determine which genetic alterations interact with infections, and how infections and genetics together alter risk and survival of glioma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Helminth parasites infect approximately 2 billion people worldwide and represent a significant public health and economic challenge. While multiple studies have revealed the mechanisms that promote helminth-induced inflammation, the factors that restrict these responses to prevent unwanted tissue damage remain poorly defined. This proposal will investigate the existence of a neuropeptide-mediated rheostat that functions to properly regulate helminth-induced inflammation and promote optimal outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cohesin generates and maintains the chromatin loops that serve as a fundamental unit of 3D genome organization. Cohesin is frequently mutated in GBM, the most common and deadly tumor of the brain, with STAG2 as its most frequently mutated subunit. This grant proposes to identify the mechanistic connection between STAG2 mutations and alterations in 3D genome organization in GBM cells and tumors, providing a long-sought molecular mechanism for cohesin-mediated tumor suppression, with the goal of defining how cohesin can be targeted for therapeutic purposes in GBM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Unlike the static, double-helical structure of DNA depicted in textbooks, sculpture, and art, the DNA of living cells is dynamic—winding and unwinding to allow its duplication and repair. Many antibiotic and anticancer drugs target enzymes that bind to DNA only in underwound or overwound states, yet the impact of DNA winding has been largely ignored because the tools to address it properly in experiments did not exist. To remedy this, we invented methods to create DNA as it exists in living cells and propose to study how these drugs work and find new drugs for infections, cancer, and neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Adipose tissue is increasingly recognized for its impact on energy expenditure, glucose and fat metabolism and is under sympathetic control. This brain-to-fat circuit has not been explored in its full extent, and specifically pre-and postganglionic neurons innervating distinct brown and white adipose tissue depots are largely unexplored. Here we propose to use the modern toolbox of neuron-specific manipulation to directly stimulate and inhibit postganglionic neurons for select adipose tissues and their interaction in metabolic control. This project is using a new brain-to-fat experimental approach that aims to integrate findings from brain circuits and adipose tissue research to generate a circuit model that is able to predict metabolic adaptations in diverse physiological states.
