IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Environmental signals that influence brain function and development play critical roles in the neural basis of mental disease. Light has long been recognized as a powerful environmental influence on specific brain regions, and we have recently demonstrated that circadian photoperiodic light cycles persistently alter the function of the brain’s serotonin neurons along with depressive and anxiety-like behaviors. Here, we will combine electrophysiological, molecular, and behavioral experiments to examine how circadian photoperiodic light exposure programs serotonin/glutamate neurons of the dorsal raphe nucleus through the modulation of the ion channel TREK-1, and exerts downstream influence on dopaminergic and glutamatergic circuits in the nucleus accumbens relevant to anxiety, depression, and reward-based behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative Membraneless organelles are an essential component of life, and are composed of many types of proteins and nucleic acids. Their function is related to the total and relative concentrations of each component, and regulated by external factors. Using computational molecular physics, we will study how interactions between molecules are predictive of compositions of membraneless organelles, and how external stimuli regulate these interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adipose tissue contains a network of immune cells that help maintain normal adipose tissue function, and obesity triggers adipose tissue inflammation that is associated with metabolic dysfunctions, such as type 2 diabetes. The signals and drivers required for the promotion of obesity-associated adipose tissue inflammation are unknown. This proposal seeks to identify the mechanisms involved in the initiation of adipose tissue T cell activation in early and late stages of obesity.

PHR: Research training is crucial for medical students because they need to observe and experience how modest contributions in the field of aging research interventions can bring about profound changes and can advance health care delivery and improve quality of life for older adults and their caregivers. We believe that participation of medical student trainees in a highly structured and mentored training program in aging research provides a positive introduction to the field and will lead many to leadership careers as clinician-scientists, assume academic leadership positions and serve as tireless advocates for older adults' overall well-being and care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Narrative The work proposed in this study will determine the role of the abhydrolase domain containing 17B depalmitoylase (ABHD17B), a previous un-recognized enzyme in mammals, in the development of diet-induced inflammation and abdominal obesity, which will illuminate the molecular signaling pathways underlying the well-established connection between obesity and metabolic disease. Understanding the molecular mechanism of ABHD17B action and its role in mediating the anti-inflammatory function of adiponectin will provide unique insight into targetable pathways for therapy development. With rapid growth of an epidemic of obesity, the development of novel therapeutic approaches to obesity-related diseases is highly relevant to public health and to the NIH mission.

PHR: Project narrative This K43 describes a career development plan for Dr Batte over 5 years to receive mentored research training, undertake critical courses and training to develop into an independent researcher. Dr Batte will delineate the mechanisms of kidney-related brain injury in severe malaria by determining the extent that AKI phenotypes are associated with biosignatures of brain injury and recovery. Further, Dr Batte will establish the extent that AKI and AKI phenotypes are associated with cerebral edema, and in addition define the association between neurobehavioral outcomes, brain injury biomarkers and AKI phenotypes

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Atrial Fibrillation is the most common type of cardiac arrhythmia in clinical practice, with a projected rise in prevalence and increased economic burden due to its complications. Our proposed studies will help determine how transcription factors regulate cardiac excitability, advancing our mechanistic understanding of the genetic susceptibility to cardiac arrhythmias. This project is relevant to the NIH mission because it will lay the foundation for future development of new therapeutic approaches to atrial fibrillation

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stress urinary incontinence is the most common female pelvic floor disorder encountered in clinical practice with significant negative impact on quality of life. The prevalence of urinary incontinence increases with aging, and weakness of the pelvic floor muscles contributes to the development of stress urinary incontinence. Given that androgen receptors are expressed throughout the pelvic floor, the anabolic effects of androgens on pelvic floor muscles may provide a therapeutic option in women with stress urinary incontinence. We propose a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled proof-of-concept trial in older postmenopausal women with stress urinary incontinence to assess whether testosterone therapy can increase pelvic floor muscles and improve urinary function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) leads to more cancer death annually than any other cancer, and despite the landmark approval of anti-PD-1 therapy for NSCLC, the majority of patients still have progressive disease. The IL-6/STAT3 pathway has been identified in association with decreased response to anti-PD-1 therapy in NSCLC patients, but the mechanism by which IL-6 leads to anti-PD-1 resistance is poorly understood. This proposed study will advance our basic understanding of IL-6-mediated anti-PD-1 resistance, and inform future combination therapy development in NSCLC for patients that have not responded to anti-PD-1 therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Because Emergency Medical System providers (EMS) are first to arrive at the scene of an overdose and are critical partners in care for people who use drugs, we partnered with them, people who use drugs, and EMS leadership to collect pilot data and then co-design EMS-delivered interventions to reduce stigma and increase access to care for people who use drugs. These interventions are being rolled out as the EMS Overdose Prevention Project (EMS-OPP), and hold great potential to reduce racial disparities in access to evidence-based medical services and to improve long-term outcomes. Guided by Public Health Critical Race Praxis, we will study the impact of EMS-OPP on the experiences and outcomes of EMS encounters for overdose survivors who are Black, Hispanic/Latinx and American Indian/Alaskan Native to inform future policy and interventions to improve equitable care. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Fuchs corneal endothelial dystrophy (FECD) is a blinding disease that affects millions of people each  year in the United States. Corneal transplantation is the common treatment for this condition. In the  current proposal, I outline experiments to identify and characterize the molecular mechanisms that lead to  disease progression in FECD with the objective of identifying therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Diversifying the biomedical workforce is imperative to meet the healthcare needs of the U.S. population. We will build on our established longitudinal panel of Black and Hispanic science majors to test the long-term effectiveness of two widely utilized interventions: undergraduate research experience and faculty mentorship. Results will inform best practice for these large- scale interventions in training the next generation of diverse biomedical researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Filarial nematodes, Brugia malayi, B. timori, and Wuchereria bancrofti, cause lymphatic filariasis that affects millions of people in the tropical regions of the world. The chronic infections result in characteristic painful swelling of the limbs (elephantiasis) and later lymphedema of the genitals. The associated irreversible physical disability and profound disfiguring cause substantial economic, social, and psychological damage. Mass drug treatment with anthelmintic medicines is recommended to interrupt the transmission cycle of filarial infection. Chemotherapy effectively clears microfilariae from the host and suppresses their reappearance, but they have limited adulticidal activity. Inhibitory GABA-gated chloride channels present at the neuromuscular junction of nematodes are a vital mediator of locomotion. They serve as a target for only one nematocidal compound, piperazine, and have not been explored in filarial nematodes. unc-49 encodes for a GABA receptor in nematodes that mediates contralateral body muscle inhibition during locomotion. UNC-49 GABA channel has been characterized from Caenorhabditis elegans and Haemonchus contortus. These receptors are pharmacologically distinct from vertebrate channels and display species-based diversity. We will explore the biological significance and potential of Bma-UNC-49 channels as a novel drug target. This project will characterize the filarial UNC-49 receptors providing a better understanding of its pharmacology and the molecular basis of the activity of selective GABA channels. This proposal will have implications for identifying the molecular basis of the activity of GABA channel activators, exploring selective drugs, and contributing to the development of novel macrofilaricidal compounds in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because acquired brain injuries, such as stroke, leave many Americans with chronic motor disabilities, requiring long-term care. This project seeks to understand the role that premotor cortex, an area suggested to be involved in functional recovery, plays in motor rehabilitation following acquired brain injuries. The results will provide critical information needed to inform how rehabilitative strategies alter brain structure and function and ultimately leading to novel therapies and improved motor outcomes following stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Given the strong link between education and health, improving schools and educational outcomes may be a potentially effective public health intervention. In 2013, we initiated a longitudinal natural experiment to study the impact of exposure to high-performing schools on adolescent health and found significant improvements in self-reported health among males, but worse health among females. We propose to continue this cohort study and follow subjects through age 28, examining males and females in physiologic health outcomes, stress, socioemotional factors, and resilience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Variants in the mitochondrial genome cause a range of disease in humans, ranging from severe pediatric syndromes to aging-related disease. Unlike the nuclear genome, the mitochondrial genome is present in hundreds to thousands of copies in a cell and hence, a cell may contain mitochondrial genomes with and without a disease-causing variant. Our study will evaluate whether mitochondrial genetic variants differ across the tissues of the human body and whether those variants arose during development or later in life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative People with all stages of chronic kidney disease (CKD) are at increased risk of poor physical functioning, but the burden and risk factors for physical function decline and its relationship to clinical outcomes in adults with non-dialysis dependent CKD has been under-studied. We propose to inform CKD clinical practice by determining the prognostic importance of physical function over time among persons with CKD, including insights to risk factors of physical function decline, and building a clinical tool to monitor physical function that could guide treatment and prognostic decisions, while identifying patients most likely to need further services. Ultimately, the proposed study will guide how patients with CKD are monitored in clinical care, inform patient-centered treatments, and promote broad improvement in physical function for this high-risk population by catalyzing greater awareness and targeted interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project narrative: This study will test whether a brief, behavioral treatment program can help vulnerable youths struggling with depression and anxiety. A previous face-to-face version of this program was effective, and this study will test to see if the program works well when delivered in a telehealth format to families who are traditionally underserved by mental health. Results may help move effective treatments for these serious problems into widespread community practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Analysis, Visualization, and Informatics Lab-space (AnVIL) is a cloud-based computing platform that brings together genomics resources and broad access to genomics datasets to enhance collaboration across research teams. The AnVIL Clinical Environment for Innovation and Translation (ACE-IT) team will amplify the existing AnVIL platform by first engaging with diverse partners to characterize barriers to clinical genomics research on cloud environments integrating tools that enable clinical genomics research methods. The team will then work with existing AnVIL teams and partners to integrate diverse datasets and implement clinical genomics tools to support the rapidly evolving field of clinical and translational genomics research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative – Overall Melanoma is a devastating disease, with increasing incidence worldwide. Although remarkable progress has been made treating melanoma, more than 60% of patients do not achieve long-term benefit. The central goal of this program is to develop functional personalized combination therapies to combat tumors that are resistant to current therapies. These studies are possible because we have a large bank of >500 melanoma patient derived xenografts which have been characterized based on DNA- and RNA-sequencing, and protein expression. We aim at matching novel combination therapies with the right patient based on the individual tumor profile; the knowledge obtained from these studies will be critical to prioritize clinical testing of novel combination therapies to improve patient’s outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Male stress urinary incontinence (SUI), a frequent result of radical prostatectomy for prostate cancer, significantly reduces health-related quality of life among older men. Surgical treatment options are known to provide near-term improvement in quality of life with high satisfaction rates but are underutilized and patients have regret about treatment decisions. The goal of this K76 proposal is to improve goal-concordant treatment decisions for SUI management in older men by identifying disparities in surgical care and addressing these disparities by developing a geriatric-informed patient-centric decision support tool to promote individualized, goal-concordant decision-making for SUI treatment decisions among older men, which will then be tested in an R01 multi-institutional implementation-effectiveness trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Filoviruses, including Ebola virus and Marburg virus, are highly pathogenic viruses that cause hemorrhagic fever in humans with a case fatality rate up to 90%, with an unmet medical need for new agents to combat filovirus infections. This proposal is designed to develop a novel series of antibody drug conjugates (ADCs) that combine an efficacious pan-filovirus small molecule inhibitor with an efficacious bispecific pan-filovirus antibody (bNAb) to target entry of filoviruses with the potential for synergistic activity, broadening the therapeutic window and easing drug stockpiling efforts. The broad range of bNAbs, mAbs and small molecules available for conjugation provides a high probability of identifying a succeeding in identifying ADCs appropriate for preclinical development en route to effective pan-filovirus therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE It is increasingly becoming apparent that reproductive fitness has a major impact on the overall health and aging of the individual but little is known about the mechanisms underlying. This project utilizes the model nematode, C. elegans, to identify genes that determine how meiosis in germ cells influences overall aging. The research has relevance for human health and high public-health significance because human counterparts of genes being studied here have been implicated in human reproductive aging, so the findings from this work may help design therapies for age-related diseases, especially those pertaining to reproductive health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Epilepsy affects over 65 million people worldwide, yet roughly 30% of patients remain resistant to available antiseizure drugs. Newer, better tolerated, and more effective treatments are desperately needed, including agents that can prevent the development of epilepsy in at-risk individuals. This proposal will thus fully characterize the anticonvulsant and potentially disease-modifying potential of two promising candidate investigational treatments for epilepsy.

PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Humans are colonized with a large number of microorganisms, collectively known as the microbiota that provide us with key functions. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Latinx community (gender-inclusive term; includes Hispanics, Latino/a) bears a disproportionate burden of chronic kidney disease (CKD) and are less likely to start recommended kidney replacement therapy, such as kidney transplant or home dialysis, compared to non-Latinx Whites. NAVIGATE-Kidney is a multi-level, community-engaged, language and culturally concordant community health worker intervention for Latinx with advanced CKD, that will reduce kidney health disparities, and address structural racism. Results from this study will provide important research evidence for solutions to reduce kidney health disparities and inform local, state, and federal health policy changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Narrative We will build an end-to-end system to convert electronic health records (EHR) to Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR) with integrated machine learning models to explore multiple chronic diseases (MCC)’s impact on Alzheimer's disease. Partnering with ACTIVE MIND, an interventional trial that examines the potential efficacy of cognitive training (CT) in reducing dementia incidences, we will develop a demonstration project to promote the use of interoperable health records in clinical research by identifying and stratifying patients with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) who are at risk for developing Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Experiences of loneliness are prevalent among older adults living in the community. The proposed study aims to develop, deploy, and validate a smart speaker-based in-home loneliness assessment system for community-dwelling older adults. This study is highly relevant to public health as it explores the innovative use of commercially available digital technologies to enable a remote loneliness assessment for older adults, which will move assessment out of the clinic and into older adults’ everyday lives to identify lonely individuals early enough to intervene before negative health outcomes occur.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative As the burden of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias in the United States and worldwide is high, there is a critical and unmet clinical need to develop and translate novel positron emission tomography (PET) imaging tools to study neurodegeneration-related biological processes in the brain. This work will validate and translate key imaging ligands in humans designed to substantially advance our scientific understanding of subtype-specific N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor and its role in the pathophysiology and glutamatergic signaling transduction pathway of Alzheimer’s disease (AD), facilitating drug discovery of novel neurotherapeutics for AD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE. Extracellular vesicles and particles (EVPs) have emerged as important mediators β cell-immune cell interaction and β cell dysfunction and survival in type 1 diabetes (T1D). Here, we have assembled an interdisciplinary team to systematically examine the role of human islet/pancreas-associated EVPs in islet cell function and survival during T1D progression. This study will identify novel “biomarkers” for T1D diagnosis and pave the road to the development of new therapy strategies to treat and prevent the progression of T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE-PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Gonorrhea is the second most frequent reportable bacterial infectious disease in the US with a reported incidence of 696,764 cases in 2021, reflective of a steady increase in recent years. Because of under-reporting and symptomatic treatment, the real incidence is believed to be much greater. Worldwide incidence is now estimated at greater than 87 million new cases per annum. Untreated gonorrhea in women can lead to upper genital tract infection and pelvic inflammatory disease, with tubal scarring, infertility, and risk for ectopic pregnancy. It also increases the risk of acquisition and transmission of HIV up to 5-fold, for reasons that remain unclear. Because no vaccine is available, control and treatment depend upon antibiotics, but N. gonorrhoeae has steadily developed resistance to each class of antibiotics deployed against it, including fluoroquinolones and most recently even cephalosporins. Importantly, gonorrhea can be acquired repeatedly with no development of protective immunity, compounding the danger of emerging antibiotic resistance. This CRP proposal seeks to further the development of an intravaginally administered formulation of the key inflammatory cytokine interleukin-12 (GneX12) as a novel therapeutic vaccine against gonorrhea, to be used in conjunction with standard-of-care antibiotics, and as a failsafe therapeutic treatment against emerging super-resistant strains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose BossDB, an open, accessible, cloud-based data archive for storage of multi-petabyte, high reso- lution, volumetric electron microscopy and X-ray microtomography datasets, as well as new connectomics and neuroimaging search, querying, and data annotation capabilities. As a current BRAIN Initiative data archive of record, BossDB leverages a proven architecture to provide petascale-capable storage, processing, sharing, and visualization of the massive and complex data generated by the connectomics community. BossDB will revo- lutionize how researchers share, annotate, and analyze data through a standardized, highly-available interface and ecosystem interconnected with community tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lower respiratory infection and lung cancer are leading causes of death worldwide, with the COVID-19 global pandemic being an example of high lethality from lung disease. Alveolar type II (AT2) cells are the lung’s facultative stem cells that under normal conditions remain quiescent and assist with gas exchange, but in the case of acute lung injury, can execute and halt proliferation as needed to help regenerate tissue, while also being at risk for misregulated proliferation leading to lung adenocarcinoma. How AT2 cells fluctuate in and out of quiescence is unclear, therefore the goal of this proposal is to investigate the regulatory mechanism behind AT2 cell reversible activation to be applied in treatment of lethal lung injuries and cancer.

PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement HIV self-testing would benefit both high-risk populations unaware of their infection and individuals aware of their infection and under treatment. This project seeks to develop and validate an easy-to-use quantitative HIV self- testing device to allow lay individuals to perform HIV viral load measurement. Increasing access to routine viral load testing can significantly improve the health outcomes of people living with HIV and help to prevent the onward transmission of HIV towards ending AIDS as a public health threat.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Better methods are urgently needed to measure therapeutic response and detect early relapse, especially in acute myeloid leukemia (AML), where 50 percent of patients that have a complete response to initial treatment go on to relapse within 2 years. Current methods for measuring minimal residual disease in AML are not sensitive enough, do not apply to all patients, and do not fully capture the genetic heterogeneity of the disease. In this project, we propose that utilizing personalized genetic mutations associated with a patient’s leukemia will result in more sensitive, quantitative, and general measurements of minimal residual disease, allowing for better evaluation of treatment efficacy and earlier detection of relapse, ultimately improving patient outcome in AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Entrepreneurship has emerged as a potent economic force and can be an avenue to increase the number of research innovations. However, gender and underrepresented minority (URM) gaps in entrepreneurship have been documented, and only 11.8% of inventors in the US are women. We propose an entrepreneurship educational program for women, including URM women with a unique approach that combines mentoring with coaching, as coaching has been shown to be four times more effective than training or mentoring alone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: CALIFORNIA PACIFIC MED CTR RES INSTITUTE
PHR: Chronic hepatitis B virus infection (CHB) afflicts up to 2.2 million Americans, and up to 350 million people globally, causing early death in about 1 million people annually. In the “BeNEG-DO” grant we are studying an intervention aimed at safely stimulating immune-mediated clinical cures in patients with CHB by timed stoppage of standard- of-care medications, which rarely achieve cures. Initial data demonstrates that the intervention can work, but with some safety concerns. Continuation of the study will help identify patients likely to benefit from the intervention and those at risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to determine how post-stroke cognitive impairment moderates motor learning during walking in older adults with chronic stroke and identify brain structural markers that mediate this relationship. The chosen experimental design integrates biomechanical analyses, neuropsychological assessments, and brain imaging techniques to determine the impact of post-stroke cognitive impairment severity on two forms of motor learning (explicit and implicit) and examine the role of the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex in the relationship between cognition and explicit motor learning. Ultimately, this work may lead to the development of a more comprehensive, effective treatment approach to improve walking dysfunction in older adults post-stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Healthcare costs for falls have reached 55 billion dollars annually in the US with falls in older adults impacting nearly every family, in every sector, of every community. Leveraging 911 fall calls as activation events could transform our ability to identify high risk individuals and significantly impact fall prevention strategies. At the completion of this study, a scalable EMS fall prediction tool will be developed to elucidate the impact that frailty, cognitive impairment and the home environment have on emergency fall events in order to activate and transform effective fall prevention solutions in the homes of vulnerable older patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  Delirium, a major cause of falls, can occur in as many as 50% of cancer patients undergoing stem cell transplant,  resulting in up to 14 times greater chance of dying. Delirium risk can be mitigated and many other outcomes of  stem cell transplants can be improved through behavioral interventions delivered at the bedside through  conversation, imagery, and audio. care.coach™ is developing a technology-enabled cancer care platform that  provides 24x7 proactive bedside support for patients undergoing stem cell transplants, to mitigate delirium and  falls while improving recovery through better adherence to diet, exercise, and other best practices, in a scalable,  cost-effective manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Loss-of-function mutations in the DYRK1A gene have been tightly linked to neurodevelopmental disorders like autism spectrum disorders and intellectual disability. The research described in this proposal aims to uncover specific mechanisms by which DYRK1A influences the function of immature neural stem and progenitor cells in the developing brain and their commitment to specific neural identities. The results of our studies will identify potential therapeutic entry points for neurodevelopmental disorders by defining intracellular signaling pathways regulated by DYRK1A that can be modulated to restore normal brain function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative  Chronic pain represents a major public health problem disproportionately impacting older adults and an improved understanding of the neurobiological and psychosocial mechanisms underlying age-related changes in pain is critical to inform interventions aimed at reducing pain in the elderly. At present, there is a deficit of scientists trained to conduct clinical and translational research investigating pain and aging. In order to address this gap, we propose to continue our Integrative and Multidisciplinary Pain and Aging Research Training (IMPART) postdoctoral training program with the long-term goal of creating the next generation of pain and aging scientists who will move the field forward through cutting edge research designed to elucidate and ameliorate adverse age-related changes in the experience of pain.
PROJECT_TERMS: Aging;multidisciplinary;Pain;Research Training;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: the Integrative and Multidisciplinary Pain and Aging Research Training (IMPART) Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Correct synapse formation is essential for brain development and defects in that process underlie a host of neurodevelopmental defects and loss of synapses is an early hallmark of neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer's. This proposal seeks to understand the role of kinetochore proteins in the formation of synaptic terminals, dendrites, and dendritic spines. These proteins have never previously been implicated in any process other than cell division and the research, therefore, has the potential to expand our understanding of what shapes neuronal connections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RFA-CA-23-034 application entitled “Support for Registration Enabling Phase 3 Clinical Trial for Nanotechnology-Based Treatment of Carcinoma in Situ of the Oral Cavity (Stage 0 Oral Cancer)” Project Narrative: Privo’s Nanotechnology-Engineered PRV111 Transmucosal Delivery System delivers and retains high concentration of cisplatin directly in the tumor, with a safety and efficacy profile that has been proven through multiple sets of preclinical and a phase 1/2 clinical study in patients suffering from early-stage oral cancer. The treatment has been shown to be significantly safer and more effective than the standard of care, while demonstrating complete tumor regression in addition to maintaining a recurrence-free status for up to 36 months post-treatment. PRV111 administration does not require any specialized training and the treatment duration is ~10-15 minutes per patch application – with the funding from this proposal, Privo will conduct the registration enabling Phase 3 clinical trial to commercialize PRV111 and effectively eliminate the need for disfiguring surgery for Stage 0 oral cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Virulent phages play a major role in controlling the density of bacterial pathogens and, through a constant arms race, impact the evolution of pathogens. ICP3 is a virulent phage that preys on Vibrio cholerae within the human small intestine, and for which resistance is rarely observed. Here we will explore the genetic requirements of ICP3 for circumventing phage defense systems of V. cholerae.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to develop new cancer therapeutics that work by blocking the activity of the MYC oncogene. We have developed a revolutionary drug discovery platform that, for the first time, has enabled the screening and identification of promising small molecules that directly inhibit the cancer-promoting function of MYC. We will perform a series of in vitro and in vivo assessment of these hits to determine their suitability for progression towards a clinically relevant, novel, highly MYC-specific, and safe cancer therapy, which currently does not exist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Radiation therapy (RT) is generally considered safe and effective, but it is well known that deviations in treatment happen on a daily basis in a busy treatment facility, and these changes are prone to higher error rates. This project will fund the commercial readiness of a fundamentally new imaging system that allows the radiotherapy team to see the beam delivery on the patient’s tissue. It provides immediate feedback and review of treatments, to improve the quality of fractionated treatments by minimizing errors in daily delivery.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The overarching goal of the Emory-Nigeria HIV Research Training Program (EN-RTP) is to enhance the capacity and the quality of researchers focused on HIV health issues relevant to women in Nigeria. To accomplish this, we will leverage existing collaborations between Emory University and three partnering Nigerian institutions to enhance human resource capacity enrichment with long-, medium-, and short-term research training of Nigerian investigators, facilitating their acquisition of the skills needed to pursue research careers focused on women’s health and HIV/AIDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PointCheckTM is the first medical device that non-invasively detects immunosuppression resulting from cancer chemotherapy, without the need for a blood sample. It uses optics to image through the skin and enable self- administered and quick testing. Use of PointCheck in patients’ homes and outpatient cancer clinics will provide early detection and enable prompt medical care to prevent life-threatening infections in cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to utilize our human neuromuscular junction (NMJ) platform to replace the mouse lethality bioassay (MLB) currently used to determine potency of commercial batches of Botox. A high throughput platform will be validated and then submitted to the FDA for qualification. We will use nanotechnology and microelectronics in combination with biomedical engineering techniques to build these hybrid 3D biological/non- biological systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Prostate cancer is the second most commonly diagnosed cancer in men in the U.S. and is responsible for about 34,000 deaths and an economic toll of $13 billion each year. To treat men whose cancer has advanced to castration-resistant prostate cancer, Arma Bio is developing dual inhibitors of the full-length androgen receptor (AR-fl) and AR-V7, the most prevalent splice variant in men with this cancer. A dual inhibitor that can overcome drug resistance will offer a much-needed therapeutic option for men with castration-resistant prostate cancer, ultimately improving clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly two thirds of new cancer patients fail treatment due to resistance that is not fully understood. Aperture Bio’s single cell proteomics platform can provide rapid single-cell molecular analyses to enable improvements over current diagnostics, ultimately improving patient treatment options and outcomes. This project further develops and validates the proprietary technology in addition to producing new, proprietary analytical software to create a comprehensive tumor T cell panel, with the ultimate goal of ensuring that every lab can employ single cell methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: 1.b. PROJECT NARRATIVE. Cannabis, i.e., marijuana, is the most used drug substance in the United States, yet the illicit black market for cannabis-derived products continues to dominate sales in states where it is now legalized. Lack of policy coherence on cannabis legalization has led to unregulated new product introduction and illegal sales on the Internet, introducing the potential for consumer harm and threatening the business viability of legitimate and licensed cannabis providers. In response, the proposed project will leverage advanced methods in big data, machine learning, and data visualization to develop a multiplatform compliance solution to detect and report illegal online sellers of cannabis products.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The growing discovery of genomic loci associated with psychiatric disorders allows the generation of polygenic risk scores (PRS) which could help identify individuals at increased risk for a psychiatric disorder and potentially prevent or delay disease onset, and minimize morbidity and risk for suicide. However, the use of PRS in child and adolescent psychiatry, and its ethical and legal implications remain understudied. To promote responsible use of psychiatric PRS in children and adolescents, we will use a mixed-methods approach that includes qualitative, quantitative, and legal analysis to: 1) give voice to stakeholders (i.e., patients, parents/caregivers, clinicians) by examining their perspectives regarding whether psychiatric PRS should be used and, if so, how; and 2) examine the legal and regulatory landscape to identify what privacy and genetic discrimination safeguards may be necessary.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Heart failure (HF) is present in 5% of veterans, represents a major health and economic burden, with 80% of care costs attributable to hospitalizations. Reduction of HF readmissions has been identified as a major VA strategic goal. Remote monitoring has shown promise in reducing readmissions. In a pilot multicenter study, we demonstrated that remote monitoring using a small wearable sensor has a high compliance rate and provides accurate early detection of impending HF readmissions for HF. In this next step, we propose to implement non- invasive remote monitoring within the VA system with an algorithmic response to the device alert and an ongoing validation and update of the response algorithm as part of the learning health-care system concept. Furthermore, we will conduct a feasibility study of clinical efficacy. Our results will be directly applicable to care of HF patients and to designing remote monitoring strategies for chronic health conditions within and outside the VA system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: This project will contribute knowledge pertinent to the cause of excess risk of osteoporotic fractures in patients with insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus. We will obtain transilial bone biopsies from type-1 diabetics in which to measure content of known chemicals that weaken bones, and compare those same measurements in matched, normal, nondiabetic subjects. Since practitioners and pharmaceutical companies are not yet convinced of their importance, results from this project will encourage performance of the expensive clinical trials needed to provide agents that reduce fracture risk in diabetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Opioid Use Disorder (OUD) is a major public health concern in the United States with a record number of opioid-related deaths in 2020 and limited therapeutics for treatment. Discovery-based genetics combined with pharmacological and neurobiological approaches in rodent model organisms are critical for understanding molecular mechanisms underlying susceptibility to OUDs. Our project’s goal in understanding the genetic basis of oxycodone metabolism and addiction model behaviors through a multidisciplinary approach has direct translational relevance to humans and personalized medicine, both in opioid therapeutics and OUD treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In cancer research, the need for a diverse pool of researchers in statistics and data science has never been greater, but the requisite academic pipeline for training such a workforce remains inadequate. GROWS@FredHutch (Generating Research Opportunities Within Statistics at Fred Hutch) is a summer mentored research program for undergraduate students who identify as underrepresented minorities, and will include an engaging and supportive mentored research experience along with career development, community building, and social/emotional support activities to encourage students to (1) gain skills and confidence in cancer statistics and data science and (2) feel a sense of belonging and rightful place in the statistics and cancer research communities. The goal of GROWS will be to promote a diverse workforce to ensure that future cancer researchers will represent our broader community, including populations disproportionately impacted by cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is important to mediate the process of thrombus formation, which can stop bleeding after injury, but can also cause vascular occlusion in diseased blood vessels. We will develop multidisciplinary approaches to directly observe flow-induced shape change in VWF, and study its effects on the properties of VWF binding to its partners. This work will establish much-needed laboratory models for human bleeding disorders and thrombosis, and improve our fundamental understanding of how our bodies sense the physical world and respond in specific ways to prevent disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: If our hypothesis is true, we expect that the telomere biomarker will identify the subset of men who would be less likely to benefit from aggressive salvage therapy – either because their disease biology is such that their cancer would not have progressed irrespective of the use of aggressive salvage therapy or because their disease biology is such that their cancer would have progressed despite use of aggressive salvage therapy. Further, we expect that men not in either of these categories would be more likely to benefit from aggressive salvage therapy. Thus, if the telomere biomarker were incorporated into precision treatment decision-making, men in the first subset could be spared unnecessary treatment and side effects, while men in the latter subset would benefit from the use of aggressive salvage therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older adults are prone to changes in sleep and cognition as they get older, and it has been proposed that sleep and circadian disturbances increase the risk of cognitive decline and dementia. Understanding subtle alterations in circadian rhythm timing in adults at risk of dementia and how such disturbances relate to cognitive functioning will identify potential predictive or treatment targets in the circadian timing system to mitigate age-related cognitive decline. I will investigate: 1) differences in circadian timing among older adults with intact cognition, older adults with subjective cognitive decline, and older adults with mild cognitive impairment; 2) associations between circadian rhythm timing and cognitive functioning in these groups; and 3) whether stress, a modifiable lifestyle factor associated with sleep disturbances and risk of cognitive impairment, moderates the associations between circadian rhythm timing and cognition.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite great strides over the past decade, tools for genetic study and manipulation of Chlamydia spp. remain severely limited. This proposal will develop new and powerful genetic tools including tightly negatively regulated promoter expression systems, a Tn7-based single chromosomal insertion transgene system, and application of the latter to build new, smaller shuttle plasmids for transformation. Successful completion of these aims will enhance genetic studies in Chlamydia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The majority of children exposed to early adversity and trauma do not have access to sustainably delivered evidence-based mental health programs (EBPs), despite the growing prevalence of large-scale multiple-EBP implementation efforts aimed at increasing access to these services. The objective of this proposal is to develop and test a package of implementation strategies designed to promote the sustained delivery of child trauma EBPs by reducing provider turnover through targeting the associated mechanisms of provider burnout and organizational psychological safety climate. Findings will have a significant public health impact by informing efforts to increase the sustained availability of child trauma EBPs, thereby improving outcomes for children exposed to trauma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT There remains an important need for the development of effective, rapid and safe methods for developing and refining new medical imaging technologies that can improve patient outcomes. Virtual imaging trials (VITs) hold great potential for this purpose but, currently, their effectiveness is generally limited by the use of image quality measures that do not quantify clinical utility for realistic diagnostic tasks. The proposed research will address this and thereby enable highly effective VITs that will accelerate new medical imaging technologies towards clinical use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because receptor crosstalk underlies the pathogenesis of many human diseases from autoimmune diseases to cancer, and because endocytosis is a vital cellular process. Understanding the functional role of endocytosis in receptor crosstalk will facilitate the development of new therapeutic approaches, such as immune adjuvants for cancer therapies and vaccines. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that seeks to increase fundamental knowledge of biological processes that will lay the foundation for advances in disease diagnosis, treatment, and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposed research is aimed at classifying novel subtypes of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), by studying inflammation in the blood of patients (complex protein and genetic profiles) and using sophisticated computational methods (machine learning and systems-based network analysis) to find data patterns that would otherwise remain hidden. This research is relevant to public health as the burden of morbidity and mortality is high in PAH, and the current system used to classify patients does not inform treatment decisions. Our project has significant potential to improve public health, as it may yield a PAH classification scheme that sits closer to underlying pathobiology, provide a critical step toward identifying patients who will respond to specific therapies, help improve the design of forthcoming clinical trials, and create a framework for precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: VACCINE RESEARCH INSTITUTE OF SAN DIEGO
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria is the world's most important lethal tropical parasitic disease (over 500,000 deaths each year) with an estimated 200 million clinical new illnesses each year. Natural P. falciparum infection requires muiltiple rounds over many years for partial immunity. Further, malaria control efforts are being impeded by the spread of multiple drug resistant malaria and the development of insecticide resistance by the anopheline mosquito vector. Therefore, an effective prophylactic vaccine is urgently needed to prevent further spread of these diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Twenty-four percent of women in the U.S. have an elective termination of pregnancy by the age 45. Mental symptoms and disorders are elevated among those having elective terminations relative to those not having elective terminations. This research seeks to understand mental health changes from before to after an elective termination and the role of the sociocultural context in mental health around such an experience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The proposed University of Illinois Short-Term Research Training Program (SRTP) will provide first year medical students with a 10-week mentored research experience in the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK) mission areas including, kidney, urologic and hematologic diseases; digestive disease and nutrition; and diabetes, endocrinology and metabolic disease. The proposed program brings together an outstanding team of established and emerging mentors with expertise in basic/mechanistic, clinical/translational, and behavioral/community-based research spanning NIDDK mission areas. In addition to mentored research, students will participate in interactive structured curriculum focused on research methodology, responsible conduct of research, presentation skills, and career development.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Knowledge of host pathways regulating the control of inflammation may impact our understanding of susceptibility to infections (like HIV-1) and other inflammatory diseases and could lead to new approaches to prevention and treatment of these diseases. We propose to further define these relationships and explore the possibility of inflammation-related effects of these variants using data from seven existing cohorts and archived blood and mucosal samples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The innate immune system deploys various pattern-recognition receptors, including Toll-like receptors (TLRs), to detect the infection of pathogenic microbes and initiate protective responses. We recently discovered that specific short non-coding RNAs (sncRNAs) are abundantly accumulated upon activation of TLR pathways in macrophages and their extracellular vehicles (EVs). The goal of the proposed project is to characterize the expression profiles of infection-induced sncRNAs and to explore their function in stimulating TLRs, which will represent novel research efforts to clarify sncRNA-engaged pathway in the immune response and may support future exploration of biomarkers and efficacious therapeutic applications targeting the sncRNAs in microbe infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Genetic recombination is a fundamental process that all living cells use to repair DNA damage that occurs during DNA synthesis or from exogenous sources. It is also the method of choice for altering genomes to study how precise changes in gene function are associated with different disease states. Insights into the mechanisms that repair double-strand breaks will impact studies in all organisms, especially those that are used as model systems for studying human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The wealth of multiple-omics datasets produced by the Cancer Genome Atlas and NCI’s Genome Data Analysis Network have set the stage to understand and predict health outcomes for cancer patients. Our proposal would contribute to the future GDAN to apply computational approaches that unite these data with the growing information contained in new single-cell datasets to provide key information about the types of cells that comprise a tumor and its microenvironment through the use of mRNA gene expression signatures. We will share new results of the GDAN through the TumorMap and Xena Browsers to support exploration of the data through collaborations with Analysis Working groups and work with the consortium to define state-of-the-art machine-learning methods to predict therapy response in new clinical trial datasets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Somatic copy-number alterations (SCNAs) and the rearrangements that generate them are, together with mutations, the major somatic genome alterations in human cancer, and understanding them yields insights into how to diagnose and treat cancers. We have extensive experience in developing methods to detect and interpret SCNAs and rearrangements and have applied these methods across tens of thousands of tumors, discovering new molecular subtypes of cancer that may benefit from new therapeutic strategies. We propose to renew our Genomics Data Analysis Center that will specialize in conducting state-of-the-art analyses of SCNAs and rearrangements from both short read and long read sequencing data to answer clinically and biologically relevant questions that are tailored to the needs of the wider Genomics Data Analysis Network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Down Syndrome is the most common human genetic disease due to chromosome aneuploidy (trisomy 21), but the molecular basis for gene deregulation in these patients remains largely enigmatic or debatable, which can be partially attributed to our lack of understanding of 3D genome organization in trisomy 21 that may conceptually go beyond the limit of “gene dosage effects”. In this proposal, we apply leading-edge 4D genome technologies to pioneer an underexplored direction that the extra copy of chromosome 21 may deregulate the entire 4D genome organization in disease cells, and impact gene expression. The results of this work will have broad implications to understand, and to therapeutically treat chromosomal aneuploidy commonly seen in many human diseases, such as cancer, congenital heart diseases and neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The current project aims to develop and evaluate an early, brief, integrated intervention to reduce alcohol use disorder (AUD) and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms after recent sexual assault. AUD and PTSD are two common intersecting health outcomes that contribute to public health care costs. Results from the proposed research will set the stage for a more rigorous randomized controlled trial of the brief intervention for AUD and PTSD, which has the potential for high impact and to be highly scalable.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic inflammation has emerged as a biomarker of interest linking low socioeconomic status (SES) with disease risk; however, the development of socioeconomic differences in inflammation during adolescence and the biobehavioral and psychosocial underpinnings of the link are not well understood. The present study explores SES associations with markers of inflammation during a window of substantial psychological, biological, and social change—the transition from adolescence to adulthood—with the goal of identifying factors that may explain how SES influences risk for inflammation. Findings from this research can provide foundational knowledge on the development of socioeconomic disparities in health and identify potential routes for intervention (e.g., improving sleep and social connection) to reduce health risk for youth of low socioeconomic backgrounds, supporting NICHD’s mission to enhance the lives and wellbeing of adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative BRAIN-STEM The goal of this project is to increase the number of students from rural areas who pursue careers in healthcare with the understanding that one of the strongest and most consistently reported predictors of practicing in rural areas is where one grew up. This will be accomplished by developing an educational program that increases academic, research, and metacognitive skills important for succeeding in the STEM subjects relevant to healthcare profession training. This project will further benefit society by sparking interest in and providing foundational knowledge about relevant health issues in neuroscience, addiction and concussion, that high school students and teachers can affect within their own community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The current arms-race that exists between drug discovery and the bacterial pathogens that rapidly develop resistance against these new antibiotics can be ended by interfering with the key evolutionary processes that enable resistance to emerge. Herein, we untangle the importance of the cell-states of tolerance, persistence and hetero-resistance in their roles as harbingers of antibiotic treatment failure (ATF) and enablers of resistance. We identify the treatment regimens that select for ATF cell-state induction, uncover the genetic mechanisms underlying their emergence, devise strategies to target their collateral sensitivities, and develop a proof-of- principle computational diagnostics approach that predicts the presence and frequency of ATF cell-states in complex bacterial populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Non-healing wounds are a major diabetic complication and represent a major public health burden. This work addresses how communication between skin cells and immune cells, mediated by skin cell-derived nanocarriers called exosomes, is interrupted by diabetes which in turn causes chronic inflammation. This work will help understand why diabetic wounds are refractory to current clinical care and provide cues on how to troubleshoot.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Sepsis is a severe life-threatening response to infection that results in over 270,000 deaths in the U.S. annually. The one-size-fits-all approach to treating sepsis has not worked, and thus it is essential to identify distinct sepsis subgroups that may have differential responses to treatments. This proposal applies cutting-edge machine learning algorithms to bedside vital signs (e.g., temperature, heart rate, etc.) to identify sepsis subgroups with differential responses to treatments, thus opening the doors for the precision medicine approach to sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Increased lipid production is essential for cancer cell survival, and numerous recent publications indicate a central role for the SREBP pathway in various cancers, including prostate cancer. African American males—who already have 2.6 times higher mortality from prostate cancer than Caucasian males—appear to have up to four- fold greater risk of developing prostate cancer in the context of obesity. Our proposed studies will help generate a rich body of evidence supporting successful targeting of lipid signaling for the treatment of lethal prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to demonstrate the feasibility of a fully integrated, wirelessly operated catheter dressing for the early detection of catheter-related sepsis. The objectives of this proposal are consistent with the goals of the NIH NIGMS Technology Development Program R21 and will have a significant impact on public health by forming the basis for real-time non-invasive and on-body monitoring of an extended range of bacterial species, including antibiotic-resistant bacterial growth. This integrated device can transform the current practices, improve the patients’ quality of life and the ability of clinicians to treat the patients much earlier than the current clinical practice, and help reduce the morbidity and mortality rates and associated healthcare costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Colorado Cancer Research Program is a cancer clinical trial research organization who seeks to provide access to NCI sponsored clinical trials for our consortium members located in the mountain states of Colorado, Wyoming, Montana, Utah, Washington and Alaska. By partnering with Healthcare systems and community hospitals, we will provide access to innovative therapies and cancer related research projects for patients in their home communities, all the while, pursuing and supporting NCI strategic research priorities. We work with Healthcare systems, Hospitals, Providers and Patients to disseminate knowledge about clinical trial options, clinical trial participation, and clinical trial outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE UNC-13 is a large synaptic protein that is important for several synaptic fusion processes, including synaptic vesicle (SV) docking and priming, lipid-binding, and SNARE complex assembly/disassembly regulation. Mutations in the HC2M and MUN domains of UNC-13 are associated with developmental disorders, seizures, and musculoskeletal abnormalities. Our research plan uses a combination of genetic, behavioral, and biochemical methods to investigates the mechanism of UNC-13 in synaptic transmission with a particular focus on the MUN and HC2M domains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Right ventricular failure (RVF) is a prevalent cause of cardiovascular collapse and a major public health problem. Unlike left ventricular failure, RVF is not frequently investigated, which has contributed to the lack of effective therapies for RVF. Here we propose to use computational model predictions, based on state-of-the-art, multi- scale, comprehensive experimental datasets, to improve our understanding of RVF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Most oral health professionals advise patients who smoke to quit, but few connect patients directly to smoking cessation medication, which is an essential component of evidence-based smoking cessation treatment. Based on findings from previous trials, this cluster randomized, hybrid type 1 implementation-effectiveness trial will test whether combining brief advice with nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) sampling, which refers to providing patients who smoke with free samples of over-the-counter nicotine patches and nicotine lozenges, during a routine dentist visit increases rates of abstinence, quit attempts, and use of NRT. The results of the proposed research have potential for important clinical and policy significance with regard to reducing tobacco-related morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Sexual assault occurs at extremely high rates and more than half involve alcohol consumption. The goal of the proposed research is to develop a virtual reality simulation of a potential sexual assault situation and use it in experimental research. This will allow the effects of alcohol consumption on sexual aggression to be examined under controlled conditions, thereby increasing confidence that differences found between drinkers and nondrinkers are due to alcohol, not other factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Relevance: Project summary: Relevance to public health. New basic science discoveries show that pharmaceutical manipulation of the hormone amylin holds promise as a potential treatment for obesity, as food intake is suppressed by amylin in obese humans and animal models. This proposal will advance knowledge of amylin action on reward-based feeding that significantly contributes to the obesity epidemic. Proposed studies identify the physiological role of amylin action throughout the brain and the mechanisms by which amylin signaling reduces reward-based feeding.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is estimated to be 5.7 million adults in the US suffering from heart failure (HF), representing a significant health care burden for the nation. The progressive cardiac fibrosis and dysfunction seen in HF involves myofibroblast differentiation, with recent data showing myofibroblast differentiation to be driven by discrete changes in fibroblast metabolism. Understanding metabolic processes involved in myofibroblast differentiation will expand the application of new medicines that modulate these processes and ultimately lessen the burden of HF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common malignant renal neoplasm, which often presents as an incidentally detected, incompletely characterized renal mass. Due to the limited capability of current imaging techniques, many of these patients with incidental renal mass undergo direct surgery or biopsy without further imaging evaluation which adds to unnecessary morbidity and health care cost. In this study, we propose to leverage our expertise in Magnetic Resonance Fingerprinting, machine learning, and body MR imaging to develop a novel free-breathing, multi-parametric MR imaging technique, which upon successful development, could make MRI a more powerful tool for the diagnosis and characterization of these patients with incidental renal mass, with the ultimate goal to eliminate unnecessary biopsy/surgery in eligible patients and provide guidance towards the most appropriate treatment strategy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research project will use the large number of protein sequences that have become available in the last few decades to learn the rules that give proteins their unique properties. These rules will emphasize covariance, an important feature in which the sequence in one region of a protein influences the sequence in another region, much like the rhyming words in separate lines of a poem or song. With these rules may help understand how proteins function in health and disease, and may one day help to design proteins that can be used as drugs or medical diagnostic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative The Biotechnology Resource Center of BioModular Multi-scale Systems (CBM2) for Precision Medicine will generate technologies to enable precision decisions on managing different disease states. The technologies evolving from the Center will possess unique and compelling operating characteristics that will provide diagnostic and prognostic information obtained from liquid biopsy markers. The technologies will use amplification-free single-molecule processing in a highly multiplexed format that will provide disease-specific signatures to help guide physicians on making critical clinical decisions (i.e., Precision Medicine) to improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ionizing radiation is known to induce cellular senescence and activate a secretory program that can result in immune modulation. We have shown that senescence is a significant contributor to the anti-tumor response to ionizing radiation. We propose to use mouse and human models of rectal cancer to define the contribution of senescence and its secretory program to the antitumor effects of radiation, to characterize how radiation-induced senescence remodels the tumor immune environment, and to assess the contribution of radiation-induced senescence and its secretory program to render systemic anti-tumor responses that can be augmented with immune checkpoint blockade.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will evaluate the impact of Family Connections, a family-based group intervention for adolescents and young adults (AYA) living with HIV and their family caregivers. The intervention seeks to increase social and family support and decrease self-stigma among AYA, so they may improve their medication adherence and achieve an undetectable viral load. Findings will fill a critical gap in available evidence-based intervention options for improving the HIV-related outcomes and wellbeing of HIV-positive AYA in sub-Saharan Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative As the Precision Medicine Initiative seeks to improve patient care by securing detailed molecular information on a patient’s disease, new diagnostic/prognostic markers and the tools to analyze them become increasingly needed. These needs include the ability to analyze low abundance markers (i.e., liquid biopsy markers) with a simple workflow required for clinical implementation. In TR&D 1, the Center will develop innovative tools for the processing of rare liquid biopsy markers’ molecular cargo at the single-molecule level without the need for amplification. Specifically, the tools consist of solid-phase enzymatic reactors coupled to nanoscale electrophoresis to allow for real time readout of the products generated from an enzymatic reaction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML) is a highly aggressive blood cancer with no effective drug therapies. Mutations in the CBL gene, which occur in approximately 15% of CMML patients, are associated with an especially poor prognosis. This project will employ cutting-edge genetic and pharmacologic approaches to identify new targeted therapies for patients with CBL-mutant CMML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative The Biotechnology Resource Center of BioModular Multi-scale Systems (CBM2) for Precision Medicine will produce an innovative label-free nanofluidic sensor with in-plane nanopores for not only detecting unamplified single molecules, but also identifying them via their molecular-dependent time-of-flight (TOF). The hardware and software required for high throughput label-free TOF sensing will be developed. By integrating solid-phase nanoscale reactors with the in-plane nanopores and nano-columns, this sensor can be configured to provide molecular information from unamplified targets (DNA, RNA, and proteins) with unprecedented identification accuracies (>95%).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Hybrid insulin peptides (HIPs) form through peptide bond formation between proinsulin fragments and other beta-cell peptides. These neoepitopes contain non-genomic amino acid sequences, making them plausible targets for disease-driving T cells in Type 1 Diabetes (T1D). Here, we propose to (1) Modulate autophagy in human islets to maximize HIP-content for mass spectrometric identification; (2) Study the role of metabolic stress on HIP-accumulation in NOD islets; (3) Analyze biochemical mechanism of HIP formation in human islets; (4) Study the role of novel HIPs in T1D pathogenesis through ELISPOT analyses; (5) Develop and implement a bioinformatics algorithm for the mass spectrometric identification of native and hybrid peptides.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anorexia nervosa (AN) is a deadly psychiatric disorder associated with marked medical and psychosocial impairment and chronic course. The current study will use neurocognitive tasks and computational modeling to test the possibility that deficits in reinforcement learning account for response to the first line treatment for adolescent AN, Family-Based Treatment (FBT). By better characterizing neurocognitive predictors of response to FBT, findings from this investigation will facilitate the identification of participants at greater risk for treatment failure and ultimately inform the development of adjunctive treatments to improve outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative The Biotechnology Resource Center of BioModular Multi-scale Systems (CBM2) for Precision Medicine will develop technologies to enable robust manufacturing and assembly of modular, integrated platforms to provide clinicians and researchers with more detailed information about patient health to facilitate disease management. The assembly technology will permit seamless transfer of rare liquid biopsy markers from module-to- motherboard for blood-to-sequencing enabling more reliable operation. The power and versatility of the technology will be demonstrated by sequencing circulating tumor cells extracted from blood and provide an electrical readout of diagnostic mutations they may carry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cardiometabolic risks are a major health challenge facing the overweight and obese US population. The adipose tissue of overweight/obese individuals lacks adequate oxygenation, which instigates local and systemic low-grade inflammation.  We have identified a novel adipokine, interleukin 19, that is able to modulate angiogenesis and inflammation in visceral fat depots. IL-19 can preserve microvascular function of adipose tissue thus reducing cardiometabolic risks and cardiovascular disease.  This research will improve our understanding of the mechanisms that govern adipose tissue dysfunction in obesity, and it will provide a framework for developing new therapeutic strategies to avert cardiometabolic disorders in the overweigh/obese population of the USA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer arises from the loss of control of growth in cells. Although attention has focused mostly on genetic mutations as the origin of these defects, it has become clear that changes in the epigenetic control of gene activity also contribute to this loss of growth control. This project aims to provide epigenetic analysis of clinical trial epigenomic data to advance our understanding of how epigenetic defects impact cancer biology and clinical outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE “Science Journeys” is a unique educational experience for children and families who are navigating hospitalization and complex medical care, an often high-stress experience and one that leads students to miss prolonged periods of in school time. With the aid of multimedia tools, “Journeys” participants will use their own health data to further their understanding of the body, what diseases affect kids, and how diagnostic methods/tests, treatments, and healthcare teams help them get well. Ultimately, this hands-on engaging STEM focused program will support the physical and mental wellness of those seeking care and increase agency in their health journey. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative: The diagnosis and treatment of diseases caused by dysregulation of lipid metabolism, including diabetes, cardiovascular disease, cancer, neurodegeneration, and fatty liver, is hinder by a lack of tools for measuring lipid biochemistry in vivo. Here, we develop tools for measuring the flux of lipids with stable isotopes using a novel ultra-high resolution mass spectrometer that can resolve natural abundance isotopes from tracer isotopes. We will overcome fundamental barriers to the implementation of this technology so that it can be accessed by the biomedical research community.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Optimizing antibiotic use is an immediate task to curtail antibiotic resistance and is an AHRQ research priority area. In order to safely optimize antibiotic use among newborn infants, an AHRQ priority population, accurate measurement of antibiotic use is required. The purpose of this pharmacoepidemiology study is to identify meaningful metrics of neonatal antibiotic use in order to allow hospitals and stakeholders to pinpoint antibiotic utilization practices that should be emulated or avoided, and ultimately improve the safety and quality of neonatal care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed Center for Pacific Innovations, Knowledge, and Opportunities (PIKO) addresses several issues of central importance to building a robust clinical and translational research (CTR) infrastructure that directly improves the health and wellbeing of indigenous Pacific People (IPP), defined as Native Hawaiians, Other Pacific Islanders, and Filipinos, and other underserved populations. The Center will establish a strong collaborative among three academic institutions and a statewide network of stakeholders, including practice-based and community-based organizations and health care providers; convert basic discoveries into real-world solutions to improve IPP health and reduce IPP health disparities; and increase the number of junior and other investigators, particularly from IPP backgrounds, for CTR careers.
