IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is projected to be the second leading cause of cancer-related deaths in the United States and has been recognized as a recalcitrant cancer that requires accelerated research via the implementation of a long-term strategic plan. PDAC tumors have scarce nutrients, and to bypass this nutrient deficiency, cancer cells use an endocytic process called macropinocytosis as an amino acid supply route. We have identified that tumor support cells, called stromal cells, also use macropinocytosis for their survival and we propose to study how this uptake pathway works in these cells and whether it represents a vulnerability that can be targeted in PDAC therapy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Obstetric and pediatric patients often suffer from imprecise medical treatment due to vast interpatient variability and lack of individualized data amongst these populations. Electrochemical aptamer based sensors offer the potential for a generalizable approach to the on-demand, high- frequency monitoring of clinically relevant analytes, which could enable personalized treatment tailored to each individual patient. This proposal will usher in the first integrated EAB platforms deployable both in the clinic and in the home of the patient, serving as a catalyst for the clinical adoption of EAB sensors for a variety of applications in the treatment of disease in children, pregnant women, and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Facultative pathogens like Vibrio cholerae must defend against the ubiquitous threat of predatory phages to cause disease in humans. This proposal aims to determine the molecular basis for the anti-phage activity of a group of mobile genetic elements in epidemic V. cholerae. Advances in our understanding of factors impacting microbial survival in states of disease will contribute to improved and targeted infection control measures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: U54 CENTER: NARRATIVE Metastatic organ colonization by circulating tumor cells depends on a response program in tumor cells, termed mechano-adaptation, to cope with mechanical and molecular stresses. In this U54 MetNet Center, we will integrate mechanical, genomic and ultrastructural information during metatastatic organ colonization and identify mechanical mechanisms of tumor cell fate decisions and identify pathways and potential therapeutic strategies to eliminate tumor cells prior to metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE High dietary sodium intake is linked to incident hypertension (HTN) and cardiovascular events. Conversely, lower sodium intake has been shown to reduce both blood pressure (BP) and prevent atherosclerotic cardiovascular diseases (ASCVD). American Heart Association guidelines advocate daily sodium intake of less than 2,300 mg, but the estimated average sodium intake for Americans is 3,400 mg per day. In recent years, consumption of pre-processed and restaurant foods has substantially increased, and more than 75% of sodium in the average U.S. diet now comes from these sources. Our overall objectives are to: (1) evaluate the efficacy of a dietary sodium mobile application intervention on reducing BP, (2) establish that the improvement in BP is directly related to the change in diet and body weight, and (3) optimize the intervention to demonstrate sustained effects on BP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Decline in episodic memory – memory for unique events – is typical of healthy aging and, in a much more exaggerated fashion, of age-related neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer’s Disease. The proposed research will contribute to the understanding of age-related differences in cognitive abilities, and the brain systems supporting them, that accompany age- and Alzheimer’s-related episodic memory decline. An important long-term goal of the research is to help pave the way for the development of interventions that will ameliorate memory decline by enhancing the memory processes that are most affected as a consequence of healthy and pathological aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Bacterial synthetic multicellular systems and materials hold promise for many health-relevant ap- plications such as modular drug biosynthesis, living diagnostic devices, and synthetic bioﬁlm research models. Establishing control over the spatial, biochemical, and biophysical characteristics of synthetic consortia will be critical, but the key engineering tools such as synthetic cell-cell adhesins are still in their infancy. To close these major gaps, the proposed investigations will establish relevant synthetic tools, design principles, and modeling tools and deliver proof of principle of a new paradigm for modular engineering of synthetic multicellular bacterial consortia with desirable and tunable material properties and medical applicability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative. The Washington University T32 postdoctoral training grant “Translational Imaging in Radiopharmaceutical Sciences” (abbreviated as “TIRS”) is a multidisciplinary initiative to train the next generation of PET molecular imaging scientists to design, develop, and translate diagnostic agents for imaging of neurodegenerative diseases and ADRDs. To accomplish this novel training mission, the T32 TIRS program brings leading scientists from 12 departments of Washington University on a single platform to provide proposed multidisciplinary training. Successful accomplishment of training goals (as outlined in program plan) will deliver molecular PET imaging research scientists who would be transitioning into faculty positions nationwide and will be expected to serve the field of diagnostic nuclear medicine in neuroscience for several decades.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Epidemiological evidence indicates a significant association between ambient PM exposures in China and increased incidence or severity of respiratory infections. Linked human in vivo and mechanistic in vitro studies are needed to understand the effects of PM on respiratory immune responses and susceptibility to infection. Our quantitative and integrated translational research approaches will be able to determine the effects of “China PM” on respiratory mucosal host defense function in humans in vitro (UNC Projects) and in vivo (Chinese Collaborative Project).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project 2: NARRATIVE Metastatic organ colonization by circulating tumor cells in vivo differs in mechanical challenge between organ sites and single-cell and collective metastasis modes. Using intravital microscopy of single or clustered tumor cells during liver and skin metastasis, we will identify novel molecular mechanisms of mechano-adaptation securing survival, dormancy and outgrowth and potential intervention points to prevent metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Part of the NIH mission is to seek fundamental knowledge about the nature and behavior of living systems, and to apply this knowledge to enhance human health and lengthen life. Our proposed research is relevant to this mission because it seeks to understand how plants and microorganisms, some of which are medically-relevant pathogens, use the phytochrome (Phy) family of photoreceptors to gather information about their light environment and adjust their growth and development accordingly. In addition, given the widespread biotechnological use of Phy variants both as novel fluorophores and as engineered photoswitches, a further understanding of Phy structure and photochemistry should accelerate the development of advanced optogenetic tools for tissue imaging and the precise spatial and temporal control of cellular events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While advances in cancer therapeutics have resulted in remarkable clinical responses in some patients, acquired resistance remains one of the biggest challenges towards expanding the clinical benefits to more patients. Tackling acquired therapy resistance will require collaborative efforts to elucidate resistance mechanisms, characterize the tumor microenvironment, discover new targets, identify predictive biomarkers, evaluate combination therapies, and develop real-time monitoring approaches. The goal of our proposed Coordinating and Data Management Center (CDMC) application is to coordinate the activities across the Acquired Resistance to Therapy Network (ARTNet), and to manage, integrate and disseminate the data and resources generated through the network. Leveraging cutting-edge multi-disciplinary team approaches, we will support the ARTNet to inform new strategies that can be better translated to overcome significant challenges in acquired resistance to cancer therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Diabetic bone disease (DBD) characterized by substantial high fracture risk represents a major complication of type 2 diabetes (T2D) afflicting 40 million people in the US and 370 million in the world. Long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs) are a family of non-protein-coding transcripts playing important roles in gene expression and pathogenesis of many human diseases. We have recently discovered and characterized a new lncRNA, lncR-DBD, which targets the major etiopathogenesis of DBD and emerges as a novel, efficient and effective therapeutic remedy for the epidemic DBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Embryonic and tissue development requires the tight spatiotemporal regulation of morphogenic movements in order to properly instruct cell fates. While a widely used cellular shape change involved in morphogenesis is apical constriction, the mechanisms by which it is regulated in mammals are largely unknown. Our investigations will uncover conserved and distinct apical constriction regulators in several mammalian morphogenic events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: A detailed understanding of human disease at the single cell level represents a challenging frontier, and very few measurement techniques are available to accurately quantify metabolites involved in all areas of human health. This MIRA application draws from our experience with nanoelectrochemistry, sensor development, and single cell analysis to innovate a generalizable platform to study metabolite concentrations in cellular compartments with minimal perturbation to cellular homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The Center for Tumor-Immune Systems Biology at MSKCC NARRATIVE Cancer immunotherapies are designed to harness the human immune system to attack cancer cells and eliminate tumors. Breakthroughs in cancer immunotherapy such as checkpoint blockade agents have revolutionized cancer care, but only a fraction of patients with specific tumor types respond to these new treatments. Our proposed Research Center will deploy tools from systems biology to improve our fundamental understanding of tumor-immune interactions in contexts where current immunotherapies fail and to develop novel strategies for enhancing responses in contexts where they have only partial success.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the majority of college students being underage for drinking, almost 80% report consuming alcohol in the past year and more than 1 in 3 report heavy drinking in the past month. Reports also show college is a high-risk window for cannabis use and consequences (including using both substances in the same day), which is highly concerning considering that the potency of present-day cannabis has markedly increased and availability continues to grow due to increased legalization across the U.S. The proposed research will address these important public health problems by testing a modified version of our parent-intervention that includes content for parents to have broader discussions about alcohol and cannabis use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: A program in Aging and Alzheimer’s Research Training (AART) at Georgetown University will train PhD students and postdoctoral fellows in laboratory research into causes and connections of aging-related neurodegenerative diseases. The program will build on a wide array of current research laboratories at Georgetown University in aging and neurodegeneration, on clinical and neuropathological programs, on graduate aging coursework, on regional centers of aging and Alzheimer’s disease, and on a dynamic office for career development. The overall goal is to train students and fellows whose current research experience is related to, but not focused on, aging and Alzheimer’s disease research, and to foster advances in aging/AD research by promoting this interdisciplinary work.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will provide a detailed picture of alcohol-induced changes in human drug-metabolizing ensemble and characterize system-wide changes in drug metabolism induced by alcohol exposure. The obtained knowledge will be instrumental for optimizing drug dozing regimes in alcohol consumers, and the drugs used in treatment of Alcohol Use Disorder and Alcohol Withdrawal Syndrome in particular. Besides providing new insights on the effects of alcohol on drug metabolism, this study will result in fundamental conceptual advancements in our understanding of complex cases of drug-drug and drug-alcohol interactions, adverse drug effects, and other alcohol-induced disorders with P450-dependent pathogenesis. Elaboration of the concept of function and regulation of the human drug-metabolizing ensemble as an integral multi-enzyme system, which is the long-term goal of our studies, is a matter of critical importance for in-depth understanding of the changes in human drug metabolism under influence of alcohol exposure and establishing a rational approach for optimal drug use under chronic alcohol exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The field of metabolomics has mainly been driven by technologies that either completely lose the spatial information of the underlying metabolic processes being studied or require invasive procedures, thus unable to probe metabolism at the most physiologically relevant states. The proposed research aims to develop a research program that will pave a path towards in vivo, noninvasive imaging of tissue metabolomics through development of an unprecedented high-resolution, multinuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopic imaging (MRSI) technology and a novel multimodal biochemical imaging framework that integrates MRSI and mass spectrometry imaging for the first time. If successful, this research will transform metabolomics into a powerful noninvasive and tissue specific tool (from an invasive and nonspatial-specific one) for studying metabolism in living animals and humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Measuring receptor-ligand interactions on cells is essential in a wide range of biomedical research and clinical applications. However, existing adhesion assays suffer frommany limitations, including bulkiness, low throughput, difficulty in resolving the non-uniform distribution of receptors on single cells, and the inability to measure both tensile and shear forces in cell adhesion. The goal of this proposed project is to develop a novel light-based four-dimensional adhesion frequency assay to overcome these key obstacles and enable a multiplexed and programmable three-dimensional profiling of both shear and tensile affinities of cells and viruses at sub-cellular resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The obesity epidemic has led to the increased incidence of fatty liver disease that can lead to hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), which is the 4th leading cause of cancer deaths in the US. There are no effective treatments for this disease and the molecular pathways that lead to HCC in the context of obesity are not well understood. The studies proposed here will investigate a novel molecular pathway mediated by HAF which protects cells against the stresses associated with fatty liver disease that can lead to HCC, and thus reveal new treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol is the most prevalently used substance among gay and bisexual men (GBM) but the impact of alcohol use and misuse on PrEP adherence is not well understood; therefore, the proposed research uses multiple data collection methodologies to better elucidate how alcohol effects PrEP adherence. The information that will be gained from the study is relevant to public health efforts to eliminate the HIV epidemic in the U.S. and relevant to NIAAA’s research priority to reduce HIV incidence and improve prevention strategies, including consistent use of PrEP, among GBM who drink.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We develop the multiplexed super-resolution force spectroscopy to investigate the mechanism of ribosome translocation during protein synthesis. We will measure the power strokes from elongation factors and their mutants during ribosome translocation on modified mRNA sequences and in the presence of antibiotics. Our research will provide new model about the ribosome translocation with sub-codon steps and provide potential drug targets for the related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to utilize the Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS) to assess alcohol use disparities between sexual minority youth (SMY) and heterosexual youth at the intersections of multiple marginalized identities including sex and race/ethnicity, and to determine how these associations impact HIV vulnerability. The team’s pooled dataset, which contains 950,295 youth from local versions of the YRBS, will be extended to include YRBS data collected between 2021 and 2025, providing the opportunity to conduct innovative, intersectional research on the associations between alcohol use, HIV vulnerabilities, and mental health on a national scale and adapt novel methodologies for this purpose. This project builds upon a highly successful prior R01 which facilitated critical health disparities research, interdisciplinary collaboration, and high-impact publication, by strengthening the available sample and leveraging additional modes of complex quantitative inquiry to support innovation in analysis and application of results.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative – Public Health Relevance Malaria remains the major mosquito-borne parasitic disease worldwide, and Venezuela and Brazil combined are currently responsible for an estimated 720,000 malaria cases, 75% of all those reported in South America. Our studies will provide the first regional comparison of key understudied ecological mechanisms and landscape genetics directly linked to malaria risk from the primary malaria vectors in endemic hotspots: gold mining settlements in Venezuela and rainforest riverine, mining, and agricultural settlements in Brazil. This field-based study at multiple spatial scales will provide evidence to improve control strategies that maximally impact malaria transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to continue the successful holistic University of Utah Native American Research Internship (NARI) program to include summer research experiences in diabetes, obesity, and metabolism, which are major health concerns of the AI/AN population. The NARI-NIDDK program will partner diabetes, obesity and metabolism researchers at the University of Utah with those AI/AN undergraduates who aspire to help understand why AI/AN have been affected so disproportionately. The overarching goal of the NARI-NIDDK program is to increase the diversity of the U.S. biomedical science workforce and reduce health disparities in the AI/AN population by supporting the scientific development of each undergraduate NARI-NIDDK participant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with combined immunodeficiencies (CID), such as partial recombination activating gene (RAG) deficiency, often present with chronic infections and autoimmune diseases, in which B and T cells are dysfunctional, including many B cells that produce antibodies against self. We aim to specifically determine the unique characteristics and fate of these autoantibody-producing B cells and to understand how they go awry in partial RAG deficiency. Accomplishing these aims may help researchers design treatments to correct the tendency of these B cells to produce autoantibodies rather than protective antibodies, and thus alleviate autoimmunity and susceptibility to infections in patients with partial RAG deficiency and other CID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Liver receptor homolog 1 (LRH-1) is a nuclear hormone receptor that acts as an important regulator of lipid and glucose metabolism and has shown promise as a new therapeutic target for obesity-related metabolic diseases; however, a poor understanding of how ligands regulate LRH-1 has hampered development of modulators. This proposal is centered on improving recently developed high-affinity LRH-1 modulators to support in vivo studies for use in a new humanized LRH-1 mouse model. These tools will enable the study of LRH-1 biology and have therapeutic potential for diseases such as diabetes and fatty liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Patients with unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma have poor overall survival. Immunotherapy with PD-L1 and VEGF inhibitor is a recent major advance, however, progression free survival remains short at less than 7 months. We propose to examine the clinical activities and immune effect of a novel combination therapy using radiation followed by intratumor injection of autologous dendritic cells followed by standard of care PD-L1 and VEGF inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Speech disorders negatively impact communication, reducing the overall quality of life and well-being of individuals with speech disorders. The proposed research is relevant to public health because the project’s findings will form a strong scientific foundation for developing theory-driven, effective, and optimized treatments for speech disorders. Additionally, this project will pave the way for developing more refined and complete theoretical perspectives of speech and speech disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We developed a cost-effective, minimally-invasive approach to determine the amount of tumor-derived DNA in blood through shallow (‘ultra low-pass’) whole genome sequencing of cell-free DNA from a single blood sample. In this proposal, we will analytically validate our cell-free DNA assay (UH2 portion) then establish clinical validity and prospectively evaluate performance in metastatic breast cancer through two large tissue collection and two therapeutic clinical trials (UH3 portion). The ultimate goal of this research is to utilize this cell-free DNA genomic biomarker to guide therapy in metastatic breast and other cancers.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative  This project aims to develop new imaging agents that can efficiently detect parathyroid glands preoperatively, and be used intraoperatively to guide exploration. It is expected that PET signal will introduce high sensitivity for parathyroid detection, and NIRF signal will facilitate subsequent gland localization during surgery. The success of this application will greatly benefit the management of patients with primary hyperparathyroidism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE There is substantial evidence that conducting multifactorial fall risk assessments and developing personalized prevention plans in primary care settings can reduce falls, but many barriers exist to integrating this evidence into practice. The US Preventive Service Task Force recommends fall prevention exercises for community- dwelling adults who are at increased risk for falls, however less than half of older persons report discussing their falls with their primary care providers (PCPs). The goal of this project is to develop, test, and evaluate shareable, standards-based fall prevention clinical decision support, eSTEPS (electronic Strategies for Tailored Exercise to Prevent FallS) that can used by primary care providers to facilitate personalized activity and exercise prescriptions and reduce falls in at risk older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Emphysema is a common serious co-morbidity in people living with HIV (PLWH). We will study if doxycycline slows its progression in PLWH (current or former smokers) by measuring diffusing capacity (how well oxygen transfers from air into blood) and quantifying computed tomography (CT) scans of the lungs. We will evaluate if doxycycline improves health status with patient-oriented surveys and functional status with 6 minute walk tests in a multi-center, randomized, placebo-controlled trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Polyamines are small organic cations that are found in all living organisms. Polyamine levels are dysregulated in multiple diseases, including cancer, but their precise molecular functions are not understood. We will develop and apply new technologies to understand the role of polyamines in cell function and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Smoking accounts for 8 out of 10 COPD-related deaths in the US. The FDA continues its efforts to strengthen tobacco control. There is a lack of evidence about the long-term effects of tobacco regulations on respiratory chronic diseases. This project will use a natural history disease microsimulation model to estimate the impact of two FDA cigarette-oriented regulations on the US COPD burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Prostate cancer resistance to medical castration develops more rapidly in men who inherit the adrenal-permissive germline gain-of-function in the steroidogenic enzyme HSD3B1 we discovered in a previous project period. This proposal will determine whether the adrenal-permissive HSD3B1(1245C) allele is a predictive biomarker that enables treatment selection for upfront treatment and whether the adverse biology is directly reversible by enzyme inhibition. We anticipate that this work is likely to change the standard of care for patients with prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antibodies blocking the CD47/SIRPα axis are a promising strategy in cancer immunotherapy with a rapid developing field in recent years. Understanding the contribution of the antibody Fc domain to the antitumor activity of anti-CD47/SIRP α antibodies remains an outstanding question in the field, as there is no consensus on the ideal Fc format to maximize the activity of these agents. The proposed research will inform the development of Fc-optimized anti-CD47/SIRPα antibodies, prevent antibody-mediated toxicities and guide optimal combination strategies, which could be applicable to a wide range of malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Significant progress in cancer outcome may be achieved through data-driven personalized treatment selection for each patient. EMPIRI’s novel, patent-pending, 3D tumor culture method (E-slices) can accurately predict individual patient’s tumor response to chemo, targeted, and immunotherapies in a clinically actionable time frame. This R01 application will validate the clinical utility of E-slices for TNBC patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Perineuronal nets (PNNs) are condensed extracellular matrix around a subset of neurons, which play important roles in the regulation of energy and/or glucose homeostasis. Our pilot observations indicate that 17β-estradiol (E2) can increase PNNs in a brain region called posterodorsal medial amygdala (MePD) in both male and female mice, and PNNs in the MePD enmesh GABA neurons and regulate feeding, body weight and glucose balance. We will follow up these findings to test whether E2 induces PNNs to facilitate GABA neurons in the MePD to prevent obesity and metabolic dysregulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Heterogeneity is inherent in cellular processes. In disease evolution (e.g., cancer) there is extensive genetic and phenotypic diversity between tumors (intertumour heterogeneity) and within individual tumors (intratumour heterogeneity). However, there is an unmet technical challenge for comprehensive proteomic characterization of tumor heterogeneity. We aim to develop a new proteomics technology for enabling routine, rapid, accurate comprehensive characterization of the diverse heterogeneity of tumor cells to meet current biomedical needs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Proper control of ribosome biogenesis and protein synthesis in hematopoietic stem and progenitor cell populations is crucial to hematopoiesis and suppression of blood-derived cancers, as prominently illustrated by a cluster of bone marrow syndromes called “ribosomopathies” in humans. The overall goal of this research program is to better understand the regulation of ribosome assembly and protein translation processes by ubiquitination of critical ribosome assembly factors that is important for preventing stem cell attrition and translation abnormalities. Our studies will provide new insights into stem cell transplantation and therapeutic strategies for treatment of various blood cell disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer is a disease of the genome and arises due an accumulation of mutations that drive normal cells to become cancerous. As a Genome Data Analysis Center (GDAC) with expertise in discovering and characterizing point mutations in the cancer genome, we aim to integrate our state-of-the-art rigorous tools and pipelines for robust point mutation characterization and driver discovery into the Genome Data Analysis Network (GDAN) alongside other GDACs with expertise in complementary fields. Understanding the significance of the point- mutation drivers in the context of analyses from other GDACs in the GDAN will provide the cancer field with a deep, comprehensive understanding of many cancer types that can inform future clinical therapeutics and advance precision medicine at the single-patient level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Relevance: Cognitive deficits involving memory are a common symptom of several neuropsychiatric disorders, and the inability to associate hedonic value of food and tastes with the appropriate context is also implicated in eating disorders. This project aims to understand mechanisms underlying neural coordination at the network level between the sensory cortical region that mediates taste perception and decisions, and the hippocampus which mediates formation and recall of episodic memories. This research will enable novel insight into physiological mechanisms that govern the ability to form and recall memories of taste experiences, and help us to develop tools for tackling cognitive deficits related to memory and eating disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Despite the clear importance of plant terpenoids in medicine and everyday life, how plants synthesize these biologically active compounds remains largely unknown. This research program aims to quickly identify plant terpenoid pathways and to achieve their cost-effective production in microbes. The relevance of this research to public health is its potential to transform the production of existing plant-based medicines while generating novel medicines to treat human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Efficacious interventions for adolescent loss of control eating and overeating are urgently needed given their adverse impacts on weight outcomes and psychosocial functioning. Existing interventions, while promising, fail to comprehensively address self-regulation factors that may impede optimal adherence/behavior change, have modest effects on weight, and can be costly, time/resource intensive, and inaccessible to many adolescents in need. The aim of this small R01 is to design and pilot test a novel technology-based, user-informed, and potentially scalable cognitive-behavioral intervention for adolescents with or at risk for overweight or obesity, built around evidence-based self-regulation theories of maladaptive eating, which has potential to alleviate public health burdens incurred by eating- and weight-related problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunotherapy has become a powerful tool against cancer, but most patients who are treated with immunotherapy, by checkpoint blockade, cellular therapies, vaccination or other strategies, do not respond. The proposed research seeks to better understand what happens in tumors when we treat patients with immunotherapy. By studying tumors directly from patients at multiple timepoints during treatment with immunotherapy, and by using modern comprehensive techniques to do so, this proposal will add significantly to our current knowledge and highlight avenues for new improved immunotherapy strategies that work in more patients and in more types of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE STATEMENT: Voice disorders affect an estimated 3-9% of Americans yearly and 29% of the population in their lifetime. Treatment for vocal fold scarring, a voice disorder caused by tissue injury or loss has been limited. In this application, we seek to link single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics, at exceptional resolution, to characterize VF morphogenesis across time, location and cellular compartments and in response to injury. Whereby, providing a novel and fundamental approach for improving our understanding of VF health and disease, and will allow for optimization of engineering processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Overall: Project Narrative This SPORE is uniquely poised to provide the expertise and infrastructure to rapidly advance sarcoma research, specifically in leiomyosarcoma (LMS), so that patient outcomes can be improved. Sarcomas like leukemias and lymphomas, are mesodermal malignancies and carry biological significance disproportionate to their clinical prevalence. The pathogenic germline variants in LMS are similar in frequency to many common epithelial cancers and our studies will lead to new insights into diagnosis and treatment not only in LMS but more common cancers as well.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: THE CANCER CELL MAP INITIATIVE v2.0 OVERALL NARRATIVE Although much attention has been devoted to mapping the tumor genome, understanding cancer requires that we move beyond simply cataloguing the genes associated with it. It is critical to understand the many interactions among these genes and the corresponding proteins, and how these complex networks give rise to tumor initiation, progression and metastasis. The Cancer Cell Map Initiative (CCMI) is applying systematic approaches to comprehensively map the molecular networks that underlie cancer and to use these maps as key resources for precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project 1: Narrative Project 1 seeks to develop therapies that maximize intrinsic LMS genotoxic stress by targeting the key DNA damage response enzyme, DNA protein kinase. We have shown that most LMS have chromosomal instability (CIN) which creates hyper-dependence on this enzyme. The initial clinical trial in this Project tests the hypothesis that a very low dose of doxorubicin sensitizes LMS cells to DNA-PKi and PARPi, thereby converting CIN into a liability while minimizing nonneoplastic cell toxicity.

PHR: Local instability of short tandem repeat tracts causes severe pathologic disruption of multiple cell types and organ systems in a cohort of trinucleotide repeat expansion disorders. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project 2: Project Narrative Project 2 will define the cancer risk to relatives in LMS families through large population databases and apply whole genome sequencing (WGS) to a very large LMS cohort to definitively map both common and rare germline variant associations with LMS, focusing on TP53 and other DNA damage response (DDR) genotypes. We will further characterize LMS risk in Li-Fraumeni Syndrome (LFS) by analyzing genotypic and phenotypic data from large LFS database. This work will set the foundations for genetic testing guidelines and risk management for families affected by LMS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed work is relevant to public health given the high rates of COVID-19 in correctional systems – which disproportionately incarcerate Black, Latinx, and poor individuals thereby affecting the families and communities to which people return after release. The project is relevant to NIMHD's mission-driven strategic goals to stimulate research to improve minority health and close the gaps in health disparities. By building strategic partnerships with individuals with a history of incarceration, correctional officers and community and correctional policymakers, we will identify and test the effectiveness of various interventions specific to correctional systems that improve COVID-19 and influenza vaccine uptake, especially among minority communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project 3: Project Narrative Leiomyosarcoma (LMS) is an aggressive soft tissue sarcoma that remains difficult to cure even with intensive chemotherapy and surgery. In this study, blood samples from patients with metastatic LMS will be used to profile circulating tumor DNA to identify genomic features that are associated with a high-risk of treatment failure. Results from this study will enable the development of new risk-based and personalized treatment strategies for patients with LMS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Public Health Relevance: Binge drinking is very common in adolescents and continued alcohol abuse by this population can lead to the development of psychiatric disorders including alcohol use disorder (AUD) in adulthood. The proposed studies will continue to elucidate the molecular mechanisms of adolescent intermittent ethanol (AIE) induced behavioral phenotypes in adulthood that are under investigation by the NADIA consortium. These studies will lead to the development of epigenetic-based therapies for adolescent binge drinking induced adult psychopathology.

PHR: Core B – Biospecimen Core - Narrative: Leiomyosarcoma (LMS) is a rare and aggressive soft tissue sarcoma that can be difficult to diagnose and treat. The Biospecimen Core will support the LMS SPORE investigators by conducting expert pathology review and facilitating the collection, specialized processing, storage, and distribution of high quality biospecimens. Any residual biospecimens will be banked and made available following review to qualified investigators who have innovative ideas.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pregnant women with chronic hypertension are at an increased risk for placental-mediated disease, as 1 in 3 pregnant women with chronic hypertension deliver preterm from complications of superimposed preeclampsia or fetal growth restriction. This project will address the unmet clinical need to characterize placental dysfunction throughout pregnancy, focusing specifically on differences in functional magnetic resonance imaging metrics of perfusion, diffusion, and oxygenation and radiomics texture features between normal pregnant women and pregnant women with chronic hypertension. Furthermore, execution of automated segmentation through deep learning will be performed to standardize and improve the efficiency of post- processing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with HIV-infection and concurrent hazardous drinking, smoking, and depressive symptoms (i.e., alcohol-associated syndemic) experience higher risk of cardiovascular disease compared to those without these behavioral health conditions. The gastrointestinal (GI) microbiome is a strong candidate mechanistic pathway for the syndemic-related excess CVD risk, through GI dysbiosis, microbial translocation (MT), and systemic inflammation. This proposal aims to test the hypotheses that the alcohol-associated syndemic is associated with GI dysbiosis and subsequent CVD risk and that targeted supplementation may restore GI microbiome homeostasis and reduce inflammation; aligning with NIAAA’s objectives to prevent and treat HIV- associated comorbidities and invest in HIV/alcohol translational research that addresses health and behavioral issues clearly linked with HIV in the context of HIV, other substance use/addiction and mental health disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our project aligns with the National Alzheimer’s Project Act to “prevent, halt, or reverse Alzheimer’s disease.” It is responsive to PAR-18-877 to “develop and implement early stage (Phase I or II) clinical trials of promising…non-pharmacologic interventions” including “in individuals with…presymptomatic…stages of disease.” Because age-related hearing loss is highly prevalent, uncommonly treated, and recognized as a major risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias, this project is of high public health significance and potential high impact.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative In order to significantly advance mental health and prevent or treat neurodevelopmental disorders it is important that we understand how brain functions develop. Learning and memory processes significantly contribute to most complex brain functions, yet the biological mechanisms underlying learning and memory during early development are largely unknown. This project proposes to identify brain regions, network of activated cells and profiles of molecular changes induced by infantile learning, hence providing an unprecedented amount of novel information regarding the biological mechanisms of infantile learning and memory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Skin color is genetically derived traits that is highly variable between human subpopulations and is determined by the quantity, type and distribution of melanin pigment. Variable melanin production by skin pigment cells not only drives skin color variation but also contributes to differential disease susceptibility among humans. This proposal seeks to understand the epigenetic and transcriptional mechanisms that govern variable melanin production resulting in human pigmentation diversity and has implications for human evolution, health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiovascular disease remains the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in the United States, and cardio- metabolic conditions are the emerging threat with the epidemic of obesity and metabolic syndrome. The key objective of this training program is to prepare the next generation of physician-scientists and scientists to apply principles in cardiovascular research to understand the underlying mechanisms and develop strategies to prevent or treat these diseases, with a focus on quality, access and affordability of health care. This program seeks MDs, MD-PhDs or PhD post-doctoral trainees to train with established mentors pursuing high impact cutting edge research, towards the goal of becoming independent physician-scientists and researchers.

PROJECT_TITLE: Principles in Cardiovascular Research Training Program
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: NHLBI Institutional Training Mechanism Study Section[NITM(JA)]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: The Public Health Relevance: Adolescent binge drinking is one of the major risk factors for development of substance and alcohol-use disorders later in life. This proposal will enhance our understanding of neuronal epigenetic mechanisms associated with the development of anxiety and alcohol use disorder (AUD) in adulthood after adolescent alcohol exposure. In addition, this research will identify novel epigenetic or molecular targets that can be used to develop future therapeutic agents in treating adult psychopathology after adolescent alcohol exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Klebsiella is a leading cause of healthcare-associated and antibiotic-resistant bacterial infections, and patients who are colonized with Klebsiella in their intestine are at increased risk of infection. The goal of this project is to develop a new tool that can detect and quantify >100 different types (or strains) of Klebsiella simultaneously, both in patient samples and conditions that mimic human colonization and infection. This tool would allow us to identify the traits of Klebsiella that consistently increase the risk of infection and to screen new potential therapeutics against hundreds of Klebsiella strains simultaneously.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cervical cancer is the leading cause of cancer death in women in Zambia, a country in southern Africa, where HIV has heightened the risk of developing and dying from cervical cancer. The HPV vaccination is an evidence-based intervention that, when delivered in adolescence, can prevent most HPV infection—the cause of cervical cancer—and adolescents living with HIV, who are at greater risk, may especially benefit from effective processes to deliver the vaccination to them. Our project builds on a successful stakeholder-engaged, systems thinking approach to design and implement strategies to reduce cervical cancer in low- and middle- income countries—an approach we will use to integrate HPV vaccination services into HIV clinical care, a needed step to reduce global inequities in cervical cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This five-year K01 Mentored Research Scientist Development Award will provide me with the multi-disciplinary mentorship and training to become an independent investigator focused on optimizing the health and well- being of women and girls at high risk of HIV acquisition and transmission. My training proposal comprises (i) expert mentorship and experiential learning with senior HIV and implementation science (IS) researchers; (ii) coursework and workshops in IS theory and methods, qualitative research, and adolescent health and development; and (iii) mentored research to ensure that I am well-positioned to pursue an independent and interdisciplinary research career. The goal of the proposed mentored research project is to develop implementation strategies that strengthen a peer-support HIV treatment model for (AGYW) aged 15-24 living with HIV in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to reduce hearing loss in head and neck cancer patients treated with cisplatin chemotherapy. The study is designed to determine if atorvastatin (an FDA-approved drug used to reduce cholesterol) reduces cisplatin-induced hearing loss. If atorvastatin is protective, it could be used to preserve the hearing of patients undergoing platinum-based cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: We have previously shown in mice and non-human primates that it possible to transduce hematopoietic stem cells in vivo and achieve therapeutic transgene expression levels that would be curative in patients with thalassemia or Sickle Cell Anemia. Here we propose to further de- risk and simplify our in vivo approach. Our ultimate goal is to deliver an off-the-shelf HSC gene therapy product to patients around the globe.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease is a severely disabling brain disorder, exacting a significant toll on those afflicted and large personal, social, economic, and public health costs. The potential contributions of this research program include elucidating the neural mechanisms of cognitive deficits in Alzheimer’s disease, and developing a personalized, non-pharmacological intervention therapy for improving cognition in Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The goal is to give trainees performing basic science research an understanding of challenges involved in treating patients. One of the primary goals of our Program is to train Ph.D. students to understand clinical infectious diseases while acquiring the basic research knowledge and tools they will need to investigate and solve these problems through hypothesis-driven research. Programs that ensure that scientists understand the clinical implications of their research and facilitate the movement of scientific discoveries to the bedside are greatly needed in this country.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative: Circadian rhythms are beneficial to health, whereas their disruption can increase risk of disease. The goal of this proposal is to uncover fundamental knowledge of how circadian rhythms are generated and coordinated between cells and organs outside of the brain, using genetic mouse models and molecular approaches. The knowledge gained will be critical to understand the adverse health effects associated with rhythm disruption and guide the develop of the most effective therapies to counteract circadian disruption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The GDAN represents an attempt to bring retrospective precision medicine to the NCI's clinical trial infrastructure. As such it is a great opportunity to learn why trials that have occurred worked at a broad level, or identify patients who likely benefited from therapy, even when the trials were not successful. Our participation in this network will bring the most robust approaches for mutation calling and expression analysis, will bring novel pathway analysis approaches, and will bring an analysis of tumor genetic heterogeneity and evolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to determine the role of a new type of hybrid insulin peptide (HIP) containing insulin B-chain sequences. Discovery and characterization of B-chain HIPs and B-chain HIP-reactive T cells will be carried out in the Non-Obese Diabetic (NOD) mouse model of autoimmune diabetes. We will investigate whether B-chain HIPs can be used to induce antigen-specific tolerance in NOD diabetes and the presence of T cells reactive to B-chain HIPs in human T1D patients to develop new tetramers for tracking these T cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Delaware Comprehensive Sickle Cell Research Center (DE SCD COBRE) is a multidisciplinary research program focused on translational, clinical and psychosocial research in sickle cell disease. The overarching hypothesis of the Delaware Sickle Cell Research Program is that effective management of a common, congenital, multi-system disease requires comprehensive investigations spanning the biological, medical, psychological, and societal factors that affect both the severity of the disease and the efficacy of interventions. Future progress also requires specialty training of early career investigators with a commitment to the successful pursuit of independent funding.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Investment in training of biomedical engineers to become experts in the development of new non-invasive imaging tools and their use in patients with brain diseases such as schizophrenia and Alzheimer's Disease will greatly advance the ability to provide good medical care. The trainees from this program make significant contributions to medical technologies that enable accurate diagnosis of illnesses and determination of responses to treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Lower limb chronic wounds in diabetic populations, often caused by chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI), represents a significant global cause of morbidity, public health care burden, and a 5-year mortality rate exceeded only by lung cancer. Current therapeutic strategies are limited in their effectiveness to address the challenges due to diabetes-associated disruption of pathways involved in the healing response leading to changes in the wound environment including hyperglycemia-related microvascular changes. This proposal addresses the need for a novel therapeutic modality that improves local vascularization and accelerates healing of hard-to-heal wounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: This grant will test the hypothesis that Latexin contributes to endothelial dysfunction and microvascular thrombotic complications in the lung and that pharmacological strategies inhibiting its activities ameliorate the severity of acute lung injury in mice. Studies in this application are designed to advance our understanding of lung endothelial biology and foster the development of new approaches to the treatment of inflammatory vascular diseases of the lung, such as the acute respiratory distress syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Bone loss is a severe complication of HIV-infection that is exacerbated by antiretroviral therapy (ART) in a manner that vary widely from person to person. Defining the mechanisms underlying this loss and identifying biomarkers that predict its severity are necessary to ongoing efforts aimed at devising preventive strategies to preserve/restore bone mass and to prevent bone fractures in aging people living with HIV/ART.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – P01, Clinical Care Gaps and Unmet Needs in AYA Cancer Survivors  This program of research is focused on the cancer care experience of adolescents and young adults (AYAs) who are diagnosed with cancer during the ages of 15 to 39 years. It involves three research projects, focusing on different aspects of care relevant to AYAs: preservation of fertility and impact on cancer care, coordination of care among multiple providers including during the transition from active cancer treatment to surveillance and follow-up, and late effects that AYA cancer survivors may experience. These projects are supported by three cores that provide biostatistical, survey, and administrative support to program activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Project 1, Fertility and Cancer Care Delivery in AYAs  Fertility is a primary concern of many adolescents and young adults (AYAs) with cancer. This project will address receipt of guideline-recommended fertility counseling and use of fertility preservation strategies as part of the P01’s goal to address the unique challenges of AYAs across the care continuum. The proposed research will identify disparities in the delivery of fertility services and quantify the impact of fertility-related decisions on the timing of cancer treatment initiation and persistence across multiple cancer types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Project 2, Patterns of Care and Care Transitions in AYA Cancer Survivors  The goal of this project is to investigate patterns of healthcare utilization among adolescent and young adult (AYA) cancer survivors, assess patient-reported care experiences and barriers to appropriate care during early survivorship, and understand associations between concordance with national clinical care guidelines and patient-reported outcomes. We will use data from multiple healthcare systems and state-based resources and reports from AYA cancer survivors themselves to generate essential insights to improve care and outcomes for this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Project 3, Late Effects in the AYA Cancer Population  This project will study the late effects of cancer treatment, including cardiovascular and endocrine diseases, in adolescent and young adult (AYA) cancer survivors. We will identify demographic, clinical, and healthcare factors that influence risk of late effects and determine how disparities in health insurance, finances, care coordination and other factors impact late effects in AYA survivors. Findings from this study will help researchers and healthcare providers improve monitoring of cancer survivors and detect late effects earlier.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to future applications of and innovations in neuroscience because it seeks to open the field to more people from diverse backgrounds by providing meaningful, reinforcing experiences and a supportive network for underrepresented, minorities, disadvantaged and/or disabled, and rural 6th-8th grade students as they explore potential opportunities in neuroscience. In the proposed work, we will lead students through multiple neuroscience programs, including a novel curriculum, a summer immersion camp, and a year-long mentorship program, and in doing so we will integrate three forms of engagement experiences into a single synergistic and cohesive engagement ecosystem for participants to better envision a future for themselves in higher education and in neuroscience more specifically. The project will support NIH’s commitments to building participation in research careers through the integration of successful yet disparate single-organization practices into a unified and longitudinal statewide model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Adults with Down syndrome experience an early age of onset and increased risk for Alzheimer's disease. The proposed study addresses this public health crisis and advances science by providing the first longitudinal investigation of the effect of four lifestyle factors (physical activity, sleep, cognitive stimulation, and social engagement) on the age of onset of early Alzheimer's neurodegeneration and on the timing of the transition to clinical dementia in adults with Down syndrome. These lifestyle factors may be important modifiable resiliency mechanisms for delaying Alzheimer's disease in adults with Down syndrome despite their genetic risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The metastasis of cancerous cells to distant and vital organs is responsible for approximately 90% of cancer mortalities, and it is clear that an important barrier to tumor progression and metastasis is the survival of cancer cells that are detached from the extracellular matrix (ECM). However, our understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the survival of ECM-detached cancer cells remains rudimentary. This proposal seeks to examine how a novel pathway involving RIPK1 and the degradation of mitochondria can restrict breast cancer progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: CORE NARRATIVE – Core B, Biostatistics and Data Harmonization Shared Resource  The Biostatistics and Data Harmonization Core will oversee and guide study design, data management and data analysis across all three P01 projects so that the scientific aims of each project are addressed using standardized, high-quality datasets and the most appropriate statistical methods. The Core will ensure that data are appropriate for the questions addressed, harmonized across source data systems to enhance comparability, and analyzed and interpreted with knowledge of strengths and limitations. This approach will maximize the potential impact of P01 findings to inform and improve healthcare for adolescent and young adult cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: CORE NARRATIVE – Core C, Survey Shared Resource  The Survey Core of this P01 application will conduct a comprehensive patient survey on a wide range of recommended topics among AYA survivors with a broad set of cancer types, who are between 2 to 10 years from diagnosis, and from diverse racial and ethnic backgrounds. By surveying AYA cancer survivors directly about their care experiences and outcomes, we will collect high-quality patient-reported data that will be linked to healthcare data to ensure completion of project aims. Centralizing all survey activities in this Core will ensure efficiency and synergy in data collection across this program of research in AYA cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Mapping brain-wide connectivity of neuronal types will provide a foundation for understanding the structures of non-human primate brains, but the scale of primate brains is challenging for many neuroanatomical techniques. Here we propose to optimize and develop barcode sequencing-based neuroanatomical techniques to achieve brain-wide, high-throughput, highly multiplexed mapping of axonal projections and synaptic connectivity of neuronal types at cellular resolution in primate brains. We will apply these techniques to generate an unprecedented multi-resolution map of brain-wide projections and synaptic inputs of neurons in the macaque visual cortex at cellular resolution.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Children with moderate to severe bilateral CP have poor upper extremity abilities and segmental trunk control deficits, limiting independent functional sitting. This study will compare the efficacy of a motorized Trunk-Support- Trainer (TruST) to engage children in play-oriented practice with skill progression with static trunk support . The TruST-intervention will inform clinicians whether such training may be a unique therapeutic solution for children with bilateral CP to acquire and improve independent functional sitting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many pathogenic bacteria are notorious for surviving harsh environments, adapting to different niches in the human body, and developing tolerance to drug treatments, all examples of phenotypic plasticity. Cellular organizations, as a hallmark of cell phenotype, dictate the physiological state and fitness of bacteria, and unraveling the origins and consequences of its plasticity is key to understanding the survival, growth, adaption, and drug tolerance of pathogenic bacteria. Exploring the optimality principles for the cellular organization could help identify bottlenecking cellular processes that can serve as non-molecular-specific targets with minimal concerns of rising drug resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will investigate the role of cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) in the targeting of self-proteins in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA). We propose that this specialized type of killer cell is responsible for the initiation and maintenance of inflammation in a subset of patients with RA who have the most severe disease. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies aimed at disrupting this disease- promoting pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to examine the feasibility and safety of administering hydrogen gas to patients suffering from cardiac arrest treated with emergency heart-lung bypass. Oxygen deprivation to the brain results in severe brain injury or death in more than 50% of these patients, and hydrogen may be a therapy to directly interrupt the culpable mechanisms of brain injury. If feasible and safe, hydrogen administration may improve outcomes in cardiac arrest, stroke, myocardial infarction, organ transplant, and sepsis, all pathologies in which ischemia-reperfusion injury plays a central role.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The challenges of living with type 1 diabetes often stand in the way of getting enough exercise. Continuous blood sugar monitoring has revolutionized type 1 diabetes care but remains underutilized to sustainably support exercise and related behaviors. This research will develop a mobile application that delivers personalized encouragement and data-driven health insights based upon patterns in blood sugar, exercise, mood, and sleep, to assist people with type 1 diabetes in exercising more frequently and confidently.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Environmental factors that can be modified at community-scale, including air pollution and features of the built and natural environment, may affect the risk of developing diabetes. Better understanding of the relationship between environmental factors and diabetes will help in the development of cost-effective policies to protect public health and reduce health inequality—critical parts of the NIH mission. This study will investigate these relationships in Hispanic Community Health Study/Study of Latinos and help to understand the inter- relationship between development of diabetes and traffic-related air pollution, the neighborhood built environment, and the intensity and location of physical activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cell-cell communication plays a critical role in organ development and healing responses following injury and disease progression. Here, we employ an integrative approach of bioengineering tools, intracellular signaling reporters, and computational modeling to (1) study mechanisms that orchestrate paracrine- and mechanically induced migratory decisions in macrophages and (2) elucidate oxygen-dependent fibroblast activation and ECM remodeling via interactions with macrophages. These studies will contribute to our understanding of homeostatic macrophage-fibroblast crosstalk and lay the foundation for future studies on dysfunctional macrophage-fibroblast interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: In patients with urinary stone disease, several knowledge gaps persist regarding the impact of fluid therapy in preventing stone recurrence, and the optimal care after insertion of a ureteral stent (a thin tube inserted into the ureter to prevent obstruction of the urine flow from the kidney). This application will address these gaps by assessing the effectiveness and safety of new behavioral strategies to increase urine fluid intake, and evaluating factors contributing to discomfort following stent insertion, with the ultimate goal of improving patient care.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Children with Down syndrome are disproportionately affected by the obesity epidemic, presenting a prevention challenge that is currently unmet. For toddlers and preschoolers with Down syndrome, this project examines how motor skills development, feeding abilities, co-occurring conditions, dietary intake, and the family context provide protection or risks for overweight/obesity. The overarching goal of this project is to identify targets for effective prevention in early childhood when such efforts may enhance downstream health outcomes for those with Down syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly 40% of individuals with bipolar disorder (BD) will develop co-occurring alcohol use disorder (AUD+BD), associated with significantly worse clinical course, poorer treatment response, and increased risk for suicide relative to AUD or BD alone. Dysfunctional reward brain circuitry is a core feature of both AUD and BD yet remains largely unexplored in AUD+BD. The proposed multimodal neuroimaging study seeks to identify neurobiological targets for improving treatment and preventative interventions for AUD+BD by defining reward brain circuitry structure and function among sets of parents with AUD+BD and their unaffected adolescent offspring (dyads) relative to dyads defined by parental AUD alone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Research today provides hope and the foundation for new treatments and cures for tomorrow. Specialized education and training in clinical and translational sciences is needed to develop investigators capable of bridging the gap between the lab, the clinic, and disciplinary boundaries and to accelerate the delivery of innovations to all communities. The goal of this new Ohio State University Center for Clinical and Translational Science predoctoral T32 training program is to leverage the large, collaborative and multidisciplinary research environment of Ohio State to recruit, train and mentor a diverse cohort of trainees from a wide variety of graduate programs and colleges to become the next generation of clinical and translational science leaders who will lead high impact research that is rigorous, inclusive, ethical and intentional to achieve health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondrial cardiomyopathies, which frequently affect Complex I of the electron transport chain, are typically pediatric diseases associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Yet, patients often live months to years with often severe cardiac dysfunction, suggesting that there are compensatory mechanisms that allows for energy production despite Complex I dysfunction. Here, I investigate a newly described Complex I-dependent mechanism that may help preserve energy production.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hypertension has long been recognized as a major risk factor for cardiovascular diseases, including coronary artery disease, heart failure and stroke, and for ESRD. In the southeastern United States, and especially in Mississippi, cardiovascular and renal diseases occur much more frequently than in the rest of the country. The objective of the multidisciplinary Hypertension and Cardiorenal Diseases Research (HCDR) Training Program is to recruit, train, and mentor pre-doctoral and postdoctoral students in cardiovascular and renal research so that they become the next generation of researchers in this field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Osteoporosis affects 24.5% of women over 65 and results in fracture-related hospital admissions exceeding those of heart attacks, strokes and breast cancer combined. Current treatment options do not account for differences between age-related and estrogen deficiency related osteoporosis, because of the need for bone biopsies for determination. This study will establish a paradigm-shifting individualized treatment protocol for age- related osteoporosis and a non-invasive method for its determination, thereby reducing the major health problems and enormous burden on society and the elderly related to this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The faithful segregation of genetic material by the mitotic spindle to daughter cells is essential for the survival of an organism. Critical to this process are the many molecular motors that facilitate spindle organization and regulate the dynamics of the microtubules in the spindle. This proposal will define mechanisms that control motor activity and define how distinct protein- protein interaction networks impact spindle morphogenesis and help cells maintain genomic integrity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) affects between 5 and 7% percent of the adult US population. Most mutations associated with COPD change regions of the genome that do not code for protein but are transcribed into RNA. By combining RNA sequencing analysis of lungs from COPD patients with novel RNA structure probing technologies to identify functional RNA structures in COPD associated genes, we will illuminate new causative features of COPD and, over longer periods, inspire new RNA-based therapeutic strategies.

PHR: Dot1 and COMPASS/MLL1 histone lysine methyltransferases play essential roles in gene regulation and are deregulated in leukemias. In this application, we propose to use structural and functional approaches to elucidate the intricate mechanisms that underlie Dot1 and COMPASS/MLL1 regulation. These novel mechanistic insights will open new avenues towards therapies based on the epigenetic regulation of Dot1 and COMPASS/MLL1 activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The proposed research is relevant to the public health because obesity, which is increasing in prevalence worldwide, represents a major national cost measured by both patient quality of life and economic burden. One under explored areas in obesity-related pathophysiology changes is the defects in mucosal innate immunity as we have previously shown, using Paneth cells as a proof-of-concept. Identifying the causes of how obesogenic diet reduces Paneth cell function will provide insight into the development of intervention strategies for diseases of which Paneth cells play a critical role, such as inflammatory bowel disease, graft versus host disease, and gut infection. Our preliminary data suggests that diet-induced obesity (due to western diet [WD] consumption) leads to Paneth cell dysfunction in both humans and mice by activating FXR signaling in the intestinal epithelium and myeloid cells. Upon conclusion, we will establish how dietary fructose (a key ingredient in WD) triggers Paneth cell defects, and determine the mechanisms by which Paneth cells themselves and intestinal stem cells repair defective Paneth cells in the context of long-term WD/HFrD consumption. Our data will help design intervention strategies for obese patients with Paneth cell defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fentanyl overdose is an epidemic, responsible for over 73,000 deaths annually in the US, and the standard of care, naloxone, is not sufficient. The proposed work addresses the urgent need for a therapeutic with a different mechanism of action, one that rapidly deactivates and removes fentanyl from the body. Such a therapeutic would save lives, improve patient outcomes, and relieve burden on already strained hospital resources.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Uterine fibroids are the most common reason women undergo major surgery, with 30,000 myomectomies and 200,000 hysterectomies attributed to fibroids each year. The annual cost of care for women with fibroids is up to $34 billion with the largest burden of this expense (up to $17 billion) due to lost work and disability following fibroid surgery. In this clinical trial, we will evaluate the safety and efficacy of a new oral medication for fibroids that can decrease the large economic and social burden of fibroid surgeries and allow women to select a treatment option that avoids procedural risks and prolonged recovery time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recently, we showed that inhibition of RAGE significantly slowed glioblastoma tumor growth and invasion, one of the most fatal cancers with an average survival of less than 2 years after therapy. Inspired by this data, we propose to develop drugs that selectively inhibit the activity of RAGE in glioblastoma tumors. If successful, our studies will result in the development of a novel therapy for not only glioblastoma, but potentially for other cancers where RAGE is important for tumor growth and invasion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The vast majority of adults with Acute Respiratory Failure (ARF) in the U.S. survive, but many experience new and persistent physical, cognitive, and mental health impairments and >50% remain dependent on family caregivers who also experience elevated levels of depression. This study will clarify the relationship between expectations for recovery, self-efficacy, mental health, and coping behaviors in ARF survivor-care partner dyads. Using a mixed methods approach, we will identify modifiable factors that contribute to better mental health and dyadic coping to inform the development of a dyadic coping intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project combines the expertise of three laboratories to identify genes regulated by the Bordetella PlrSR two-component regulatory system. Our recent data indicate that one or more PlrSR-regulated genes is critical for bacterial survival in the lower respiratory tract. The gene products could serve as therapeutic targets or new vaccine components for treating or preventing pertussis (aka whooping cough), a serious respiratory illness that is increasing in the United States and other countries that use acellular pertussis vaccines.
