IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This renewal application builds on our successful execution of the RAPID EC (RCT Assessing Pregnancy with Intrauterine Devices for Emergency Contraception) trial, which demonstrated the levonorgestrel (LNG) 52 mg IUD is effective for emergency contraception (EC) and can be placed throughout the menstrual cycle, with a negative pregnancy test. This project will test the reproducibility and generalizability of our data in “real world” clinical situations, in 8 sites across the U.S. With a larger and more heterogenous population, this work could favorably impact millions of people’s IUD access globally.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To improve early access to pre-emergency care for pediatric patients, a telemedicine and medication delivery service (TMDS) is a promising innovative alternative to conventional approaches. Our objectives are to: (i) develop an electronic clinical decision support (eCDS) tool for a TMDS, (ii) derive a disease severity prediction (DSP) algorithm to enhance the eCDS for accurate triage and escalation of care, and (iii) externally validate the DSP and evaluate the eCDS in a pilot stepped wedge cluster randomized trial. This single-site study will provide essential experience and metrics for a future multi-site randomized controlled trial of the DSP integrated into the eCDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women are more represented within obese and extremely obese classifications, and women and girls are three times more likely to engage in disordered eating than men and boys. Here we propose studies to understand sex differences in the neural circuit that regulates feeding, specifically how an understudied population of neurons can modulate the effects of estrogens on food intake. Ultimately, these neurons may be critical modulators of the effects of estrogens that can be exploited to treat obesity and eating disorders in women.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The economic, environmental and health infrastructure in cities is not equally distributed nor sufficient to serve this growing urban population. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Racial and ethnic minorities – especially American Indians, Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians, and Pacific Islanders – are underrepresented in health research. The Community Health and Aging in Native Groups of Elders Resource Center for Minority Aging Research is training program that focuses on community-based research with Native communities. It will also implement the National Institute on Aging’s mandate to increase the diversity of investigators conducting research with Native populations in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE If healthy babies are sequenced near birth, when should genetic information relevant to later stages of their lives be revealed? There are different possible strategies for when this genomic information is revealed, and this research will determine their clinical feasibility, analyze their ethical, legal and social implications, understand diverse parents' preferences, and seek consensus on the necessary and desirable features of a strategy. The project will generate concrete recommendations for implementers of newborn sequencing and will hence help ensure the ethical rollout of genomic medicine for all.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative:  Heart failure (HF), the leading cause of death worldwide, is characterized by T-cell mediated inflammation and cardiac fibrosis. However, anti-inflammatory or anti-fibrotic therapies have not yet shown efficacy in the prevention or treatment of HF. The goal of this proposal is to study novel signaling pathways in T-cells that contribute to cardiac fibrosis and may result in new therapeutic targets in HF.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because the development and validation of a smartphone- based ultrasound program for trauma aims to fill a critical deficit in existing diagnostic capacity and decrease preventable deaths among injured patients in Cameroon. If found to be feasible and effective, this approach would shift clinical practice patterns in this context. The research is relevant to NIH’s mission because it seeks to lengthen the lives of trauma patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Frail older adult patients do better during and after surgery if they are in better condition before surgery, so an “app” with videos of exercises was created to help patients get in better condition by encouraging and tracking exercise. However, patients have never been asked to give feedback about the app, so this study will get feedback from frail older adult patients who need lung cancer surgery to improve the app. By combining principles of user-centered design and implementation science, our proposed research will aim to enhance the prehabilitation app for increased uptake and usage particularly among frail/pre-frail older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many patients with stroke, in particular minority and older patients, receive stroke care at hospitals without advanced stroke-related resources or expertise and may be less likely to receive life-saving reperfusion or high-quality stroke care as a result. A critical area for intervention is the way that patients are transferred between hospitals so that stroke patients are more equitably matched with the resources needed for their care. In this project, our goal is to understand the role that interhospital transfer processes play in contributing to disparities in access and outcomes for stroke patients, and to identify solutions to ensure better access and outcomes for stroke patients of all races and ethnicities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary disease and recurrent exacerbations dominate the lives of patients with cystic fibrosis (CF) infected with Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Pa). The proposed K23 project will evaluate Pa antibiotic tolerance mediated by its bacteriophage, Pf, as well as the potential of Pf as a predictive biomarker for response to antibiotic therapy. This will lead to new mechanistic insights to guide therapy in treatment of Pa associated CF pulmonary disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Mosquito-borne alphaviruses, such as chikungunya virus, causing debilitating arthritis, and Eastern equine encephalitis virus, causing fatal encephalitis, are becoming endemic in the Americas with no available vaccines or antivirals. Using reverse genetics, cutting-edge microscopy, and molecular biology approaches, we will explore the functional role of alphavirus ion channel 6K in affecting intracellular ion homeostasis, membrane modifications, and virus budding. Identifying the host proteins in the secretory pathway modifying the Golgi facilitating virus budding will provide targets for antiviral strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Suicidal thoughts and behaviors are increasing among children in the U.S., especially among Black youth. It is still very difficult to know who is at risk for suicide. In this study, we propose to measure experiences like loneliness, low self-worth, and hopelessness in young children to determine whether risk for suicide can be captured in early childhood, and whether protective factors such as racial socialization and identitity protect Black youth from developing suicidal thoughts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Delirium, an acute, fluctuating change in cognition with significant downstream consequences, is present in up to 35% of older adults in the Emergency Department (ED), but the incidence (number of patients developing delirium in the ED, versus those with delirium prior to ED visit) and time course are currently unknown. Prevention is the only effective treatment for delirium, requiring early identification of patients at-risk of developing delirium in the ED, but up to 83% of ED providers fail to recognize delirium cases, often due to lack of screening. We propose to tackle the first steps towards developing preventive and management strategies for delirium in the ED — that is, determining its incidence and time course, identifying the most relevant risk factors, and evaluating geriatric risk assessment instruments for ED delirium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Our preliminary data suggests that radiation induced pulmonary fibrosis (RIPF) is caused by radiation-induced isoprostane signaling through the thromboxane-prostanoid receptor (TPr), and that blocking TPr with a small molecule, ifetroban, significantly reduces RIPF. In this project, we test mechanistic hypotheses, ensure that ifetroban does not diminish the effect of standard of care (immune checkpoint therapy), and still works to reduce RIPF when combined with it. We also examine human radiation oncology patients to ensure that the increased isoprostanes are also present in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE  Arterial Spin Labeled perfusion magnetic resonance imaging (ASL-MRI) is the only non-invasive method to measure regional cerebral blood flow and has been included as a part of multi-modal MRI in several multisite longitudinal studies aimed at aging and Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) research. ASL data can be noisy and can also vary significantly across sites. The proposed project will develop methods for automated quality evaluation and harmonization of data that will ensure maximal data retainment, optimal statistical analysis, and biomarker development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Community-dwelling older adults admitted to a skilled nursing facility (SNF) following a hospitalization represent a medically complex and vulnerable population at high risk for several potentially adverse outcomes. This project uses a sample of Medicare beneficiaries aged 65 years and older discharged from a hospital to a SNF to develop and internally validate a parsimonious clinical prediction model for multiple separate outcomes (hospital re-admission, successful discharge home, prolonged SNF stay suggesting transition to long-term care, and 6-month mortality) using readily available clinical predictors that will allow SNF clinicians to directly obtain risk estimates through an easy-to-use web calculator. Prognostic information from this calculator can help frame conversations with patients and families related to management of acute and chronic conditions, treatment preferences, and future planning, and will lay the foundation for future work exploring how the implementation of this prognostic information can improve shared decision making and patient-oriented outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Effective vaccination is key to mitigating the burden of influenza and other respiratory infections, however frailty and associated immune system aging may reduce its effectiveness among older adults at the highest risk. This work will clarify the role of frailty in outcomes following influenza vaccination among older adults. This will inform vaccine policies and future clinical trials to optimize administration of influenza vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Older women living with HIV require adequate support from their informal care networks to meet their caregiving needs and promote mental and behavioral health as they age. Understanding the social resources that older women living with HIV have in place, including how care networks evolve over time, the factors that shape them, and how effective they are in meeting care needs, are critical areas of needed research in the HIV and aging field. Findings from this study can be used to inform social support promoting intervention development, health policy, and clinical practice to promote healthy aging among people with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Gene editing utilizes a collection of molecular technologies to change the genetic sequences in cells or organisms. Although extremely useful, gene editing technologies have several limitations, including difficulties controlling the number and location of insertions produced during transgenesis, and limitations in the scale and throughput of genome editing in lab animals such as zebrafish. This proposal seeks to address these limitations by developing several new gene editing technologies based on DNA integrases and CRISPR nucleases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prevalence of cardiac transplantation continues to increase around the globe with little improvement to patient morbidity and late stage allograft rejection. This proposal aims to understand the role of the conventional dendritic cell 1 (cDC1) subset in prolonging cardiac allograft survival and the influence of donor antigen exposure on cDC1 function. Specifically, how cDC1 signaling may facilitate a regulatory and hypoactive T cell response to improve graft survival and how such mechanisms can be targeted to decrease morbidity and improve patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One million individuals in the United States identify as transgender (0.39% of population), of which 90% are either on gender-affirming hormone therapy (GAHT) or considering starting GAHT. In this project we will apply a systems immunology approach to explore how GAHT affects immune function at the cellular, metabolic, and epigenetic level. Considering the high rates of HIV infection in transgender women in the United States, understanding how GAHT influences immune function and susceptibility to infection is relevant to public health, while in the longer-term potential immune signalling pathways can be therapeutically targeted to improve immune function during GAHT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: The overall purpose of the Texas RCMAR is to enhance the diversity of the aging research work force by mentoring scientists from underrepresented populations to help them develop sustained careers in behavioral, social, economic, and medical research with a focus on minority populations, primarily Hispanics/Latinos in Texas, the Southwestern United States, and Mexico, as well as health disparities in general. Through our Leadership and Administrative Core (LAC), Analysis Core (AnC) and Research Education Component (REC), we will continue to leverage our national and international network of colleagues to develop infrastructure to promote advances in these areas and to increase the number of investigators in the area of health and aging of minority populations and health disparities. Our success in mentoring RCMAR Scientists into independent researchers will expand, with the addition of the University of Texas at San Antonio as a new partner, joining the University of Texas Medical Branch and the University of Texas at Austin in support of our theme of Migration, Aging, and Health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative More than one million Americans present with foot drop after stroke. As our aging population grows in the United States and across the world, incidence of stroke will grow as age is a key risk factor, thus there will be a need for low-cost, easy-to-use, and scalable solutions to administer proper therapy to promote recovery. This study will evaluate a Variable Friction shoe (VF shoe), a new low-cost medical device, to offer therapy for foot drop in an at-home setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Aortic Stenosis (AS) is a significant disease of the aortic valve of the heart, which is chronic, progressive, and has a 2-year survival rate of 50% in symptomatic patients who are untreated. In as many as 30-40% of subjects with low gradient but potentially severe AS current diagnostic methods are discordant and inconclusive. The proposal will develop new MRI methods for improved stratification of these subjects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetes is a chronic disease that results from poor function of insulin-producing beta cells within the pancreas. The goal of our study is to understand how strengthening the health of beta cell mitochondria, the power plants of the cell, is important for the prevention of diabetes. Our studies will determine the relevance of supporting the health of mitochondria to ensure that beta cells can generate the energy needed to make insulin and control blood sugar.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Periodontitis affects nearly half of the US adults and is associated with poor quality of life and increased healthcare costs. Periodontitis can be prevented if the high-risk patients are identified before the disease initiation and progression. A prediction model that identifies early bone loss patterns using advanced image processing and informatics methods proposed in this study may identify high-risk patients before the disease initiation to provide preventive management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current influenza viruses do not provide broadly protective immunity due to the immunodominance of humoral immunity against evolving epitopes of the hemagglutinin head domain rather than against the conserved stalk domain. In this study, we will rationally design and test a vaccine that shifts immunodominance of humoral immunity towards the stalk domain by increasing the diversity of head epitopes, which will allow stalk-specific B cells to more readily acquire antigen and be selected into the long-lived memory B cell pool. Using multiple models of preexisting immunity, our study will reveal that increasing head epitope diversity augments broadly protective humoral immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Effective preventions and therapeutics for Staphylococcus aureus infection remain limited to antibiotics, which are challenged by increasing bacterial resistance. It is vitally important to determine the infection specific-roles of bacterial products as they contribute to pathogenesis. This project focuses on a newly identified S. aureus factor that is required for lung infection and will determine its mechanism of action, in order to elucidate therapeutic targeting potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: COMPLETE Project Narrative This prospective cluster-randomized trial examines the efficacy of an early palliative care-based communication intervention delivered by trained physician and nurse dyads, to parents of children with cancer within their practice, to foster alignment of the goals of treatment when cure is unrealistic. We hypothesize that goal alignment will facilitate hospice enrollment, lessen use of high-intensity medical interventions, pain and emotional distress in children and reduce distress in parents at end-of-life. Findings from the proposed research will provide essential information to promote communication practice standards that can be rapidly translated into practice to improve outcomes for children at end of life, and their parents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: In support of the NIAID Biodefense Research Program’s aim to develop medical countermeasures for biodefense pathogens, the NIH has funded the construction of 12 Regional Biocontainment Laboratories (RBLs) to support Biosafety Level 2 and 3 (BSL-2 and BSL-3) research. The Tulane National Primate Research Center (TNPRC) is the only National Primate Research Center with an RBL at BSL-3 for the study of high-consequence pathogens, including select agents and toxins. The proposed UC7 will provide support for everyday operation of the TNPRC RBL BSL-3 facility to facilitate research and medical countermeasure development for biodefense, emerging infectious diseases, and pandemic preparedness and response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE LIN28B is a pleiotropic RNA-binding oncofetal protein that correlates with poor prognosis in hepatocellular  carcinoma (HCC). This proposal seeks to understand how LIN28B contributes directly to the metastatic  phenotype of HCC cells and how it contributes to the angiogenic and endothelial modulatory phenotype of HCC  cells using a combination of cell, animal, and human specimen studies. I anticipate that these results will provide  rationale and targets for novel drug and biomarker development for HCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The cell cortex is the outermost layer of the cell, and it is remodeled to support changes in cell shape, including pinching the cell in two during the final stage of cell division; failure to complete this process is correlated with disease states like cancer. Before these shape changes occur, the cortex is dynamically patterned into waves of signaling and structural proteins. The work proposed here will investigate how and why these patterns form and define the role of cortical patterning in supporting successful cell division.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative We will increase the speed of single-beam SEM systems for connectomics by 10-100 fold without substan- tially increasing cost. We will build computationally efﬁcient methods for aligning and segmenting connectome datasets in a cloud-based infrastructure (BossDB). We will validate the faster pipeline for connectomics and create tools for collaborative connectomics where many individual groups are able to complete portions of larger mammalian brains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) are global crises that require translational research solutions. A dearth of qualified investigators is available for the sustained effort that will likely be required to fully address this challenge. The Training in Translational ADRD Neuroscience, or TITAN, program will provide novel and necessary training to prepare investigators to lead the nation in research to reduce the impact of these deadly diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The glycyl radical enzyme (GRE) superfamily catalyzes an array of challenging reactions using radical intermediates, including selective hydroalkylation of the alkene fumarate. Despite important applications for human health and environmental concerns, there remain large gaps in our knowledge of this superfamily, particularly within the X-succinate synthase (XSS) class. The aims proposed herein will use advanced cryo- electron microscopy techniques to probes both novel conformations and structures of GREs, as well as develop routes for in vitro cofactor installation and engineering of XSSs to provide synthetically useful C–C bond-forming catalysts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Tissue damage due to injury, disease, or congenital defect continues to be a critical clinical obstacle in human health and regenerative medicine-based therapies, while a promising strategy, still face two critical obstacles: chronic inflammation and fibrosis. We pose an innovative hypothesis whereby immuno-stromal signaling axes and fibroblast heterogeneity link together inflammation and disrupted mechanotransduction, bridging a critical gap in our understanding of tissue fibrosis and regeneration. Developing a better understanding of immuno- stromal crosstalk will help elucidate disease pathogenesis, new candidates for biomarkers, and targets for therapeutic interventions.

PHR: Project Narrative  The main goal of this project is to identify new regulators of cardiac inflammation and fibrosis, two patho- logical features that characterize several cardiac diseases. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the clear need for evidence-based, developmentally targeted, scalable, psychosocial interventions for Adolescents and Young Adult (AYA) survivors of cancer, few exist. Our proposed project builds on a successful resilience intervention designed by AYAs for AYAs, and endeavors to identify the optimal balance of smart-phone versus telehealth intervention delivery, sustainable practice of skills, and creative digital strategies for recognizing AYAs with new or escalating distress. If successful, results will inform future research and clinical strategies for integrating psychosocial and mobile health technologies aimed at improving outcomes for AYAs with cancer during both their initial treatment and their later survivorship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The public health impact of physical activity during the critical midlife period to slow cognitive aging depends on new insights about how to increase both the effectiveness and sustainability of physical activity intervention programs designed with the heart and brain in mind. Moderate-to-vigorous intensity activity is critical for these benefits, but can be difficult to achieve due to high demands on self-regulatory abilities needed to reverse sedentary habits and mange negative feelings evoked by exercise. The proposed research will develop and test the efficacy of cognitive training strategies designed to improve these self-regulatory capacities for middle-aged adults to adopt and sustain a physically active lifestyle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: There is mounting evidence for the key role of social and structural determinants of health in understanding HIV prevention and care outcomes. Successful implementation and sustainment of sociostructural interventions will need to systematically consider disparity determinants, adaptations, and other ways to ensure the outcomes of sociostructural interventions are reached and health equity is achieved. The goal of this proposal is to develop the Sociostructural Implementation Science Coordination Initiative to support the companion R01s with D&I science to coordinate data harmonization and foster opportunities for cross-site learning, as well as build the capacity of the larger research and practice fields.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social interactions with mature social partners are critical for an infant’s health and successful development as they scaffold and support far-reaching outcomes including vocabulary development, school achievement, self- control, and executive functioning. The proposed research connects one behavior of mature social partners, vocalizations, with infant autonomic activity and sustained attention, a cognitive achievement highly predictive of individual differences in infant visual attention, self-control, language, and later school achievement. The proposed research will advance the field by linking the role of in-the-moment measures of caregiver vocalization, to infant gaze and infant autonomic activity to long-term developmental outcomes such as self-regulated attention and learning, providing a potential new path to determining targets for intervention for at-risk infants.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE According to the American Cancer Society it is estimated that 800-900 new osteosarcoma cases will be diagnosed in 2020. The majority of cases are in people aged 30 or under and 5-year survival rates are approximately 70%; however, with lung metastasis this number drops to a mere 20%. In this project, we will utilize high-resolution imaging techniques and comparative models to determine the effects of the microenvironment on metastatic osteosarcoma drug response with the goal to develop novel approaches that increase the sensitivity of these cells to existing therapies and improve survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reduction of risk for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) may be possible through lifestyle change including increased physical activity. While novel and effective behavioral interventions targeting increased physical activity and positive cognitive outcomes have been developed over the past several decades, little is known about the mechanisms that lead to longer-term adherence to health-promoting levels of physical activity behavior (long-term “maintenance”). The proposed adherence-promoting mHealth intervention is designed to support the development of a psychological scaffold for long-term physical activity maintenance in midlife that will help promote cognitive health into older age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Targeted therapies have revolutionized patient care for a wide range of cancers, but are fundamentally limited by acquired resistance mutations. Current technologies used in industry to evaluate the mutational landscapes of next generation targeted therapies are limited in sensitivity, incomplete, and retrospective. This project proposes to develop and commercialize deep mutational scanning with duplex sequencing (DMS-DS), the most comprehensive and accurate platform available for measuring the mutational landscape of investigational targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: MAKERERE UNIVERSITY COLLEGE OF HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Oral diseases affect approximately 3.5 billion people globally, increasing health and economic burdens while significantly decreasing quality of life. This is especially true in sub-Saharan Africa where this burden is made worse by HIV. In this application, whose overall objective is to strengthen the oral health research capacity in Uganda, the team will work through the proposed aims to plan for the establishment of an oral health research training program for Makerere University and Uganda Christian University, that is well aligned to the NIH HIV AIDS priority area on research training of the multidisciplinary workforce required to conduct High Priority HIV/AIDS or HIV/AIDS-related research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative. Human autologous fat transplantation, widely used for soft tissue reconstruction, is seriously hampered by loss of the grafted fat because of a lack of vascular supply to support delivery of oxygen and nutrients to the transplanted fat. We propose to solve this challenge by genetically modifying harvested fat prior to transplantation with an adenovirus gene transfer vector coding for all 3 major isoforms of vascular endothelial growth factor, a potent mediator of angiogenesis. We will assess this strategy in studies quantifying the survival of human fat transplanted to immunodeficient mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Powassan virus (POWV) is a tick-borne virus that causes a 10% fatal brain disease, and a new tick POWV isolate, LI9, was found to cause highly lethal brain damage in aged mice, a finding that mimics POWV disease in elderly patients. In contrast, an attenuated POWV, LI9-P, fails to cause brain damage in mice and is a potential vaccine that differs in its ability to regulate antiviral responses of cells that form brain barriers. Paired lethal and attenuated POWVs, and our unique ability to modify POWVs, permit us to propose defining determinants of POWV disease, mechanisms of POWV entry into the brain, neuroinflammation, age-dependent POWV lethality mechanisms and potential inhibitors of brain damage applicable to the elderly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE African American and Latino youth are more likely to experience an unmet mental health or psychosocial need than do their white counterparts. School-based and pediatric primary care services are ideal hubs to provide mental health, healthcare, social services, and prevention to students and families who otherwise face barriers to care. Using Participatory Design and Community Partnered Participatory Research (CPPR), the proposed intervention is a model of care for connecting youth ages 11-24 to mental health care and supports by combining mobile technology for screening, triage and care coordination, co-created with the community and used by culturally responsive individuals called family and youth navigators, in school-based and pediatric primary care services.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Narrative Antiretroviral therapy programs put into place by PEPFAR, the Global Fund and others have resulted in a remarkable decrease in HIV-related morbidity and mortality; however, the rate of certain cancers are rising significantly as HIV population are aging. Most sub-Saharan African medical institutions are ill prepared to deal with this emerging health challenge. This Nigerian-led research-training program will build capacity in molecular cancer epidemiology, biostatistics, and clinical investigation to train researchers to conduct population-based molecular epidemiology and diagnostics research, leading to the development of preventative and therapeutic strategies to reduce incidence and decrease mortality of HIV-associated malignancies in Nigeria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Incarcerated individuals have higher rates of chronic disease than the general population, including more hypertension, diabetes, high cholesterol, and obesity. The Chronic Disease Self-Management Program (CDSMP) is an evidence-based disease management program that has been utilized in state corrections systems on a limited basis; however, there has been little deliberate research investigation into efficient and effective strategies for scaling up the intervention among older adults within state corrections systems. The research objective of this K01 is to use mixed methods research approaches to engage community-agency CDSMP leaders, correctional staff, and incarcerated individuals in developing strategies to maximize the scalability of the Chronic Disease Self-Management Program among older adults within a state correctional system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Defining and monitoring serious and other adverse events in clinical trials involving older adults with serious illness pose challenges to the research community such as the reporting of events that are: implausibly related to the intervention, misaligned with patient values, and/or stemming from well-known relationships between the events and other conditions. In 2020, the NIA sponsored an initiative to convene investigators, regulators, sponsor agency members, and patient stakeholders to address the challenges, resulting in a new framework to support improved reporting. The proposed project will 1) develop the details of the methodology for defining, classifying and reporting (S)AEs in clinical trials involving older, seriously ill adults; 2) create publicly available tools to support the research community; and 3) conduct widespread dissemination and implementation of the framework.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This proposed training program will leverage the existing HIV research and teaching platforms at University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) to support HIV capacity building at Hanoi Medical University (HMU) and Chiang Mai University (CMU). Aligning with NIH HIV research priorities, the scientific areas of HIV training will include co-occurring conditions of HIV, HIV service disparities, advanced biomedical strategies for HIV and comorbidity prevention, implementation science and digital health. With highly individualized and targeted training and support, junior to mid-career faculties and researchers at HMU and CMU will establish and assume leadership roles in a multidisciplinary HIV research and training vanguard hub to provide consultation, training, and leadership in state-of-the-art HIV prevention and treatment research throughout Southeast Asia.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Finding a permanent cure for people living with HIV is a key priority of the NIH, requiring broad and inclusive basic science research into how the virus remains latent in people on antiretroviral therapy. However, although over 70% of HIV patients live in Africa, very little of the basic science of cure research involves African patients or scientists, a key gap that needs urgent remedy. This D43 training program is a collaboration between two institutions (Washington University in St. Louis and the University of Ghana) to develop a comprehensive basic science research training program to prepare the next generation of Ghanaian researchers to conduct high- quality HIV basic science and cure research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Slip and fall accidents are a significant source of occupational injuries leading to personal and economic harm for workers and their families. The development of tools to inform better selection of slip-resistant shoes and timely replacement of worn shoes is expected to reduce slip and fall accidents. The purpose of this research is to develop and validate these tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This research project will specifically focus on the development of a low-cost and highly sensitive multiplex biosensor system integrated with a smartphone readout that can rapidly and accurately analyze a panel of wood smoke biomarkers from dual biological media (blood and urine) at anticipated low concentrations. This approach will enable a more accurate prediction of occupational exposures to wood smoke, and provide better analytical performance (e.g., sensitivity, dynamic range, detection limit, reliability, accuracy and speed) as well as operational performance (user-friendly design) for early detecting biomarkers than current methods. Once validated, the multiplex sensor platform will represent the next-generation quantitative tool for measuring mixed occupational exposures, which is fully consistent with the goals of the NIOSH Research to Practice (r2P) initiative.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: The occupational stress of fire fighting, which includes frequent exposure to psychological trauma, results in a substantial proportion of career fire fighters experiencing disabling mental health consequences. An evidence-based, peer-delivered curriculum for preventing mental health challenges in fire service recruits – the Brief Unified Protocol (BUP) -- will be a culturally competent, exportable, and efficient prevention intervention if demonstrated superior to an educational training that is similar to standard practice in Fire Academies. The objective of this research is to increase the resilience of the Nation’s Fire Service through expanding 40 years of emotional regulation research to a real-world, prevention-focused application.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Peer Delivered, Emotion Regulation-Focused Mental Health Prevention Training for Fire Fighter Trainees
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: Center for Global Health
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it offers new and improved strategies to efficiently and accurately diagnose the etiology of acute febrile illness, a requisite for effective disease control and treatment. The proposed research is relevant to the US Centers of Disease Control and Prevention as it will inform regional assessments and demonstrate a pathway for implementation of improved diagnostics by key stakeholders in a region that is highly endemic for emerging infectious diseases.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: GH20-005, Conducting Integrated Infectious Disease and Public Health Research in Peru

IC_NAME: Center for Global Health
PHR: Project Narrative Peru and Ecuador are at high risk of acute febrile illness outbreaks; however, the specific causes of acute febrile illness remain there largely unknown, limiting control measures optimized to the specific diseases, and thus the effectiveness of the public health responses. In close coordination with key offices of the Ministries of Health, our Project of Febrile Illness Surveillance in the Andean and Amazon Countries (“PISAAC”) proposes to study the etiology and epidemiology of acute undifferentiated febrile illness in strategically selected regions of Peru and Ecuador, strengthening the capacities and services for diagnosis, and the specific outbreak-oriented training of the appropriate workforce. As the surveillance platform implemented by PISAAC should serve to additional health problems, we will extend its use to antimicrobial resistance, and acute diarrheal diseases.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-GH-20-005, Project of Febrile Illness Surveillance in the Andean and Amazon Countries (PISAAC)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Aminoglycoside antibiotics (AGAs) are potent antibiotics which have long been used as potent broad spectrum antibiotics, with targets including gram-negative pathogens, MRSA, MDR-TB, and complex infectious diseases such as hospitalized CAPD and exacerbated CF. Significant limitations of the AGAs, however, are AGA-induced permanent hearing loss (ototoxicity) and nephrotoxicity which are reported to affect up to 20% of the patient population, and susceptibility to resistance due AGA and target modifying enzymes. On the basis of recent advances in the understanding of the molecular basis for AGA-induced ototoxicity, and existing knowledge of the mechanisms of resistance, this proposal seeks to design, and synthesize novel AGAs that do not suffer from the complications of toxicity, are not subject to common mechanisms of resistance, and to evaluate them both in vitro and in animal models for efficacy against gram-positive an gram-negative organisms, and lack of ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Structural racism, defined as the laws, policies, institutional practices, and entrenched norms embedded within society that foster discrimination through mutually reinforcing inequitable systems, has been indicated as a root cause of inequities in health outcomes including those related to diabetes. One form of structural racism, historic redlining, known as the practice of denying resources to communities based on race, has been shown to impact health outcomes; however, the relationship between historic redlining and contemporary diabetes outcomes has not been well-studied. Therefore, this study will address this gap in knowledge by using an experimental convergent mixed methods design to (1) understand the relationship between historic redlining and diabetes-related outcomes among adults with type 2 diabetes based on their lived experiences, (2) quantify the direct and indirect pathways through which historic redlining impacts diabetes-related outcomes; and (3) conduct hierarchical modeling to assess a) the impact of individual, interpersonal, and neighborhood level factors on individual level diabetes outcomes, b) the contribution of historic redlining exposure toward neighborhood level associations, and c) whether individual level associations are moderated by historic redlining.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE By taking advantage of an existing cohort study that is unique in having collected multiple 24-hour urine samples from over 100,000 adults, this project has the potential to convincingly settle the debate on whether a sodium intake below the population average is associated with higher mortality. This contribution is important because if sodium intake below the population average is associated with higher mortality, then salt reduction efforts should only focus on those who consume high levels of sodium, rather than the entire population. The proposed research is, thus, relevant to public health because it will help clarify dietary guidelines on salt and whether population-wide efforts, such as broad reformulation of the food supply, may cause harm among a large proportion of the population.
